It happened Wednesday. Officials say the driver died, likely by igniting himself. He had propane tanks in that vehicle.

The U.S. is stepping up pressure on Pakistan over what officials describe as a serious lack of cooperation in fighting terrorists.

Correspondent Rich Edson tells us tonight from the State Department that perception is costing the Pakistanis a lot of very real money.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

RICH EDSON, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Pakistani jets fly over a military parade in Islamabad. It's the country's 78th annual national day celebrating its founding as an independent nation. As Pakistan displays its military, the United States wanted to use more of it to address terrorist organizations operating within its borders.

The U.S. claims Pakistan shelters militant groups that launch attacks into neighboring Afghanistan against U.S. and allied forces. Pakistan denies the long-held U.S. accusations.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Terrorists are on the run in our country. We have eliminated their safe havens, hideouts, IED factories, whatever else. And we believe we still need to continue our work because the border with Afghanistan is porous.

EDSON: Pakistan says the U.S. needs to address safe havens in Afghanistan, and points out it continues allowing American forces to use Pakistani roads to supply its military in Afghanistan.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: It's been a long war for you guys. And Pakistan also wants peace in Afghanistan because instability in Afghanistan is bad news for Pakistan. So therefore if our objective is the same I believe it's only a matter of reconciling our strategies.

EDSON: The $1.3-trillion government funding bill President Trump just signed includes a prohibition against Pakistan receiving U.S. security funding. The U.S. will only pay Pakistan that money when the secretaries of state and defense certify the Pakistani government is addressing security concerns and militant groups inside its borders.

HEATHER NAUERT, STATE DEPARTMENT SPOKESWOMAN: We've certainly seen Pakistan take some positive steps in the right direction, but a lot more needs to be done in terms of Pakistan cracking down not just on the Taliban but on the Haqqani Network and other terror networks as well.

EDSON: In January the Trump administration announced it would withhold security related aid to Pakistan, officials say nearly $2 billion. Since then the countries have tried to improve their relationship. Earlier this month Ambassador Alice Wells met with Pakistan's foreign secretary. She says Pakistan still needs to take sustained and decisive steps against terrorist organizations.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

EDSON: The responsibility to manage this relationship soon falls to CIA Director Mike Pompeo if the Senate confirms him as secretary of state. In December Pompeo said if Pakistan fails to address these save havens the U.S. will do everything it can to make sure they no longer exist. Bret?

BAIER: Rich Edson at the State Department. Rich, thank you.

In tonight's "Whatever Happened To" segment, one of our viewers asks what happened to the Pakistani doctor who helped the CIA confirm the compound where Usama bin Laden was hiding? That doctor was later imprisoned by the Pakistani government. As part of the omnibus spending bill signed today by President Trump, $33 million is being withheld from Pakistan until that doctor's release. Tonight correspondent Conor Powell has the story.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

BARACK OBAMA, FORMER U.S. PRESIDENT: The United States has conducted an operation that killed Usama bin Laden, the leader of Al Qaeda.

CONOR POWELL, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: President Obama's announcement on the evening of May 1st, 2011, marked the end of one of America's largest manhunts in history. Americans across the country celebrated bin Laden's demise. And the raid of the terror mastermind's compound produced a treasure trove of information on Al Qaeda's operation. But not of it would have happened without the help of a little known Pakistani physician, Dr. Shakeel Afridi.

LT. COL. MICHAEL WALTZ (RET), FORMER CHENEY COUNTERTERRORISM ADVISER: Dr. Afridi was critical to capture and kill Usama bin Laden because he ran a vaccination program for hepatitis that allowed us to confirm the DNA of terrorists in the area, but specifically for the bin Laden family.

POWELL: While Afridi and the Navy Seals that undertook the raid were immediately hailed as heroes in the United States, back at home in Pakistan Dr. Afridi is not hailed as a hero but instead as a traitor. Following the bin Laden raid, Pakistani authorities arrested Dr. Afridi and sentenced him to 33 years in prison. His charge -- treason.

In an exclusive interview from his jail cell with FOX News in 2012, Dr. Afridi detailed his torture at the hand of Pakistan's infamous intelligence service, the ISI. Dr. Afridi described how he had been burned with cigarettes and shocked with electricity while ISI officers cursed America.

As a candidate Donald Trump vowed to secure Dr. Afridi's release, telling FOX News in April of 2016 he could get it done in two minutes.

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Two minutes, I would tell them let him out, and I am sure they would let him out, because we give a lot of aid to Pakistan. We give a lot of money to Pakistan.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

POWELL: The Trump administration has significantly cut financial aid to Pakistan in hopes of pushing Islamabad away from its historical and traditional ties to militants. But so far Pakistani leaders have refused President Trump's multiple requests to release Dr. Afridi, who continues to languish in a Pakistan prison to this day. Bret?

BAIER: Conor Powell in our Middle East newsroom. Conor, thank you.

Back here in the U.S., the archbishop of New York says the Democratic Party has turned its back on Catholics. Cardinal Timothy Dolan writes in the "Wall Street Journal," quote, "I am a pastor, not a politician, and I've certainly had spats and disappointments with politicians from both of America's leading parties. But it saddens me and weakens the democracy millions of Americas cherish when the party that once embraced Catholics now slams the door on us." We have asked the Democratic National Committee for a response and have not received one as of yet.

Up next, the panel on the president's decision to reluctantly sign that $1.3 trillion budget and then blasting Congress for giving it to him.

First, beyond our borders tonight. A car bombing outside a sports stadium in Afghanistan's southern Helmand province kills 13 people and wounds 40 others. The explosion occurred after Afghan new year's celebrations were winding down and revelers were on their way home. No word yet on who was behind that attack.

A Spanish supreme court judge is charging 13 Catalan separatists politicians with rebellion for their attempt to declare independence from Spain. Several of those politicians, including the former regional president, have fled to other countries following the failed secession attempt in late October.

The European Union is recalling its ambassador from Moscow. It is the latest move in the uproar over a poisoning of a former Russian spy in England. A top Russian lawmaker and senior Russian diplomat are now both criticizing Britain's accusations against the Kremlin, just some of the other stories beyond our borders tonight. We'll be right back.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: I will never sign another bill like this again. I am not going to do it again. Nobody read it. It's only hours old.

I was thinking about doing the veto but because of the incredible gains that we have been able to make for the military, that overrode any of our thinking.

I'm calling on Congress to give me a line item veto for all government spending bills. We have to get rid of the filibuster rule and go to 51 votes in the Senate.

BAIER: President Trump reluctantly signing that $1.3 trillion budget bill. And that was after a head fake on Twitter today with the veto threat, saying "I am considering a veto of the omnibus spending bill based on the fact that the 800,000 plus DACA recipients have been totally abandoned by the Democrats (not even mentioned in bill) and the BORDER WALL which is desperately needed for our national defense is not fully funded."

There are numerous criticisms of this bill. The immigration part is part of it, but Ann Coulter from the conservative side "Threatened veto not over the -- on the wall but over the DREAMERS. Can I sign up with Mueller?" Continuing, "CONGRATULATIONS PRESIDENT SCHUMER." And finishing up "I will never another bill like this again. Yeah, because you'll be impeached." Ann Coulter has a unique way of expressing conservative angst about the president's action, but there was some pushback today about the signing of this bill.

Let's bring in our panel, Charles Hurt, opinion editor for "The Washington Times," Leslie Marshall, syndicated talk radio host, and Tom Bevan, Real Clear Politics co-founder and publisher. You know, Charlie, that tweet really sent people scrambling. Most of Congress had gone home.

CHARLES HURT, OPINION EDITOR, "THE WASHINGTON TIMES": The Trump tweet.

BAIER: Yes. I don't know about the Ann Coulter tweet, too. But the original Trump tweet about there could be a veto.

HURT: And you get a sense from that press conference that he actually had to be convinced by the White House to go ahead and sign it and not actually veto it. He really did seem to be torn about it. But I think come November if we're looking at a complete wipeout of Republican seats, I think we can look back to this week and see the beginning of that dissatisfaction with voters. I don't know what Republicans have, what reason Republican voters have to vote for Republicans at this point.

BAIER: The tax law they will say.

BAIER: And Leslie, he said it was going to be a press conference and he only like two questions, so it really wasn't a press conference. But everybody covered it, and it took the moment and it took the news for the day. Did he get it both ways? Did he get to show his anger about it and sign it?

LESLIE MARSHALL, RADIO TALK SHOW HOST: I think right now every time the president speaks because he said I am vetoing this and then he signs it, I am having a press conference, only taking two questions, it's really hard for any of us I think regardless if we're left or right to believe anything he says. I just had to throw that out.

But I do think as a Democrat it's absolutely laughable that he thinks the Hispanic community and the American people are going to buy that Democrats are throwing DACA under the bus, they don't care, when the House and the Senate are majority Republican, and the majority of Republicans are what wrote these thousands of pages that nobody seems to know what's in.

SEN. JOHNNY ISAKSON, (R) GEORGIA: The Democrats leveraged some power out of that narrow margin that we have. And why they didn't use that power to get DACA I will never understand.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: Republicans, Tom, say they just want to use this as an election issue. There was a three-year deal that was floating up there on Capitol Hill but it never came to fruition.

TOM BEVAN, REAL CLEAR POLITICS CO-FOUNDER: I think Trump actually did play Democrats last time around on the government shutdown this issue very well, saying Democrats were trying to hold the military hostage, as Charlie said. This time, though, they got the military spending. And ironically, Trump wasn't upset about the spending. He didn't even mention it. That's why the tweet was so funny. He said people didn't believe it because he said the reason I might veto this is because DACA is not in the bill.

BAIER: That's what set Ann Coulter off.

BEVAN: Exactly, and that was why it was so incredible and nobody really believed that he was going to pull the trigger and veto this thing. But now Republicans have their spending and DACA is going to have to be done as a side issue, as a separate bill. But I don't think there is any indication from anyone on Capitol Hill that that is going to be something that gets done this year.

BAIER: Let's be real here. This is really the last big bill we're going to see out of Congress before the midterms, right?

BEVAN: That's right. This is essentially it. There's not much else that can or will get done. And Republicans, to Charlie's point, they are hanging their hat on the tax bill. And that's not a certain thing that that is going to be enough to get them over the finish line in November and hold on to the majorities.

BAIER: Reaction to the change of national security advisor from McMaster to Bolton. Listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. LINDSEY GRAHAM, (R) SOUTH CAROLINA: John Bolton is the right guy at the right time with a worldview that I think will reinforce the president's instincts to go after our enemies and to be a better ally.

SEN. CHRIS VAN HOLLEN, (D) MARYLAND: He has a history being a warmonger. He is very trigger happy.

GRAHAM: He believes in the military option as a last resort.

VAN HOLLEN: The other thing is his management style. People who worked with him have said he is a kiss up and kick down kind of guy. He's a yes man to the president, but he treats people below him very badly.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: All of this commentary today was really something. And many channels as I mentioned before said this talking head is now national security adviser, kind of not talking about his past as maybe a foreign policy expert.

HURT: It's funny when the talking heads are accusing somebody of just being a talking head. And also even with Van Hollen there, either he is a kiss up guy or he's a warmonger. I don't know how you can really be both. But I think that at this point President Trump is at the very least proved pretty adept at changing the dynamics with some of these foreign relationships whether it's with China or with North Korea. And I think give him a little latitude on that.

BAIER: Take Bolton out of it, but it seems like they are ready for action, war on a number of fronts. But it's not legitimate war, but you have Tillerson for Pompeo at State, obviously a different tone there. Gary Cohn leaving, Kudlow coming. You have John Dowd in the personal legal, and then Joe diGenova we think, but there may be some back and forth about that. And it seems like the White House is getting ready to take on forward leaning.

MARSHALL: I think especially with regard to foreign policy. And you can't just take Bolton out of the equation. When you put him with Pompeo that it is going to be more confrontational especially regarding Iran and North Korea. I am not sure that sit down with Kim Jong-un is going to happen essentially with these latest appointments by the president.

BAIER: We will see. Next up, the Friday lightning round.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: China is going to end up treating us fairly. For many years they had free rein. They don't have free rein anymore. Last year we lost $500 billion on trade with China. We can't let that happen.

HUA CHUNYING, CHINESE FOREIGN MINISTRY (through translator): China does not want a trade war but we are never afraid of having one. We have the confidence and capacity to handle any challenge. We hope the U.S. side can be cautious in the decision making so as not to bring the economic and trade relations between China and the U.S. into danger.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: Well, the tariffs are coming, and now China is saying that they are considering their own retaliatory tariffs up to $3 billion U.S. products. We are back with the panel. Charlie?

HURT: These are scary times. But in the 18 years since Bill Clinton normalized trade relations with China, presidents from both parties have claimed to take China seriously, and this is the first president to actually show some action on it.

BAIER: The U.S. China Business Council says China just wants to know what the Trump administration wants them to.

MARSHALL: There was a lot of verbal threatening, if you will, and not a lot of specifics. If you look at what we have, we are talking about a 0.1 percent impact to the economy of China. We have been in a trade war for over a decade, and so when people say they are fearful of a trade war, that's ridiculous. Like you said, with former presidencies, we have had this trade deficit, we've had job loss. And I have to say something has to be done. The president said he was going to get tough for China. That's why some people voted for him, and I think this is the right thing.

BAIER: OK. Mark that down, Leslie Marshall.

MARSHALL: Yes, I agree with the president.

BAIER: The week of Facebook, which was not a great week for Facebook. Now they are apologizing. Tom, what will happen here?

BEVAN: Its' a fascinating story in that there is this double standard that's been applied to what the Trump campaign did in 2016 versus what Obama did in 2012. But more broadly speaking, the question is this is part of the growing backlash against big tech in general that we see around the country. And I think Facebook is in trouble. I think where this is ultimately going to lead, we're going to continue to have incidents like this privacy violations and the like, and it's going to lead to regulation if not breaking up big tech in the end.

BAIER: It's going to be fascinating to watch from a government perspective and watching Capitol Hill.

OK, winners and losers. It's Friday. Winner first, then loser.

BEVAN: Winner, Loyola Chicago and Sister Jean. This is not your typically Cinderella story. When you watch these kids come off the court after three thrilling victories and hug Sister Jean, this is more than your typical March Madness Cinderella story.

BAIER: I'm going to interrupt. She said God is going to help us and we've got to box out 23.

(LAUGHTER)

BEVAN: She is the best. Loser, the progressive resistance. Illinois this week, primaries. Marie Newman had tons of backing. Dan Lipinski held on there by the skin of his teeth, and also J.B. Pritzker who is sort the establishment billionaire ran away with that race.

BAIER: Winner and loser?

MARSHALL: I'm going to go with the kids that are marching here in Washington tomorrow, the March for Life. Rubio even said they have done more in five weeks than Congress has done in years, and I think it's awesome that they are not just having words. They're putting them to action and then they're going to vote. And I think we're going to see some of those people in Congress in gubernatorial positions in the future.

My loser, Ben Carson for two reasons. One, and it's not just the price of the dining set, OK. One, as a woman, you throw your wife under the bus even though she said she didn't, he blames the wife. And then second, Jesus would approve of his response, the guy who came to town on a donkey? He's lost twice for me there.

BAIER: All right, winner and loser?

HURT: Winner is Maryland school cop Blaine Gaskill who proved that a good guy with a gun can stop a bad guy with a gun. The loser is the innocent America taxpayer who will be paying for this nonsense for generations.

BAIER: There you go. Thank you, panel, got around quickly.

When we come back, it's Friday. "Notable Quotables."

BAIER: We love this time. Do you? Finally tonight, this week's "Notable Quotables."

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: We still want our community to remain vigilant as we always should.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: This is what we prepare for, and this is what we pray that we never have to do.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: We have got to take back extra drugs. They shouldn't be sitting in your medicine cabinet.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Facebook should have had a way of verifying everything and not being sloppy about it.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Although the intelligence is uniform that no votes were changed, they weren't doing it for fun.

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: I had a call with President Putin.

MITCH MCCONNELL, (R) SENATE MAJORITY LEADER: Calling him wouldn't have been high on my list.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: We are going to see the spending bill soon.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: We're in good shape.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Come to the well if you have read this language.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: As far as the content of the bill, this could have been written by President Obama.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: This was manure management. Keep us in the dark and feed us manure.

TRUMP: I will never sign another bill like this again.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: This can be a very mean-spirited town.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: This is the longest interview on FOX that I have ever had.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: This $31,000 table had been bought. I said what the heck is that all about?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Thank you for your willingness on a snowy day to travel through this town that sometimes understands snow removal, sometimes doesn't.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: What advice would you give to the 25-year-old Donald Trump knowing what you know today?

TRUMP: Don't run for president.

(LAUGHTER)

(APPLAUSE)

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: One week. Make sure this weekend to tune in to "FOX News Sunday." Chris will have an exclusive interview with the treasury secretary Steven Mnuchin. He will also have some of the students in that protest. They will be here in Washington all weekend. You'll hear a lot about that as well.

Thanks for inviting us into your home tonight. That's it for this SPECIAL REPORT, fair, balanced, and unafraid. Make it a great weekend. THE STORY hosted by Martha MacCallum starts right now. Martha?

urn:contentItem:5RYY-BND1-JBHT-D024-00000-00Stock Sell-Off; Economic War; Terror in France; Bolton Career Highlights; 21st Century Threat; Eagle-Eyed; Financial Pressure; U.S. Pressures Pakistan on Terrorism Activity Within Its Borders; Pakistan Doctor that Helped in Raid that Killed bin Laden Still in Pakistani Prison; President Trump Signs Spending Bill2018-03-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:23ZLexisNexisStock Sell-Off; Economic War; Terror in France; Bolton Career Highlights; 21st Century Threat; Eagle-Eyed; Financial Pressure; U.S. Pressures Pakistan on Terrorism Activity Within Its Borders; Pakistan Doctor that Helped in Raid that Killed bin Laden Still in Pakistani Prison; President Trump Signs Spending BillLanhamFULL TEXT

BRET BAIER, FOX NEWS HOST: Hey -- Kimberly. Have a great weekend.

After an 11th hour veto threat President Trump reluctantly signs a massive budget bill promising he will never sign something like this again.

China strikes back at the U.S. over the President's tariffs, and stocks plummet again.

And what happened to that Pakistani doctor who helped facilitate the raid that killed Osama bin Laden?

This is SPECIAL REPORT.

Good evening. Welcome to Washington. I'm Bret Baier. President Trump head-faked (ph) a veto today but ultimately signed a huge budget bill to keep the government funded and to assure a huge increase in military spending. But he may have been reactive to conservative criticisms and a lot of it of what is in and not in the massive omnibus bill.

Afterward he blasted Congress in general, and Democrats in particular, for coming up with a plan no one had time to read and full of money he says is being wasted. And he is promising he will never do it again.

Chief White House correspondent John Roberts starts us off tonight, as he often does, on the north lawn. Good evening -- John.

JOHN ROBERTS, FOX NEWS CHIEF WHITE HOUSE CORRESPONDENT: Bret -- good evening to you.

The President's veto threat might have been an elaborate bluff but it did have the intended effect; his event this afternoon to criticize the omnibus spending bill becoming must-see TV.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Hello, everybody.

ROBERTS: On Wednesday President Trump said he would support it. This morning he threatened to veto it but ultimately the President held his nose and signed the $1.3-trillion bill to keep the government running for the next six months.

TRUMP: I say to Congress I will never sign another bill like this again. I am not going to do it again. Nobody read it. It's only hours old.

ROBERTS: The veto threat was issued in a morning tweet. President Trump upset that the 800,000 plus DACA recipients have been totally abandoned by the Democrats, not even mentioned in bill. And the border wall which is desperately needed for our national defense is not fully-funded.

The tweet prompted an urgent phone call from the Secretary of Defense urging the President for the sake of the military to sign the bill.

TRUMP: We looked at a veto. I looked very seriously at the veto. I was thinking about doing the veto but because of the incredible gains that we have been able to make for the military -- that overrode any of our -- any of our thinking.

ROBERTS: Mattis showed clear relief that the Pentagon would be getting the additional $60 billion that Congress signed off on.

JAMES MATTIS, U.S. SECRETARY OF DEFENSE: Today we received the largest military budget in history, reversing many years of decline and unpredictable funding. And together we are going to make our military stronger than ever.

ROBERTS: President Trump railed against the Senate rule that requires Democratic support and Democratic spending ideas to pass the bill. And he ripped the Democrats for not including anything for the so-called Dreamers.

TRUMP: I can tell you this, and I say this to DACA recipients, that the Republicans are with you. They want to get your situation taken care of. The Democrats fought us. They just fought every single inch of the way.

ROBERTS: But a month ago Democrats did offer a fix -- a bipartisan proposal to fully fund the wall, $25 billion in exchange for a path to citizenship for 1.8 million Dreamers but the White House rejected it.

Democrats accused the President of creating unnecessary drama at the 11th hour with his veto threat.

SEN. CHRIS VAN HOLLEN (D), MARYLAND: This is now what people are getting used to about Donald Trump and I don't think it's wearing well on the public. This constant say one thing one day, change your mind the next day -- and that's what we're seeing here.

ROBERTS: The initial plan was for the President to sign the bill after scorching it.

TRUMP: This ridiculous situation that took place over the last week.

ROBERTS: But President Trump didn't want the enduring image of him putting pen to paper on something he didn't like so aides removed a chair and signing document before he arrived.

And more staff changes at the White House. After months of rumors, President Trump announced national security advisor H.R. McMaster is leaving to be replaced by former U.N. Ambassador John Bolton. Bolton is well known for his outspoken, hard line positions including support for the Iraq war which the President opposed.

JOHN BOLTON, FORMER U.S. AMBASSADOR TO THE UNITED NATIONS: I have never been shy about what my views are but frankly, what I've said in private now is behind me, at least, effective April 9th. And the important thing is what the President says and what advice I give him.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

ROBERTS: And there appears to be another staffing change in the works. The White House is not pushing back at all on an imminent departure of V.A. Secretary Dr. David Shulkin. The only thing that appears to be in question now is the timing of when he will depart -- Bret.

BAIER: Several of those timing issues. John -- thank you.

It was another carnage-filled day on Wall Street. The Dow lost 425 -- the lowest closing for 2018. The S&P 500 was down 53. The Nasdaq dropped 174. For the week the Dow was off 5.75 percentage points. The S&P 500 was off 6. The Nasdaq dropped 6.5.

Let's get some analysis now from Deirdre Bolton of the Fox Business Network in New York. Good evening -- Deirdre.

DEIRDRE BOLTON, FBN HOST: Good evening -- Bret.

You have to go all the way back to January 2016 to see the stock market lose this much ground in one week. So financial, tech stocks -- they were the biggest waste (ph). Investors are basically worried about three big forces -- a potential trade war with China, the direction of interest rates and the affordability of the $1.3 trillion in new government spending.

So most investors think that the tariffs that we have imposed on China and the ones that China has imposed in retaliation are just the beginning. So as a result some investors are reconsidering their positions in Boeing, Apple, Nike, Intel, Starbucks -- each of those companies got between 10 percent and 20 percent of their sales from China last year.

The Federal Reserve raised interest rates on Wednesday -- penciled in two more hikes for this year so higher rate makes all borrowing more expensive. And that can be a headwind for the economy and for the stock market.

Congress passing and the President signing that massive bill -- spending bill was a darned if you do, darned if you don't scenario for market sentiment but today it added pressure. So tech has been a market bright spot in the past year but with Facebook on the ropes, the sector fell like all others. Some traders telling this week feels like that brutal two-week selloff that we say in February. So buckle your seat belts for next week.

Bret -- back to you.

BAIER: Deidre -- thank you.

Well, China is fighting back against President Trump's decision to impose those massive tariffs on their products sent to the U.S. And that leaves the world's two largest economies on the brink of a major economic conflict.

Correspondent Gillian Turner looks at what that possibly could mean.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

GILLIAN TURNER, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: U.S. farmers are increasingly fearful that a full-fledged trade war with Beijing is on the horizon. That includes Rob Shaffer (ph), a fourth generation soy bean farmer in Emory, Illinois who also serves on the board of directors of the American Soy Bean Association.

ROB SHAFFER, AMERICAN SOY BEAN ASSOCIATION: I'm just trying to make sure that we get it through to the, you know, administration this far (ph). And I think -- I think they understand it, but I just want to make sure that they understand how it's affected the people out in the Midwest and as far as, you know, my bottom line.

TURNER: China is now threatening to impose its own retaliatory tariffs on up to $3 billion worth of U.S. import. And American farmers caution that such a move might incentivize competitors of American companies to step in and grab their business.

SHAFFER: Brazil and Argentina, ok, are willing and eater to take our share of the Chinese market. And once you lose a customer, it's awful hard to get them back.

TURNER: China's commerce ministry is currently considering a 15 percent tariff on American exports to include dried fruit, wine and steel pipes, plus a 25 percent tariff on pork and recycled aluminum.

China's also drafting a list of 128 American products it would target in the future should the U.S. and China fail to reach a bilateral trade agreement.

TRUMP: We're losing $375 billion with China. It could be $504 billion depending on the way you count. It's bad.

TURNER: But the U.S. isn't just battling China in the traditional trade sector. In addition to the disputes over hard goods, such as fuel and poultry, the two sides are now clashing over the tech sector.

Over the past two weeks, alarming signs of a major fallout have emerged. The Trump administration blocked China from buying U.S. tech giant Qualcomm -- a deal worth $117 billion. And China subsequently pulled its own multimillion dollar investment from U.S. private equity powerhouse Blackstone.

GORDON CHANG, AUTHOR, "COMING COLLAPSE OF CHINA": Our society is dependent upon innovation in ways that it hasn't been before. But the Chinese are taking the fruits of that innovation and they're stealing it in ways which are predatory, mercantilist and completely unacceptable.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

TURNER: This on-going U.S.-China tariff dispute underscores Washington's latest worry that China will displace America as the world's innovation hub and that Shanghai or Shenzhen may soon become the new Silicon Valley -- Bret.

BAIER: Gillian -- thank you.

French counterterrorism officials are investigating a hostage situation today that resulted in the deaths of three people. The hostage taker was also killed. France's president says the evidence suggests it was a terror attack possibly tied to ISIS.

Senior foreign affairs correspondent Greg Palkot has details tonight.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

GREG PALKOT, FOX NEWS SENIOR FOREIGN AFFAIRS CORRESPONDENT: Terrorists striking again in France -- this time within the south-western corner of the country. An armed man claiming ties to ISIS hijacked a car and fired at a group of police in the city of Carcassonne and then drove over to the nearby village of Trebes, where he took 50 hostages in a supermarket.

During a three-hour siege, a policeman swapped himself for them so they could monitor the situation. When police heard shots they stormed the store killing the gunman. All told -- four died, 16 were injured including the brave officer.

EMMANUEL MACRON, FRENCH PRESIDENT (through translator): Security forces intervened in an extremely fast and coordinated manner after what was first an attack against police officers.

PALKOT: Police say the man responsible for the mayhem was 26-year-old Moroccan-born Radouane Lakdim. He was under surveillance as a radical but not thought a threat. He did shout "Allahu Akbar" or "God is great" when he burst into the store. ISIS later claimed responsibility.

GERARD COLLOMB, FRENCH INTERIOR MINISTER (through translator): It means the terrorism threat is very strong. We have not had attacks for several months. This one happened without us being able to oppose it.

PALKOT: During failed negotiations Lakdim also demanded the release of a suspected terrorist now on trial linked to ISIS attacks in Paris in 2015. Some 240 people have been killed in attacks in France in recent years. The locals are shaken again.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: My husband called me to say our children were safe inside their school.

PALKOT: Terror that still has all of Europe on high alert and concerned.

ANGELA MERKEL, CHANCELLOR OF GERMANY (through translator): We would like to express our sincere condolences. We stand firmly at France's at this terrible time.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

PALKOT: Authorities are now saying they've made an arrest in connection with the French attacks. They're trying to see if the gunman had help or if he acted alone. Whichever -- he was very dangerous -- Bret.

BAIER: Greg Palkot in London. Greg -- thank you.

The job of national security advisor does not require senate confirmation. That's good news for Ambassador John Bolton, the incoming national security adviser, who has dealt with congressional skepticism before.

While Fox viewers here, of course, most recently remember him as a Fox News contributor on foreign policy issues, several news outlets today repeatedly referred to the ambassador as a talking head.

National security correspondent Jennifer Griffin is at the Pentagon with details on the career of President Trump's new national security advisor. Good evening -- Jennifer.

JENNIFER GRIFFIN, FOX NEWS NATIONAL SECURITY CORRESPONDENT: Good evening -- Bret.

Ambassador John Bolton is no stranger to Washington. In 2005 he received a recess appointment from President Bush to serve as U.N. Ambassador because his contentious past made confirmation impossible.

Bolton began his career during the Reagan administration at USAID before moving to the Justice Department as assistant attorney general. Under President George H.W. Bush he served as assistant secretary of state for international organization and oversaw U.S. involvement in groups like the U.N. of which Bolton was no fan, famously saying in 1994, "The Secretariat building in New York has 38 stories. If you lost 10 stories today it wouldn't make a bit of difference."

A Yale-educated lawyer Bolton rose to prominence during the Florida recount in 2000 dispatched by Republicans to look over the shoulders of Palm Beach County canvassing board members as they examined punch card ballots in search of hanging chads. A few months later Bolton was rewarded with an appointment to serve as undersecretary of state for arms control. He was the Bush administration's point man on weapons of mass destruction until 2005.

A proponent of the Iraq war, he was involved in the negotiated handover of Libya's WMD transporting Libya's entire nuclear weapons program to Oakridge, Tennessee after the invasion of Iraq.

Bolton has called for regime change in Iran along with North Korea and recently penned "The Legal Case for Striking North Korea First". In 2003, Bolton represented the U.S. at six-party talks designed to prevent North Korea from going nuclear. Three years later Kim Jong-un's father conducted his country's first nuclear test -- Bret.

BAIER: Jennifer Griffin, live at the Pentagon. Jennifer -- thank you.

Former Georgia Democratic Governor and U.S. Senator Zell Miller has died. Miller served as governor from 1991 to 1999. He was called out of retirement at the age of 68 in 2000 to fill the final four years of a Senate term.

The lifelong Democrat spent most of that term attacking his own party for veering away from mainstream values. He even gave the key note address at the 2004 Republican convention.

Miller's family says he died peacefully at his home after being treated for Parkinson's disease. Zell Miller was 86.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BAIER: The U.S. is indicting nine Iranians for conspiring to break into computers and o attack U.S. agencies, businesses and universities. The Justice Department officials believe all nine are still in Iran.

This comes as the woman in charge of securing the President's nuclear arsenal from hackers says the system is a very attractive target. Marianne Bailey is the new head of NSA cyber security. Tonight she gives her first national TV interview to chief intelligence correspondent Catherine Herridge.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MARIANNE BAILEY, NSA CYBER SECURITY: With technology brings great opportunity, also risk.

CATHERINE HERRIDGE, FOX NEWS CHIEF INTELLIGENCE CORRESPONDENT: NSA's Marianne Bailey is charged with guarding national security systems across the defense department and U.S. government with hundreds of thousands of probing attacks daily.

BAILEY: Cyber security is a leveler. You don't have to be a nation state to have really advanced tools and actually invoke damage.

HERRIDGE: What are they trying to accomplish?

The motto of the Boy Scouts of America, "Be prepared", is taking on new meaning tonight. A father in Utah says scouting officials are not prepared to deal with his son who has Down Syndrome. Scout officials say they're doing everything they can to make things right.

Correspondent Alicia Acuna has the story.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

ALICIA ACUNA, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: 22 merit badges fill Logan Blythe's Boy Scout sash, building blocks to becoming an Eagle Scout -- an honor the local Utah Council told him he'd earned. But the next day an e-mail arrived from the National Boy Scouts of America that crushed his accomplishments.

CHAD BLYTHE, FATHER OF LOGAN BLYTHE: He stopped going to meetings. He's not been -- he's no longer willing to put on the uniform.

ACUNA: The advancement committee concluded that the local scouts granted the 15-year-old with Down syndrome unapproved accommodations. In part writing, "The young man must do the requirements as written, including leadership responsibilities."

The family is suing the National Boy Scouts of America for $1 and accommodations. The BSA turned down an interview request but in a statement apologized for any confusion saying "The process of achieving the Eagle Scout rank is rigorous for any scout, but it is designed so that accommodations can be made for Scouts with disabilities or special needs."

On background an official inside the BSA tells Fox News Logan Blythe was not stripped of the Eagle Scout rank and it still is available to him. The National Disabilities Advancement team wants to work directly with the Blythe family to help determine a path that is both appropriate and empowering for him.

The family's attorney says the statement is not good enough and that his client's Down syndrome prevents him from meeting all of the requirements.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: It leads you to believe that there is a mechanism available for him to achieve that, when there's not. In this particular boy's case this is as much as he can do.

BLYTHE: Let's accept that and give him the badge. Why -- because he's A, tried and B, done his best.

ACUNA: The family attorney tells me he now has a sit down meeting scheduled with a high ranking Boy Scout official on Monday -- Bret.

The Trump administration is proposing new regulations that effectively ban bump stocks, devices that increase the firing rate of some firearms. We saw that in Las Vegas. Attorney General Jeff Sessions released a statement a short time ago. The Justice Department will take public comments on this proposal.

Last fall a gunman used bump stocks in that attack on concert goers in Las Vegas killing 58 people. The regulation announcement comes on the evening before a planned march here in Washington to protect gun violence. We don't know how many people will be here but it's expected to be a big event.

Up next, U.S. relations with Pakistan at a low point and costing the Pakistanis billions of dollars potentially.

First here's what some of our Fox affiliates around the country are covering tonight.

Fox 45 in Baltimore as a teenage girl who was shot when a classmate opened fired inside their Maryland High School has died. Sixteen-year-old Jaelynn Willey was taken off life support by her family. The girl was shot by a former boyfriend who was killed during that incident.

Fox 40 in Sacramento as demonstrators decrying this week's fatal police shooting of an unarmed black man stopped traffic and kept fans from getting to an NBA basketball game for some time. The protest over the shooting of 22-year-old Stephon Clark tied up city streets, blocked an interstate and briefly delayed the NBA game between the hometown Kings and Atlanta.

And this is a live look at Atlanta from our affiliate Fox 5. The big story there tonight, a spokesman says Atlanta's airport has taken downs its Wi-Fi network and disabled parts of its Web site out of an abundance of caution following a ransomware cyber attack on the city's computer network. Federal authorities are working with police to investigate this incident which crippled several on line services provided by city of Atlanta.

That's tonight's live look outside the Beltway from SPECIAL REPORT.

We'll be right back.

BAIER: Authorities at Travis Air Force Base in California are investigating a security breach in which a vehicle burst into flames after crashing through the main gate as terrorism. It happened Wednesday. Officials say the driver died, likely by igniting himself. He had propane tanks in that vehicle.

The U.S. is stepping up pressure on Pakistan over what officials describe as a serious lack of cooperation in fighting terrorists.

Correspondent Rich Edson tells us tonight from the State Department that perception is costing the Pakistanis a lot of very real money.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

RICH EDSON, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Pakistani jets fly over a military parade in Islamabad. It's the country's 78th annual national day celebrating its founding as an independent nation. As Pakistan displays its military, the United States wanted to use more of it to address terrorist organizations operating within its borders.

The U.S. claims Pakistan shelters militant groups that launch attacks into neighboring Afghanistan against U.S. and allied forces. Pakistan denies the long-held U.S. accusations.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Terrorists are on the run in our country. We have eliminated their safe havens, hideouts, IED factories, whatever else. And we believe we still need to continue our work because the border with Afghanistan is porous.

EDSON: Pakistan says the U.S. needs to address safe havens in Afghanistan, and points out it continues allowing American forces to use Pakistani roads to supply its military in Afghanistan.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: It's been a long war for you guys. And Pakistan also wants peace in Afghanistan because instability in Afghanistan is bad news for Pakistan. So therefore if our objective is the same I believe it's only a matter of reconciling our strategies.

EDSON: The $1.3-trillion government funding bill President Trump just signed includes a prohibition against Pakistan receiving U.S. security funding. The U.S. will only pay Pakistan that money when the secretaries of state and defense certify the Pakistani government is addressing security concerns and militant groups inside its borders.

HEATHER NAUERT, STATE DEPARTMENT SPOKESWOMAN: We've certainly seen Pakistan take some positive steps in the right direction, but a lot more needs to be done in terms of Pakistan cracking down not just on the Taliban but on the Haqqani Network and other terror networks as well.

EDSON: In January the Trump administration announced it would withhold security related aid to Pakistan, officials say nearly $2 billion. She says Pakistan still needs to take sustained and decisive steps against terrorist organizations.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

BAIER: Rich Edson at the State Department. Rich, thank you.

In tonight's "Whatever Happened To" segment, one of our viewers asks what happened to the Pakistani doctor who helped the CIA confirm the compound where Usama bin Laden was hiding? That doctor was later imprisoned by the Pakistani government. As part of the omnibus spending bill signed today by President Trump, $33 million is being withheld from Pakistan until that doctor's release. Tonight correspondent Conor Powell has the story.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

BARACK OBAMA, FORMER U.S. PRESIDENT: The United States has conducted an operation that killed Usama bin Laden, the leader of Al Qaeda.

CONOR POWELL, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: President Obama's announcement on the evening of May 1st, 2011, marked the end of one of America's largest manhunts in history. Americans across the country celebrated bin Laden's demise. And the raid of the terror mastermind's compound produced a treasure trove of information on Al Qaeda's operation. But not of it would have happened without the help of a little known Pakistani physician, Dr. Shakeel Afridi.

LT. COL. MICHAEL WALTZ (RET), FORMER CHENEY COUNTERTERRORISM ADVISER: Dr. Afridi was critical to capture and kill Usama bin Laden because he ran a vaccination program for hepatitis that allowed us to confirm the DNA of terrorists in the area, but specifically for the bin Laden family.

POWELL: While Afridi and the Navy Seals that undertook the raid were immediately hailed as heroes in the United States, back at home in Pakistan Dr. Afridi is not hailed as a hero but instead as a traitor. Following the bin Laden raid, Pakistani authorities arrested Dr. Afridi and sentenced him to 33 years in prison. His charge -- treason.

In an exclusive interview from his jail cell with FOX News in 2012, Dr. Afridi detailed his torture at the hand of Pakistan's infamous intelligence service, the ISI. Dr. Afridi described how he had been burned with cigarettes and shocked with electricity while ISI officers cursed America.

As a candidate Donald Trump vowed to secure Dr. Afridi's release, telling FOX News in April of 2016 he could get it done in two minutes.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

POWELL: The Trump administration has significantly cut financial aid to Pakistan in hopes of pushing Islamabad away from its historical and traditional ties to militants. But so far Pakistani leaders have refused President Trump's multiple requests to release Dr. Afridi, who continues to languish in a Pakistan prison to this day. Bret?

BAIER: Conor Powell in our Middle East newsroom. Conor, thank you.

Back here in the U.S., the archbishop of New York says the Democratic Party has turned its back on Catholics. urn:contentItem:60TM-6RP1-JCMN-Y4W7-00000-00Stocks end another day of sharp swings with meager gains2020-09-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:23ZLexisNexisStocks end another day of sharp swings with meager gains

Sep 11, 2020( MarketBeat: https://www.marketbeat.com/ Delivered by Newstex) In this July 9, 2020 file photo, signage is shown at the New York Stock Exchange, in New York. Stocks are rising modestly in early trading on Wall Street as a bumpy, holiday-shortened week of trading winds down. The S&P 500 was up 0.4% in the early going Friday, Sept. 11. (AP Photo/Mark Lennihan, File)NEW YORK (AP) — Stocks ended with meager gains on Wall Street Friday following another rocky day of sharp swings.

The S&P 500 climbed 0.1% but still ended with its second weekly loss in a row. Momentum has been lightning-quick to shift on Wall Street recently. The Nasdaq composite, which includes many of the superstar tech stocks that have been the focus of the market's recent selling, lost 0.6% after flip-flopping earlier between gains and losses. It had swung at least 1.3% in each of the last five days, with four of those down. The Dow rose 131 points, or 0.5%. THIS IS A BREAKING NEWS UPDATE. AP's earlier story appears below. Stocks keep swinging between gains and losses on Wall Street Friday, as a tumultuous week of abrupt stops and starts comes to a close. The S&P 500 was down 0.1% in afternoon trading, after a roller-coaster day where it careened from a gain of 0.9% to an equivalent loss. Momentum has been lightning-quick to shift on Wall Street recently, and a similar morning gain for the S&P 500 on Thursday gave way to a 1.8% loss for its fourth drop in five days. The Nasdaq composite, which includes many of the superstar tech stocks that have been the focus of the market's recent selling, was down 0.7% after flip-flopping earlier between gains and losses. It has swung at least 1.3% in each of the last five days, with four of those down. The Dow Jones Industrial Average was up 105 points, or 0.4%, at 27,639, as of 2:46 p.m. Eastern time. Analysts expect swings to continue to rattle markets for weeks, if not months, as investors wait for more clarity on several key issues. At the head of the list of uncertainties, for now at least, is what to do with Big Tech stocks. Apple, Amazon and others soared through the pandemic as their businesses boomed despite the recession. The coronavirus accelerated a shift to online life that's benefited them, and a pile-on of investors into Big Tech sent their share prices soaring to levels that critics said were simply too high. (Ad) The coronavirus knocked the wind out of stocks. But there are 5 Companies that could be HUGE in 2020 and 2021! Time to get your FREE Report on these 5 Companies that could DOMINATE! (Tickers Included) Apple had a nearly irrepressible run this summer where it rose in 13 out of 14 weeks. Zoom Video Communications surged above $450 per share earlier this month after starting the year at less than $70. That all came to an abrupt halt last week. Worries that the stocks had gotten overheated helped send the S&P 500 to its worst three-day run in nearly three months, and the Nasdaq composite slid 10%. Tech stocks and the market broadly recovered a bit on Wednesday, and they seemed to regain their stride Thursday morning, only for an afternoon swoon to batter them again. On Friday, tech stocks again swung from gains to losses. The fluctuations came even after Oracle reported stronger profit for its latest quarter than analysts expected. It also gave a forecast for profits in the current quarter that topped Wall Street's expectations. After leaping as much as 7.9% in the morning, its stock was virtually flat. Big Tech and the high-growth area of the stock market "just got ahead of itself,' said Jason Pride, chief investment officer of private wealth at Glenmede. 'It doesn't matter how it got there, it matters that it got there and now we're kind of deflating that overvaluation a little bit.' The S&P 500 is on track for a loss of 2.6% this week. That would be its second weekly loss in a row, something that hasn't happened for nearly four months. After rising as much as 1.5% shortly after trading began, Apple fell back to a loss of 1.3%. Apple is on pace for a loss of 7.4% this week, which would be its worst since March, when the market was still plummeting on worries about the recession caused by the pandemic. Movements for it and other Big Tech stocks matter more than ever for broad market indexes because their immense size means they can influence the S&P 500 almost by themselves. Five Big Tech companies make up nearly 23% of the index's entire value. One big factor that remains in the stock market's favor is the Federal Reserve, which continues to pump aid into the economy. It has slashed short-term interest rates to record lows and bought up all kinds of bonds to support markets. It also said recently it will keep delivering stimulus even if inflation rises above its target level, as long as inflation had been well under it before then. A report on Friday showed that inflation remains low, though it was higher than economists expected. Consumer prices rose 1.3% in August from a year earlier, a shade above the 1.2% that investors were expecting. Following the report, the yield on the 10-year Treasury gave up an earlier gain. It was at 0.66%, down from 0.68% late Thursday. Unprecedented amounts of aid from Congress, along with the Federal Reserve, also helped the stock market halt its nearly 34% plummet in late March. But it looks less likely by the day that Congress will approve more support for the limping economy before the November elections, even though investors say such stimulus is crucial after unemployment benefits and other stimulus has expired. Senate Democrats on Thursday shot down a scaled-back package proposed by Republicans, saying it shortchanged too many needs. Investors are also worried about all the uncertainty that elections bring generally, which can result in big changes for tax laws and regulations that affect corporate profits. Concerns are likewise high about trade tensions between the United States and China, among other major economies, and whether the expectations building for a coming COVID-19 vaccine prove to be too optimistic. European stock markets made modest moves. The German DAX was close to flat, and the French CAC rose 0.2%. The FTSE 100 in London rose 0.5% after data showed the British economy recouped further lost ground during July after a swath of coronavirus restrictions on businesses were lifted. Asian markets were stronger. Japan's Nikkei 225 rose 0.7%, the Hang Seng in Hong Kong climbed 0.8% and stocks in Shanghai added 0.8%. The Kospi in South Korea was close to flat. ___ AP Business Writer Yuri Kageyama contributed. Top 8 Companies That Are Adapting to a Post-Coronavirus World[1]The unintended consequences of the coronavirus pandemic are being played out in homes and apartments throughout the world. More and more employees are working from home, that's if they have a job to go to. Entire industries are effectively shut down as the world attempts to slow the spread of the virus. At some point, however, things will return to normal. But it will be a new normal. There are many businesses that won't reopen, and many industries that will forever be changed. As an investor, now is the time to get out your crystal ball. Timing the market is a fool's errand. But looking at what industries are positioned to thrive in a world that will be changed by the coronavirus is a prudent strategy. We've identified 8 companies that are adapting to what the economy will be like in a post-coronavirus world. It will undoubtedly be more digital than it already is. Supply chains may become more vertically integrated as 'Made in America' may take on a whole new meaning. As will the idea of working from home, going to a concert, or even preparing a meal. View the "Top 8 Companies That Are Adapting to a Post-Coronavirus World"[2]. urn:contentItem:60YY-3RB1-DY9S-T0NG-00000-00Stocks end bumpy day lower after Trump's positive virus test2020-10-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:23ZLexisNexisBUSINESSStocks end bumpy day lower after Trump's positive virus testStan Choe And Damian J. TroiseThe Associated Press

NEW YORK - Wall Street's major stock indexes fell on Friday after President Donald Trump tested positive for the coronavirus, but the losses ended up milder than investors braced for early in the morning.

The S&P 500 slumped 1.7% as soon as trading began, only to churn through another turbulent session. By the end of the day, it had trimmed its loss to 1%, down 32.38 points at 3,348.42. Despite the drop, most of the stocks in the index were higher, and the S&P 500 still managed to close out its first winning week in the last five.

The paring of losses came as optimism rose that Washington may be able to get past its partisanship to deliver more support for the economy. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi told airlines in the afternoon to stop furloughing workers because aid for them is imminent. She said a wider rescue package for the economy, one that investors have long been agitating for, could also perhaps be on the way.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average swung from a loss of 433 points to a gain of 44 points through the day. It ended at 27,682.81, down 134.09 points, or 0.5%.

Big technology stocks remained weak, and the Nasdaq composite fell 251.49, or 2.2%, at 11,075.02. It's a sharp departure from much of the summer, when Big Tech stocks carried the market higher. The tech slump was also the main reason for the S&P 500's drop.

Treasury yields ticked higher, though, and smaller stocks were also stronger than the rest of the market in a sign of optimism. The Russell 2000 index of small-cap stocks gained 8.09, or 0.5%, to 1,539.30.

Earlier Friday, markets appeared set for a much uglier day. Stock futures and Treasury yields tumbled after Trump tweeted overnight that he and First Lady Melania Trump had tested positive for COVID-19.

Analysts said some of the market's movements could be explained by investors building up expectations for a Joe Biden victory of the White House, with Election Day a little more than a month away. That could mean higher tax rates and tighter regulations on companies, which would limit profits and hurt stock prices, though it could also raise the odds of more stimulus for the economy.

"To say this potentially could be a big deal is an understatement," Rabobank said in a commentary. "Anyway, everything now takes a backseat to the latest incredible twist in this US election campaign."

After the market closed, the White House announced that Trump was "fatigued" and will spend a "few days" at a military hospital on the advice of his physicians. The announcement said that the visit is precautionary and that Trump will work from the hospital's presidential suite.

The White House also said Trump had been injected with an experimental antibody drug combination for the virus made by Regeneron. The company's shares rose 3% in after-hours trading.

Trump's positive COVID-19 test also highlights the continued spread of the pandemic. The potential for a further ramp up in virus infections as the weather turns colder is raising worries that governments may put some more restrictions on businesses.

Also stirring up the market's movements Friday was the latest report on U.S. jobs growth, which is usually the headline economic data of each month but almost became an afterthought. Employers added fewer jobs last month than economists expected, the third straight month of slower hiring.

The slowdown is yet another sign that the recovery is trailing off, said Mike Zigmont, director of trading and research at Harvest Volatility Management. The numbers don't inspire bullishness, but they could be a brighter signal for more help from Congress.

"If the conclusion is that the economic data disappoints, Wall Street may say that's added incentive for the next stimulus deal to eventually go through and more quickly," he said.

All the uncertainty is making an already shaky market even more so. Stocks have been swinging recently amid a raft of open questions for investors: Who will win the election, and what will it mean for the economy? Will the relationship between the world's two largest economies, the United States and China, keep worsening? Did stocks get too expensive after their 60% surge to record heights through the summer, Big Tech in particular?

In recent days, the dominant question has been whether Washington will be able to get past its partisanship to deliver more aid to the economy.

Extra benefits for laid-off workers and other support for the economy that Congress approved in March has expired, and investors have been clamouring for more assistance. Layoffs have remained stubbornly high across the country, and parts of the economy have slowed with the support from Congress gone.

The House of Representatives passed a Democratic $2.2 trillion package Thursday night, but it has little chance of getting through the Republican Senate. Talks between Democrats and Republicans on a compromise are continuing, but skepticism is high.

Airlines have announced the furloughs of tens of thousands of workers, saying they need more support from Washington as demand for travel has vanished. After Pelosi said in the afternoon that some kind of aid was imminent, their shares shook off earlier losses to climb. American Airlines rose 3.3% and United Airlines climbed 2.4%.

The yield on the 10-year Treasury rose to 0.69% from 0.68% late Thursday, after pulling back from an earlier loss.

In Europe, stocks also trimmed their losses as the day progressed. Trading in Asia was thin, with markets in Shanghai and Hong Kong closed. The Nikkei 225 fell 0.7% after the Tokyo Stock Exchange resumed trading following an all-day outage due to a technical failure.

___

AP Business Writer Elaine Kurtenbach contributed.

urn:contentItem:60YX-2581-DYMD-60F2-00000-00Stocks end bumpy day lower after Trump's positive virus test2020-10-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:23ZLexisNexisBUSINESS NEWSDOMESTIC NEWSStocks end bumpy day lower after Trump's positive virus testSTAN CHOE and DAMIAN J. TROISEAP Business WritersNEW YORK

NEW YORK (AP) — Wall Street’s major stock indexes fell on Friday after President Donald Trump tested positive for the coronavirus, but the losses ended up milder than investors braced for early in the morning.

The S&P 500 slumped 1.7% as soon as trading began, only to churn through another turbulent session. By the end of the day, it had trimmed its loss to 1%, down 32.38 points at 3,348.42. Despite the drop, most of the stocks in the index were higher, and the S&P 500 still managed to close out its first winning week in the last five.

The paring of losses came as optimism rose that Washington may be able to get past its partisanship to deliver more support for the economy. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi told airlines in the afternoon to stop furloughing workers because aid for them is imminent. She said a wider rescue package for the economy, one that investors have long been agitating for, could also perhaps be on the way.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average swung from a loss of 433 points to a gain of 44 points through the day. It ended at 27,682.81, down 134.09 points, or 0.5%.

Big technology stocks remained weak, and the Nasdaq composite fell 251.49, or 2.2%, at 11,075.02. It’s a sharp departure from much of the summer, when Big Tech stocks carried the market higher. The tech slump was also the main reason for the S&P 500’s drop.

Treasury yields ticked higher, though, and smaller stocks were also stronger than the rest of the market in a sign of optimism. The Russell 2000 index of small-cap stocks gained 8.09, or 0.5%, to 1,539.30.

Earlier Friday, markets appeared set for a much uglier day. Stock futures and Treasury yields tumbled after Trump tweeted overnight that he and First Lady Melania Trump had tested positive for COVID-19.

Analysts said some of the market’s movements could be explained by investors building up expectations for a Joe Biden victory of the White House, with Election Day a little more than a month away. That could mean higher tax rates and tighter regulations on companies, which would limit profits and hurt stock prices, though it could also raise the odds of more stimulus for the economy.

“To say this potentially could be a big deal is an understatement,” Rabobank said in a commentary. “Anyway, everything now takes a backseat to the latest incredible twist in this US election campaign.”

After the market closed, the White House announced that Trump was “fatigued” and will spend a “few days” at a military hospital on the advice of his physicians. The announcement said that the visit is precautionary and that Trump will work from the hospital’s presidential suite.

The White House also said Trump had been injected with an experimental antibody drug combination for the virus made by Regeneron. The company's shares rose 3% in after-hours trading.

Trump’s positive COVID-19 test also highlights the continued spread of the pandemic. The potential for a further ramp up in virus infections as the weather turns colder is raising worries that governments may put some more restrictions on businesses.

Also stirring up the market’s movements Friday was the latest report on U.S. jobs growth, which is usually the headline economic data of each month but almost became an afterthought. Employers added fewer jobs last month than economists expected, the third straight month of slower hiring.

The slowdown is yet another sign that the recovery is trailing off, said Mike Zigmont, director of trading and research at Harvest Volatility Management. The numbers don't inspire bullishness, but they could be a brighter signal for more help from Congress.

“If the conclusion is that the economic data disappoints, Wall Street may say that’s added incentive for the next stimulus deal to eventually go through and more quickly,” he said.

All the uncertainty is making an already shaky market even more so. Stocks have been swinging recently amid a raft of open questions for investors: Who will win the election, and what will it mean for the economy? Will the relationship between the world’s two largest economies, the United States and China, keep worsening? Did stocks get too expensive after their 60% surge to record heights through the summer, Big Tech in particular?

In recent days, the dominant question has been whether Washington will be able to get past its partisanship to deliver more aid to the economy.

Extra benefits for laid-off workers and other support for the economy that Congress approved in March has expired, and investors have been clamoring for more assistance. Layoffs have remained stubbornly high across the country, and parts of the economy have slowed with the support from Congress gone.

The House of Representatives passed a Democratic $2.2 trillion package Thursday night, but it has little chance of getting through the Republican Senate. Talks between Democrats and Republicans on a compromise are continuing, but skepticism is high.

Airlines have announced the furloughs of tens of thousands of workers, saying they need more support from Washington as demand for travel has vanished. After Pelosi said in the afternoon that some kind of aid was imminent, their shares shook off earlier losses to climb. American Airlines rose 3.3% and United Airlines climbed 2.4%.

The yield on the 10-year Treasury rose to 0.69% from 0.68% late Thursday, after pulling back from an earlier loss.

In Europe, stocks also trimmed their losses as the day progressed. Trading in Asia was thin, with markets in Shanghai and Hong Kong closed. The Nikkei 225 fell 0.7% after the Tokyo Stock Exchange resumed trading following an all-day outage due to a technical failure.

___

AP Business Writer Elaine Kurtenbach contributed.

Oct 02, 2020( MarketBeat: https://www.marketbeat.com/ Delivered by Newstex) Pedestrians pass the New York Stock Exchange, Friday, Oct. 2, 2020, in New York. Stocks are pulling lower Friday, as Wall Street's first reaction to President Donald Trump's testing positive for the coronavirus was to retrench. (AP Photo/John Minchillo)NEW YORK (AP) — Wall Street's major stock indexes fell on Friday after President Donald Trump tested positive for the coronavirus, but the losses ended up milder than investors braced for early in the morning.

The S&P 500 slumped 1.7% as soon as trading began, only to churn through another turbulent session. By the end of the day, it had trimmed its loss to 1%, down 32.38 points at 3,348.42. Despite the drop, most of the stocks in the index were higher, and the S&P 500 still managed to close out its first winning week in the last five. The paring of losses came as optimism rose that Washington may be able to get past its partisanship to deliver more support for the economy. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi told airlines in the afternoon to stop furloughing workers because aid for them is imminent. She said a wider rescue package for the economy, one that investors have long been agitating for, could also perhaps be on the way. The Dow Jones Industrial Average swung from a loss of 433 points to a gain of 44 points through the day. It ended at 27,682.81, down 134.09 points, or 0.5%. Big technology stocks remained weak, and the Nasdaq composite fell 251.49, or 2.2%, at 11,075.02. It's a sharp departure from much of the summer, when Big Tech stocks carried the market higher. The tech slump was also the main reason for the S&P 500's drop. Treasury yields ticked higher, though, and smaller stocks were also stronger than the rest of the market in a sign of optimism. The Russell 2000 index of small-cap stocks gained 8.09, or 0.5%, to 1,539.30. Earlier Friday morning, markets appeared set for a much uglier day. Stock futures and Treasury yields tumbled after Trump tweeted overnight that he and First Lady Melania Trump had tested positive for COVID-19. Analysts said some of the market's movements could be explained by investors building up expectations for a Joe Biden victory of the White House, with Election Day a little more than a month away. That could mean higher tax rates and tighter regulations on companies, which would limit profits and hurt stock prices, though it could also raise the odds of more stimulus for the economy. (Ad) He's pinpointed 18 recommendations that went on to soar 1,000% or more. And he just went public with what he predicts will be his next 1,000% winner. 'To say this potentially could be a big deal is an understatement,' Rabobank said in a commentary. 'Anyway, everything now takes a backseat to the latest incredible twist in this US election campaign.' Trump's positive COVID-19 test also highlights the continued spread of the pandemic. The White House physician said the president is expected to continue carrying out his duties 'without disruption' while recovering. But the potential for a further ramp up in infections as the weather turns colder is raising worries that governments may put some more restrictions on businesses. Also stirring up the market's movements Friday was the latest report on U.S. jobs growth, which is usually the headline economic data of each month but almost became an afterthought. Employers added fewer jobs last month than economists expected, the third straight month of slower hiring. The slowdown is yet another sign that the recovery is trailing off, said Mike Zigmont, director of trading and research at Harvest Volatility Management. The numbers don't inspire bullishness, but they could be a brighter signal for more help from Congress. 'If the conclusion is that the economic data disappoints, Wall Street may say that's added incentive for the next stimulus deal to eventually go through and more quickly,' he said. Other reports on the economy were mixed. Consumer sentiment was stronger than economists expected, which is key because their spending drives the bulk of the economy. Orders for machinery and other long-lasting goods also strengthened by more than expected, but growth in factory orders fell short of forecasts. All the uncertainty is making an already shaky market even more so. Stocks have been swinging recently amid a raft of open questions for investors: Who will win the election, and what will it mean for the economy? Will the relationship between the world's two largest economies, the United States and China, keep worsening? Did stocks get too expensive after their 60% surge to record heights through the summer, Big Tech in particular? In recent days, the dominant question has been whether Washington will be able to get past its partisanship to deliver more aid to the economy. Extra benefits for laid-off workers and other support for the economy that Congress approved in March has expired, and investors have been clamoring for more assistance. Layoffs have remained stubbornly high across the country, and parts of the economy have slowed with the support from Congress gone. The House of Representatives passed a Democratic $2.2 trillion package Thursday night, but it has little chance of getting through the Republican Senate. Talks between Democrats and Republicans on a compromise are continuing, but skepticism is high. Airlines have announced the furloughs of tens of thousands of workers, saying they need more support from Washington as demand for travel has vanished. After Pelosi said in the afternoon that some kind of aid was imminent, their shares shook off earlier losses to climb. American Airlines rose 3.3%, United Airlines climbed 2.4% and Delta Air Lines gained 2.1%. The yield on the 10-year Treasury rose to 0.69% from 0.68% late Thursday, after pulling back from an earlier loss. In Europe, stocks also trimmed their losses as the day progressed. Germany's DAX lost 0.3%, and France's CAC 40 rose less than 0.1%. The FTSE 100 in London edged up 0.4%. Trading in Asia was thin, with markets in Shanghai and Hong Kong closed. The Nikkei 225 index shed strong early gains to lose 0.7% after the Tokyo Stock Exchange resumed trading following an all-day outage due to a technical failure. ___ AP Business Writer Elaine Kurtenbach contributed.
