Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:6103-34X1-JCSC-J1CP-00000-00Stocks End Bumpy Day Lower After Trump's Positive Virus Test2020-10-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:23ZLexisNexisNEWSStocks End Bumpy Day Lower After Trump's Positive Virus Test

Major U.S. stock indexes ended lower at the end of another bumpy day after President Donald Trump tested positive for the coronavirus. Stocks did erase some of their early losses and still posted their first weekly gain in five weeks. The S&P 500 fell 1%, ... Major U.S. stock indexes ended lower at the end of another...

Major U.S. stock indexes ended lower at the end of another bumpy day after President Donald Trump tested positive for the coronavirus. Stocks did erase some of their early losses and still posted their first weekly gain in five weeks. The S&P 500 fell 1%, ...

Major U.S. stock indexes ended lower at the end of another bumpy day after President Donald Trump tested positive for the coronavirus. Stocks did erase some of their early losses and still posted their first weekly gain in five weeks. The S&P 500 fell 1%, after being down as much as 1.7% earlier. Small-company stocks bucked the downward trend and ended higher. Even though more stocks rose than fell, major indexes were dragged lower by losses in big technology companies like Apple and Microsoft. Airlines rose after House Speaker Nancy Pelosi told them to stop furloughing workers because aid for them is imminent. THIS IS A UPDATE: AP’s earlier story appears below. Wall Street is easing off its knee-jerk reaction to sell after President Donald Trump tested positive for the coronavirus, and stocks are clawing back much of their sharp losses from earlier in the morning on Friday. After slumping as much as 1.7% after trading began, the S&P 500 wavered through the day before cutting its loss to 0.5% by the afternoon. Most stocks across the market were higher, including two out of three in the S&P 500. The paring of losses came as optimism rose that Washington may be able to get past its partisanship to deliver more support for the economy. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi told airlines in the afternoon to stop furloughing workers because aid for them is imminent. She said a wider rescue package for the economy, one that investors have long been agitating for, could also perhaps be on the way. The Dow Jones Industrial Average swung from a loss of 433 points to a gain of as much as 44 points. It was up 2 points, or less than 0.1%, at 27,819, as of 2:08 p.m. Eastern time. Smaller stocks were rallying more than the rest of the market, and the Russell 2000 index of small-cap stocks was up 0.3%. Big technology stocks remained weak, though, and the Nasdaq composite was down 1.6%. It's a sharp departure from much of the summer, when Big Tech stocks carried the market higher, though their remarkable ascent left critics calling them too expensive. Earlier Friday morning, markets appeared set for much sharper declines. Stock futures and Treasury yields tumbled after Trump tweeted overnight that he and First Lady Melania Trump had tested positive for COVID-19. Analysts said some of the market’s movements could be explained by investors building up expectations for a Joe Biden victory of the White House, with Election Day a little more than a month away. That could mean higher tax rates and tighter regulations on companies, which would limit profits and hurt stock prices, but it could also raise the odds of more stimulus for the economy. “To say this potentially could be a big deal is an understatement,” Rabobank said in a commentary. “Anyway, everything now takes a backseat to the latest incredible twist in this US election campaign.” Trump’s positive COVID-19 test also highlights the continued spread of the pandemic. The White House physician said the president is expected to continue carrying out his duties “without disruption” while recovering. But the potential for a further ramp up in infections as the weather turns colder is raising worries that governments may put some more restrictions on businesses. Also stirring up the market’s movements Friday was the latest report on U.S. jobs growth, which is usually the headline economic data of each month. Employers added fewer jobs last month than economists expected, the third straight month of slowing hiring. The slowdown is yet another sign that the recovery is trailing off, said Mike Zigmont, director of trading and research at Harvest Volatility Management. The numbers don't inspire bullishness, but they could be a brighter signal for more help from Congress. “If the conclusion is that the economic data disappoints, Wall Street may say that’s added incentive for the next stimulus deal to eventually go through and more quickly,” he said. Other reports on the economy were more mixed. Consumer sentiment was stronger for September than economists expected, which is key because their spending drives the bulk of the economy. Orders for machinery and other long-lasting goods also strengthened by more than expected in August, but growth in factory orders fell short of forecasts. All the uncertainty is making an already shaky market even more so. Stocks have swung through turbulent trading recently amid a raft of open questions for investors: Who will win the election, and what will it mean for the economy? Will the relationship between the world’s two largest economies, the United States and China, keep worsening? Did stocks get too expensive after their 60% surge to record heights through the summer, Big Tech in particular? In recent days, the dominant question has been whether Washington will be able to get past its partisanship to deliver more aid to the economy. Extra benefits for laid-off workers and other support for the economy that Congress approved in March has expired, and investors have been clamoring for more assistance. Layoffs have remained stubbornly high across the country, and parts of the economy have slowed with the support from Congress gone. The House of Representatives passed a Democratic $2.2 trillion package Thursday night, but it has little chance of getting through the Republican Senate. Talks between Democrats and Republicans on a compromise are continuing, but skepticism is high. Airlines have announced the furloughs of tens of thousands of workers, saying they need more support from Washington as demand for travel has vanished. After Pelosi said in the afternoon that some kind of aid was imminent, their shares shook off earlier losses to climb. American Airlines was up 2.1%, Delta Air Lines rose 1.7% and United Airlines climbed 1.6%. The yield on the 10-year Treasury rose to 0.69% from 0.68% late Thursday, after pulling back from an earlier loss. In Europe, stocks also trimmed their losses as the day progressed. Germany’s DAX lost 0.3%, and France’s CAC 40 rose less than 0.1%. The FTSE 100 in London edged up 0.4%. Trading in Asia was thin, with markets in Shanghai and Hong Kong closed. The Nikkei 225 index shed strong early gains to lose 0.7% after the Tokyo Stock Exchange resumed trading following an all-day outage due to a technical failure. Reports that the Japanese government is preparing new stimulus measures to help the economy recover from a prolonged downturn worsened by the coronavirus pandemic provided only a temporary lift. Prices fell further after Trump’s announcement. ___ AP Business Writer Elaine Kurtenbach contributed.

Wall Street’s major stock indexes fell on Friday after President Donald Trump tested positive for the coronavirus, but the losses ended up milder than investors braced for early in the morning. The S&P 500 slumped 1.7% as soon as trading began, only to churn through another turbulent session. By the end of the day, it had trimmed its loss to 1%, down 32.38 points at 3,348.42. She said a wider rescue package for the economy, one that investors have long been agitating for, could also perhaps be on the way. The Dow Jones Industrial Average swung from a loss of 433 points to a gain of 44 points through the day. It ended at 27,682.81, down 134.09 points, or 0.5%. Big technology stocks remained weak, and the Nasdaq composite fell 251.49, or 2.2%, at 11,075.02. It’s a sharp departure from much of the summer, when Big Tech stocks carried the market higher. The tech slump was also the main reason for the S&P 500’s drop. Treasury yields ticked higher, though, and smaller stocks were also stronger than the rest of the market in a sign of optimism. The Russell 2000 index of small-cap stocks gained 8.09, or 0.5%, to 1,539.30. Earlier Friday, markets appeared set for a much uglier day. Stock futures and Treasury yields tumbled after Trump tweeted overnight that he and First Lady Melania Trump had tested positive for COVID-19. Analysts said some of the market’s movements could be explained by investors building up expectations for a Joe Biden victory of the White House, with Election Day a little more than a month away. The announcement said that the visit is precautionary and that Trump will work from the hospital’s presidential suite. The White House also said Trump had been injected with an experimental antibody drug combination for the virus made by Regeneron. The company's shares rose 3% in after-hours trading. Trump’s positive COVID-19 test also highlights the continued spread of the pandemic. The potential for a further ramp up in virus infections as the weather turns colder is raising worries that governments may put some more restrictions on businesses. Also stirring up the market’s movements Friday was the latest report on U.S. jobs growth, which is usually the headline economic data of each month but almost became an afterthought. Employers added fewer jobs last month than economists expected, the third straight month of slower hiring. The slowdown is yet another sign that the recovery is trailing off, said Mike Zigmont, director of trading and research at Harvest Volatility Management. The numbers don't inspire bullishness, but they could be a brighter signal for more help from Congress. “If the conclusion is that the economic data disappoints, Wall Street may say that’s added incentive for the next stimulus deal to eventually go through and more quickly,” he said. All the uncertainty is making an already shaky market even more so. Stocks have been swinging recently amid a raft of open questions for investors: Who will win the election, and what will it mean for the economy? Will the relationship between the world’s two largest economies, the United States and China, keep worsening? Did stocks get too expensive after their 60% surge to record heights through the summer, Big Tech in particular? In recent days, the dominant question has been whether Washington will be able to get past its partisanship to deliver more aid to the economy. Extra benefits for laid-off workers and other support for the economy that Congress approved in March has expired, and investors have been clamoring for more assistance. Layoffs have remained stubbornly high across the country, and parts of the economy have slowed with the support from Congress gone. The House of Representatives passed a Democratic $2.2 trillion package Thursday night, but it has little chance of getting through the Republican Senate. Talks between Democrats and Republicans on a compromise are continuing, but skepticism is high. Airlines have announced the furloughs of tens of thousands of workers, saying they need more support from Washington as demand for travel has vanished. After Pelosi said in the afternoon that some kind of aid was imminent, their shares shook off earlier losses to climb. American Airlines rose 3.3% and United Airlines climbed 2.4%. The yield on the 10-year Treasury rose to 0.69% from 0.68% late Thursday, after pulling back from an earlier loss. In Europe, stocks also trimmed their losses as the day progressed. Trading in Asia was thin, with markets in Shanghai and Hong Kong closed. The Nikkei 225 fell 0.7% after the Tokyo Stock Exchange resumed trading following an all-day outage due to a technical failure. ___ AP Business Writer Elaine Kurtenbach contributed.

urn:contentItem:6104-TNK1-JBCN-4398-00000-00Stocks end bumpy day lower after Trump’s positive virus test;Big technology stocks remained weak2020-10-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:23ZLexisNexisLOCAL NEWSStocks end bumpy day lower after Trump’s positive virus testBig technology stocks remained weak

AP Business Writers

NEW YORK Wall Street’s major stock indexes fell on Friday after President Donald Trump tested positive for the coronavirus, but the losses ended up milder than investors braced for early in the morning.

The S&P 500 slumped 1.7% as soon as trading began, only to churn through another turbulent session. By the end of the day, it had trimmed its loss to 1%, down 32.38 points at 3,348.42. Despite the drop, most of the stocks in the index were higher, and the S&P 500 still managed to close out its first winning week in the last five.

The paring of losses came as optimism rose that Washington may be able to get past its partisanship to deliver more support for the economy. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi told airlines in the afternoon to stop furloughing workers because aid for them is imminent. She said a wider rescue package for the economy, one that investors have long been agitating for, could also perhaps be on the way.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average swung from a loss of 433 points to a gain of 44 points through the day. It ended at 27,682.81, down 134.09 points, or 0.5%.

Big technology stocks remained weak, and the Nasdaq composite fell 251.49, or 2.2%, at 11,075.02. It’s a sharp departure from much of the summer, when Big Tech stocks carried the market higher. The tech slump was also the main reason for the S&P 500’s drop.

Election effect

Analysts said some of the market’s movements could be explained by investors building up expectations for a Joe Biden victory of the White House, with Election Day a little more than a month away. That could mean higher tax rates and tighter regulations on companies, which would limit profits and hurt stock prices, though it could also raise the odds of more stimulus for the economy.

‘‘To say this potentially could be a big deal is an understatement,’’ Rabobank said in a commentary. ‘‘Anyway, everything now takes a backseat to the latest incredible twist in this U.S. election campaign.’’

May 16, 2011 (TradersHuddle.com delivered by Newstex) --
New York, May 16th (TradersHuddle.com) Stocks ended lower, as technology shares were dumped, with investors worrying about continuing woes over the European debt crisis, which could dampen economic recovery and spurring a move away from riskier assets. The Dollar finished lower, but trimmed its losses, with the U.S. Government reaching its legal debt ceiling.



The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 47.38 points, or 0.38%. The S&P 500 index lost 8.30 points, or 0.62%, while the NASDAQ tumbled 46.16 points or 1.63%.

The market started modestly lower, as the Dollar gave up some of its earlier gains. The weak opening followed poor overseas performance in equity markets around the world on renewed European Sovereign debt concerns.

Asian markets finished lower after Japan provided mixed economic data, with machine orders much higher than expected, but consumer confidence much lower. Meanwhile China and Hong Kong also moved to the downside on inflation fears, as some economists predict that China has not seen a CPI peak yet.

European markets finished lower on news the IMF Chief was detained and was waiting arraignment. The CAC underperformed the other major bourses, as Mr. Strauss-Kahn was also rumored to be a leading French Presidential Candidate. There is little indication that the IMF activities will be curtail by his arrest, however jitters on the sovereign crisis increased, as it came very near talks on how to handle the euro zone crisis, as finance ministers are already discussing the next round of help for Greece and Portugals bailout.

The market actually made an attempt to move into positive territory, with the Dow moving into the green for some time midday, as the Dollar weakened and the euro regained some of the lost ground, but an upturn in the greenback and weakness in technology, the biggest sector by weight, dragged the market lower. The tech heavy NASDAQ was the notable underperformer with the index falling to a 1-month low and just above its 50day moving average. PowerShares QQQ Trust (NASDAQ:QQQ), the ETF that seeks to provide investment results that generally correspond to the price and yield performance of the NASDAQ-100 Index, fell 1.73% to $57.40, closing just above its 50day moving average at the $57.26 area.

Among the S&P 500 sectors, healthcare was the only sector finishing in positive territory with a fractional gain, while technology, consumer discretionary, and energy led the declines.

Technology as a group tumbled 1.5% during the session, with big cap tech among the weakest areas in the sector, with investors moving away from riskier assets. Apple (   NASDAQ:AAPL), the maker of iPads and iPhones, dropped 2.11% to $333.30, closing lower than its pre-earnings close on April 19th and giving back more than its gap up after the spectacular quarterly earnings. The stock broke below its 50day moving average last week, spurring downward momentum on the stock, with next level of support at $320.16.

In the Dow Jones Industrial Average, technology also dragged the index lower, with the top three decliners coming from big tech companies. Microsoft (NASDAQ:MSFT) (   NASDAQ:MSFT), the worlds largest software publisher, lost 1.84% to $24.57, closing 3.22% from its calculated support at $25.36. Cisco (   NASDAQ:CSCO), the worlds largest networking equipment maker, fell 1.66% to $16.60, closing below calculated support at $16.64, while Hewlett-Packard (NYSE:HPQ) (   NYSE:HPQ), the worlds largest PC maker, slid 1.51% to $39.80, closing 1.61% above calculated support at $39.16.

Google (   NASDAQ:GOOG), the owner of the largest search engine, was another tech heavy weight out of favor in todays session. Google (NASDAQ:GOOG) fell more than 2% to $518.42, closing below its April low and trading at levels not seen since September. The company today also filed a mixed securities shelf offering for an indeterminate amount.

Consumer discretionary stocks also came under sharp pressure. The sector's 1.4% decline came as Lowe's (NYSE:LOW) Companies (   NYSE:LOW), the second largest home improvement retailer, tumbled 3.57% to $24.84, a three-month low, following a disappointing quarterly report, which featured an earnings miss and disappointing forecast, as the retailer trimmed its full year earnings forecast.

JC Penney (   NYSE:JCP), the department stores operator based in Plano, TX, was tumbled 3.20% to $37.21, after gapping up to a 2-year high at $41 following an upside earnings surpris, but the stock quickly rolled over.

Meanwhile, financials had lagged last week, but in todays session the sector traded with relative strength for much of the session, finishing with a fractional loss. The sector received a boost from card metrics that showed improvements for credit card issuers from March to April.

American ExpressAmerican Express (NYSE:AXP) (   NYSE:AXP) gained 1.17% to $50.07, as the company said that its April U.S. Managed Net write-off rate was 3.5%, an improvement over the 3.7% rate in March, while April loans 30 days past due were 1.7%, showing a slight improvement from the 1.8% rate in March. American Express actually gapped up earlier in the session, with the stock posting a new 52-week high at $50.61.

Capital One (   NYSE:COF) also was a notable outperformer in the sector and in the broad market index, as it gained 2.18% to $53.48 after significant improvements in its April Card Metrics. Capital One (NYSE:COF) said that the April Domestic Annualized Net Charge-Off Rate was 4.97%; April Delinquency rate of 3.41% versus 3.59% in March.

Also on the financial sector, the NYSE Euronext (NYSE:NYX) (   NYSE:NYX) plunged 12.62% to $35.73 on news that the NASDAQ OMX (   NASDAQ:NDAQ) and the IntercontinentalExchange (NYSE:ICE) (   NYSE:ICE) withdraw their proposal to acquire NYSE Euronext, following discussions with the Antitrust Division of the U.S. Department of Justice, which made it clear that the deal will not be successful in securing regulatory approval. Shares of NASDAQ OMX also suffered, falling 2.53% to $26.23, meanwhile InterncontinentalExchange jumped 3.30% to $122.22.

A drop in crude oil prices and gasoline futures pressured the energy sector. Crude oil settled lower by 2.3% to $97.37 per barrel. A selloff in gasoline futures, to the tune of 4.5%, weighed on crude oil throughout the afternoon session. A weaker Dollar had little bearing on crude's movement after it was unable to trade above the flat line.

Valero (   NYSE:VLO), the independent refiner, fell 1.50% to $26.23, closing just above its calculated support at $26.18. Gasoline prices pressured the stock, as traders sold the futures on reports the opening of the Morganza Spillway, was reducing the risk of flooding in the refineries along the Mississippi River in Louisiana.

Weakness in the greenback initially helped precious metals move higher, but both metals pulled back, after trading to their respective highs, despite continued weakness in the greenback. June gold shed 0.2% to close at $1490.60 per ounce, while July silver fell 2.5% to end at $34.11 per ounce. The iShares (NASDAQ:FEFN) (NASDAQ:EUFN) (NASDAQ:EMMT) (NASDAQ:EMFN) (NASDAQ:AXFN) (NYSE:CFT) (NASDAQ:ACWX) (NASDAQ:ACWI) (NYSE:EMB) (NYSE:TOK) (NYSE:SCZ) (NYSE:IGF) (NASDAQ:IFSM) (NASDAQ:IFNA) (NASDAQ:IFGL) (NASDAQ:IFEU) (NASDAQ:IFAS) (NYSE:TLT) (NYSE:SHY) (NYSE:WPS) (NYSE:RXI) (NYSE:MXI) (NYSE:KXI) (NYSE:JXI) (NYSE:EXI) (NYSE:EFA) (NYSE:EFV) (NYSE:EFG) (NYSE:TIP) (NYSE:NYC) (NYSE:DVY) (NYSE:EEM) (NYSE:KLD) (NYSE:IWC) (NYSE:TLH) (NYSE:SHV) (NYSE:IEI) (NYSE:GVI) (NYSE:GBF) (NYSE:CSJ) (NYSE:CIU) (NYSE:ITB) (NYSE:ITA) (NYSE:IHI) (NYSE:IHF) (NYSE:IHE) (NYSE:IEZ) (NYSE:IEO) (NYSE:IAT) (NYSE:IAK) (NYSE:IAI) (NYSE:TUR) (NYSE:THD) (NYSE:EIS) (NYSE:SCJ) (NYSE:ECH) (NYSE:BKF) (NYSE:AIA) (NYSE:IVV) (NYSE:EWJ) (NYSE:EWH) Silver Trust ETF (   NYSE:SLV), the fund that corresponds to the price of silver owned by the Trust less expenses and liabilities, tumbled 4.48% to $32.85, with the trust trimming its year to date gains to 8.85%, while extending its losses for May to 29.9%.

urn:contentItem:3X5H-SHP0-009B-G1N9-00000-00Stocks Explode Across the Board; IPO Market Goes from Hot to Definitely Not; Sky Falls for Iridium1999-08-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:23ZLexisNexisCNN MONEYLINE NEWS HOUR 18:30 pm ETBusinessSHOW99081300V19Stocks Explode Across the Board; IPO Market Goes from Hot to Definitely Not; Sky Falls for IridiumStuart Varney, Rhonda Schaffler, Terry Keenan, Steve Young, Fred Katayama, John King, Allan Dodds Frank, Susan Lisovicz, Peter Viles, Ceci Rodgers, Greg Clarkin, Steve Young

the markets truly snapped out of their summer funk today, with a powerhouse rally that left the Dow up 184 points and the Nasdaq up 88, the biggest one-day point gains this summer. This was supposed to be one of the biggest weeks of the year for the IPO market, with 58 companies slated to go public, but only half made it into the once sizzling IPO market, as rising interest rates and poor quality has had many investors turning their backs on some big name deals. Iridium, the world's most ambitious satellite venture, slid today into bankruptcy, after the international consortium led by Motorola attracted only 15,000 customers, far short of what it had aimed for.

THIS IS A RUSH TRANSCRIPT. THIS COPY MAY NOT BE IN ITS FINAL FORM AND MAY BE UPDATED.

STUART VARNEY, CNN ANCHOR: Tonight on MONEYLINE. Friday the 13th was Wall Street's lucky day: Stocks explode across the board.

A little known combatant enters the bidding war for Reynolds Metals. Why aluminum has the takeover crowd talking.

And less than 24 hours to go before the Iowa straw poll, GOP candidates spend big to win tomorrow's beauty contest: Where they got the cash, a special MONEYLINE report.

ANNOUNCER: This is THE MONEYLINE NEWS HOUR. Reporting tonight from New York, Stuart Varney and Willow Bay.

VARNEY: Good evening, everyone, and welcome to MONEYLINE. Willow continues on vacation tonight.

Well, the markets truly snapped out of their summer funk, for the day at least, with a powerhouse rally from Wall Street all the way to Chicago. Bonds shot up and stocks rocketed higher, a strong finish to an otherwise volatile week. The Dow was up 184 points, the Nasdaq up 88, the biggest one-day point gains this summer. More than a quarter trillion dollars was added in this day alone, and advancing issues beat decliners on the big board by a two-to-one margin.

Rhonda Schaffler looks at what mood -- drove this rally in today's "Street Sweep."

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

RHONDA SCHAFFLER, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): The news could hardly have been better for inflation-wary Wall Street. The Producer Price Index, a measure of wholesale inflation watched closely by the Fed, barely budged last month. Armed with that sign of tame inflation, investors jumped into the market with renewed passion. The ferocious rally spread to nearly every sector, from financials to technology to cyclicals.

American Express, JP Morgan, GE and GM all rose sharply, as the Dow surged 184 points or 1.7 percent, closing a volatile week at 10,973. The buying was even more frenzied on the Nasdaq, which soared nearly 3.5 percent to 2637.

The market's rally was impressive, but some say not a decisive turn of sentiment.

ARTHUR CASHIN, PAINEWEBBER: We got a very good number. Most of the other numbers this week seem to indicate that the economy, if anything, is getting stronger and the labor market might be getting a little tighter. There's a feeling down here that unless the numbers continue to get better, as we are head into the 24th, simple anxiety may have prices waste away again.

SCHAFFLER: The 24th is the date of the next Fed policy making meeting, and for today, at least, many investors worried about it a little less.

But some market watchers say the real economic event for Wall Street and the Fed is still to come.

WALTER MOLANO, BCP SECURITIES: I think that the markets are still a little bit skeptical and I think that the PPI data is nothing really to hang your hat on. I think that investors will be really looking more towards the CPI number next week.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

SCHAFFLER: That key report on consumer prices comes Tuesday and will give the Fed another important piece of information to ponder. With just 11 days now before the next Fed meeting, most say a small rate hike is a given. The markets are hoping that increase would be the last of the year -- Stuart.

VARNEY: Rhonda, is there a consensus estimate on what Tuesday's inflation figures will show?

SCHAFFLER: The consensus estimate for CPI is a gain of about three-tenths of a percent. The core rate, they're looking for gain of two-tenths of a percent. It's a little higher than the PPI, but the CPI index also measures inflation in the services industry. So that is why they're expecting a little bit higher of a number there.

VARNEY: Fair enough. Rhonda Schaffler at the big board, thank you.

Other big board stocks scoring big gains today, AOL, the most active of them all, up 4 1/8. Lucent, Hewlett Packard and IBM all gained smartly as well. The big tech stocks on the Nasdaq surged as well, Intel and Microsoft up around $3 apiece, Amazon.com gained almost 5 3/4, and Yahoo! was up 4 1/2.

Clearly pushing stocks higher today, a powerful rebound in bonds. Bonds rocketed more than a full point in price, and that sent the yield down to 6.09 percent.

Now, let's take a look at what some of MONEYLINE's other reporters are working on for us tonight, beginning with Terry Keenan -- Terry.

TERRY KEENAN, CNN CORRESPONDENT: Thanks, Stuart. This was supposed to be one of the biggest weeks of the year for the IPO market, with 58 companies slated to go public. Only half made it. I'll take a look at why.

STEVE YOUNG, CNN CORRESPONDENT: I'm Steve Young.

The world's most ambitious satellite venture slid today into bankruptcy. I'll explain why and what lies ahead.

FRED KATAYAMA, CNN CORRESPONDENT: I'm Fred Katayama.

Falling profits and litigation problems are creating migraines for investors of American Home Products. Is it time to get out? We'll have the bottom line on AHP -- Stuart.

VARNEY: Thank you, Fred.

Those stories plus a big market bull. Ned Riley says interest rates are going down and stocks are going up. That's later.

All right, stepping outside the world of business now for the MONEYLINE news digest, for the first time since December, Iraq today fired missiles at allied planes in the northern no-fly zone. U.S. jets shot back.

A massive assault tonight by Moscow against Chechen rebels moving into Dagestan. It's the Kremlin's worst security crisis since the Chechnyan war.

And the White House is warning China tonight that military moves against Taiwan would be of grave concern. Beijing is angry about talk of statehood by Taipei.

Back here in the United States, it's a high octane cocktail of partying and party politics, the Iowa straw poll just hours away tonight. Millionaire publisher Steve Forbes is there. So is Elizabeth Dole, she worked the phones in person at her campaign headquarters. Up to 15,000 Iowans are expected to pay the $25 needed to vote in this mock election.

John King reports on the man expected to place first.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: The next president of the United States: George W. Bush!

(APPLAUSE)

JOHN KING, CNN WHITE HOUSE CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): The front-runner knows he has something to prove.

GOV. GEORGE W. BUSH (R-TX), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: It's the first measurable step to see which candidate can convince good, hardworking, decent working folks to show up on one day to start expressing their opinion about the future of this country. KING: Yet it was a relaxed George W. Bush, campaigning across Iowa on the eve of the GOP straw poll, greeting supporters in Cedar Rapids, showing off his Spanish skills at a Mexican restaurant in Davenport.

BUSH: (speaking in Spanish).

KING: Things are clearly going his way these days, and the governor wears the smile of a man both happy and hungry.

BUSH: And I'm running with one thing in mind: I'm running to become the next president of the United States.

KING: His rivals have sharpened the attacks this week, calling the governor untested. His lead, the product of big money and a famous name. So far, he's shrugging it all off.

BUSH: I am going to respond by smiling and saying here's what I believe in.

KING: Front-runners can do that, and this is a candidate determined to protect his lead.

BUSH: We'll see you all Saturday.

KING: Bush keeps saying it won't always be this easy, that there will be plenty of tough days ahead, but for now, things are just fine, and he's clearly enjoying himself.

KING (on camera): The Bush campaign standing by its predictions of a straw poll victory. But the candidate himself seems a bit concerned about the high expectations, telling reporters, "I just want to win. I just want to get the most votes."

John King, CNN, Cedar Rapids, Iowa.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

VARNEY: And later this hour, we'll tell you who is funding the candidates, how much they are giving, and the key question, why?

Also making news tonight, businesses are putting losses from this week's Chicago blackout at $100 million. Commonwealth Edison shut down power in a 30-block downtown area after equipment failures. One hotel went through 4,500 light sticks from its Y2K disaster packs.

And German tennis ace Steffi Graf is calling it quits. She earned 22 Grand Slam singles titles and more than $20 million during her 17-year career. She says she's not having fun anymore.

Still to come, whoever said the aluminum industry was dull? Well, the metal moves continue with a surprise twist today.

And a stellar rally from Wall Street, but there is a dark spot. We'll go "Behind the Numbers" with Terry Keenan on that one.

Stay with MONEYLINE.

ANNOUNCER: From CNN's New York headquarters, this is THE MONEYLINE NEWS HOUR.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

VARNEY: The latest twist now on the bidding war that is really rocking the aluminum business. A little-known Chicago company has made an unsolicited bid for Reynolds Metals. Topping Wednesday's $65 a share offer by Alcoa, Michigan Avenue Partners did not release details on just how big its bid is. Reynolds stock shot up three points. Alcoa lost more than $1.

Greg Clarkin will be along later to tell us more about this story.

Now the IPO market has suddenly gone from hot to definitely not.

More now on that from Terry Keenan. She's joining us for "Behind the Numbers," our look at stories that keep the market moving.

Terry, what's going on this one.

KEENAN: Well, Stuart, it has been a sorry summer for the once sizzling IPO market, as rising interest rates and poor quality has had many investors turning their backs on some big name deals. Many say the dice was cast last week, when 1-800-Flowers.com went public and promptly wilted, falling below its offering price of 21 on the first day of trading. Today, it closed just before 14.

In fact, the summer of '99 has been a terrible time to go public. Of the 84 IPOs since July 1, 42 are now trading below their offering price. Today, five IPOs, including FTD.com, were postponed indefinitely, and half of the 58 companies expected to sell stock this week never made it to market.

Now late today, I spoke with Jonathan Cohen. He's the Internet maven at underwriter Wit Capital, and he says the washout has actually been healthy, a pause that refreshes.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JONATHAN COHEN, WIT CAPITAL: Investors took their foot off the gas for a short period of time, while they were seeing what happened with interest rates, while they were seeing what happened with the broader market, but the level of investor interest in the IPO space, and in Internet IPOs particularly, continues to be very, very strong. There's no question.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

KEENAN: Well, Cohen says today's IPO activity shows there still is a big appetite for quality names. While five deals were postponed, the three that did go public traded higher. One, Quest Software was a standout, up 235 percent on its first day of trading -- Stuart.

VARNEY: Terry, what's the short-term prognostication for the IPO market? Any improvement likely?

KEENAN: Well, short term for the rest of August, it looks like slow-going. But after Labor Day, barring any market correction, most IPO analysts say it'll be off to the races and set the stage for a strong fourth quarter, such as we saw last year, when we had a real comeback in the IPO market.

VARNEY: OK, Terry Keenan, with "Behind the Numbers."

Thanks very much, Terry.

In our "Sectors Report" tonight: casinos. Forgive the pun, but they are indeed hitting the jackpot. The group was up 11 percent today, after a Bank of America analyst talked it up. And a report from the Nevada Gaming Control Board didn't hurt either. It said, gamblers in Las Vegas put $8.5 billion on the table in the last fiscal year, up almost 8 percent from the year before. Another analyst sees even better business this fall and into the season of Y2K celebrations.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BRIAN EGGERT: I do think a number of factors will drive the stocks higher in the second half of the year. We have the opening of the Paris resort in Las Vegas on September 1. We have the De La Hoya and Holyfield fights in September and November. And we also have the millennium New Year, a period during which we think room rates could be up eight percent or nine percent.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

VARNEY: Now take a look at today's winnings for the big names on the strip: Mirage, Mandalay Resort Group and Harris, up more than $1 a piece. MGM Grand gained almost 2 1/4 and Park Place Entertainment, owner of Bally's; that was up 75 cents.

And by the way, that was Brian Eggert on that brief interview we had there, not Jonathan Cohen.

Up next: money and power, a special MONEYLINE report. Who's putting up the big bucks for the presidential hopefuls. And most important, what do they want in return?

We'll answer that in a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

VARNEY: More now on the race for 2000, a case study in money, power and politics. The Iowa straw poll holds a dubious place in American political history. Not one straw poll winner has gone on to take the nomination. Well, that's not stopped GOP hopefuls from spending huge amounts of money leading up to the Iowa contest. And money is one resource the candidates from both parties have in abundance.

In a special MONEYLINE report, Allan Dodds Frank looks at who is giving and why.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

ALLAN DODDS FRANK, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): Presidential primary donors can give up to $1,000 per candidate in what's called "hard money." But even with that restriction and no corporate giving allowed, big-money issues are producing record contributions.

Doing the biggest giving, those with the most to protect or lose.

Topping the givers: lawyers, battling about restrictions on jury awards.

JAMES LANGDON, AKIN, GUMP, STRAUSS, HAUER & FELD: Lawyers tend to be the early money into campaigns. I think there is a division between the plaintiff's bar and other lawyers. And so the tort-reform issue has had an effect, I suspect, where various lawyers line up, with respect to candidates that are there.

DODDS FRANK: Corporate lawyers, who want to reduce jury verdicts, such as the recent $4.2 billion awarded against General Motors, are supporting Republicans. Plaintiff's lawyers are backing Democrats, especially Vice President Al Gore.

MELVIN WEISS: Republicans tend to be associated with corporate America, and they don't like people bringing lawsuits against them or looking into their dirty linen; and the only ones who do that, effectively, are lawyers representing victims of wrongdoing.

DODDS FRANK: Lawyers have given Gore and Bush more than $3 million apiece in hard money, with former New Jersey Senator Bill Bradley collecting another $1.7 million. Lawyers also are responding to pleas from senator John McCain, Elizabeth Dole and former Vice President Dan Quayle.

BONNIE MCELVEEN-HUNTER, NTL. FINANCE CHMN., DOLE CAMPAIGN: When somebody tells me that I've already given to that other candidate, I always remind them that I've never seen a pair of pants with just one pocket. So this is about the primary process.

DODDS FRANK: Wall Street also is heeding that message, spreading money across the board. The financial services industry is the second biggest source of hard money so far, followed by real estate and health care interests.

For bankers, brokers and insurance executives, the big-money issue they face from the next administration is clear. They want a say in how the next president's appointees implement recently passed laws letting financial services companies offer banking, securities and insurance under one roof.

EDWARD YINGLING, AMERICAN BANKERS ASSOCIATION: The real issue out there is that the next president will probably have the opportunity to implement changes that will determine the whole structure of the financial services industry for literally decades to come. DODDS FRANK: On Wall Street, Bush has a slight leads, collecting $1.9 million to $1.7 million for Bradley and $800,000 for Gore.

One Bush supporter, Jack Hennessy, of Credit Suisse First Boston, says financial services executives cover all the bases.

JACK HENNESSY, CHAIRMAN, CSFB, PRIVATE EQUITY: The firms, as opposed to individuals -- the firms generally want to make sure they sort of hedge their bets. In a regulated industry, which could be regulated out of business at any moment, you want to make sure you don't place all your bets, I guess, on one horse. On the other hand, I believe in backing the man I believe in.

DODDS FRANK: Goldman Sachs typifies how Wall Street plays politics. Different executives there have solicited colleagues for $1,000 checks to produce bundles: $78,000 for bush, $70,000 for Bradley and $54,000 for Gore.

No one from Goldman Sachs would appear on camera, but an industry lobbyist explains Wall Street's participation.

MARC LACKRITZ, SECURITIES INDUSTRY ASSOCIATION: From the standpoint of making sure that the next administration is market sensitive, it would make a lot of sense that the securities industry is very active in the campaign and very active in supporting a number of different candidates.

DODDS FRANK: Fund-raisers from both parties concede $1,000 individual contributions are just the first step, buying little more than invitations to keep on giving. The influence comes later, as the presidential primaries give way to the general election. Then, individuals and companies step up donations of so-called "soft money." It can be given in unlimited amounts to national parties, so long as it is used to advertise issues rather than candidates.

Naturally, those invited to meetings for elite donors include $1,000 hard-money contributors, whose companies later give huge sums of soft money.

MEL SEMBLER, NATIONAL FINANCE CHAIRMAN, REPUBLICAN NTNL. COMMITTEE: We ask some of them to get involved who are specialists in certain areas, to help us formulate policies, or talk to each other and try and craft policies that are important for the future.

DODDS FRANK (on camera): The fountains of soft money usually begin gushing after the primary candidates have been sorted out. But this election cycle, Wall Street is taking no chances, already giving $8 million, triple the lawyers' soft-money tally. That generosity just whets the appetites of Republican and Democratic fund-raisers, who expect to raise more than $600 million in soft money during the next 15 months.

Allan Dodds Frank, CNN Financial News, New York.

(END VIDEOTAPE) VARNEY: Now the two front-runners over the next 15 months will rely on a cadre of well-heeled contributors to keep the cash coming. George W. Bush has 115 supporters who have pledged to raise $100,000 each. Among them, Hank Greenberg, from the insurance giant AIG, and Kenneth Lay, the head of Enron. Vice President Gore has 25 contributors who have made the same pledge. They include Viacom CEO, Sumner Redstone.

Up next: the hipper side of Ford? Yes, Detroit oldest auto maker tries something very new.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

VARNEY: Ford has a new car to sell. And the company is turning back to an old technique to sell it. For the first time in decades, Ford is set to run live TV commercials. More than 60 are scheduled to appear, starting next month. Like all live TV -- and here is an understatement -- they'll have an element of risk. But that of course is part of the appeal.

Susan Lisovicz has more.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Ford's mighty Thunderbird, special V-8 engine.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SUSAN LISOVICZ, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): Once upon a time, Ford had cars like the 1956 Thunderbird that connected with the youth culture, which were marketed on live TV. That was decades before competitors like Volkswagen put their pedal to the metal on hip alternative vehicles.

Now the number-two auto maker says the Ford Focus, which features colors such as Sangria Red and CD Silver, will replace the rather stodgy Escort, and its new marketing campaign underscores how it's thinking out of the box.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP, FORD ADVERTISEMENT)

ANNABEL GURWICH: And it's got a snack dispenser. I love that!

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LISOVICZ: Annabel Gurwich, who hosts a popular cable TV show, will be the star of the commercials, which will air live.

JAN KING, FORD DIVISION: We said to ourselves: One, we've got this brand new car, we're going after a new segment, wouldn't it be great if we could create a whole new media? Because we almost have to disrupt this group of consumers from thinking this is a conventional Ford car. LISOVICZ (on camera): Ford's new campaign will debut during next month's "MTV Video Awards." Its radio spots will feature beat poetry, and its Web site will include video shot on hand-held cameras by film students…

(voice-over): … reminiscent of this summer's sleeper hit, "The Blair Witch Project."

Some marketing experts say Ford should be scared.

CLIVE CHAJET, PRESIDENT, CHAJET CONSULTANCY: I don't think that just because the technique of producing the commercial, which in this instance is live, the technique makes the message any more believable since it's being delivered by a professional actress, as opposed to a professional car driver.

LISOVICZ (voice-over): But Ford says the Focus is already a hit with its target audience in Europe, where it won the best small car of the year award. Analysts say the auto maker is spending upwards of $100 million on marketing, in hopes of drawing the same reception in the United States.

Susan Lisovicz, CNN Financial News, New York.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

VARNEY: Coming up in the second half-hour of MONEYLINE: big relief and an even bigger rally.

We'll take apart a strong day for stocks, a dark day though for Iridium, from wiring the planet to chapter 11. And the bottom line at American Home Products. Life after Fen-Phen?

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

VARNEY: Coming up in the second half of the MONEYLINE NEWS HOUR: a bidding war breaks out for Reynolds Metals, faster than you can say "aluminum." An ambitious satellite phone venture ends up bankrupt. We'll tell you what went wrong at Iridium. Also tonight: the bottom line on a drug giant with legal migraines. What's the remedy for American Home Products' ailing stock?

But we begin tonight with our top story: Wall Street's best rally this summer. It was a welcome end to a week that began with big-time selling and ended with robust buying.

Peter Viles has our report.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

PETER VILES, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): That surprisingly tame reading on wholesale inflation brought the bulls out in force and even brought out praise for the man the market fears, Alan Greenspan.

JORDAN KIMMEL, FIRST MONTAUK SECURITIES GROUP: What we see here right now is there really is no inflation, and I think most market participants know this. Greenspan does not want a runaway situation like Japan, where things got built up out of control, so he's done a wonderful job of sort of managing the emotions.

VILES: The Dow gained 184 points for the day, 259 for the week. The Nasdaq gained 88 -- its fourth biggest daily gain ever -- and 87 for the week. Some of day's winners included JP Morgan, Texas Instruments, General Motors, Intel and Microsoft. A strong finish to a week that began with fears that interest rates could march higher well into the fall.

DAVID BEAD, MORGENS WATERFALL VINTIADIS: We haven't been in a rising interest rate environment since '94, and because of that, you always could buy on the dips and stocks would come back. Now it's going to be a little bit different, at least until we get some sign that the Fed is through raising interest rates.

VILES: Those fears peaked Tuesday, when the Dow slipped below 10500, before bouncing back. The Nasdaq fell to 2442, Tuesday 14 percent below its July peak, before it began its comeback.

Still, with the economy strong and the Fed poised to raise rates in 11 days, many market watchers doubt the strength of this rally.

DOUGLASS CLIGOTT: One way to characterize the past couple of days is simply, somewhat of a relief rally. We think the pressure will be back on, though, over the next week or two, and hence, again, we think a resumed downward trend is a pretty good bet.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

VILES: Another sign that this rally, however impressive, was not a real breakout rally: Volume on the Big Board, again, was on the soft side. Just about 700 million shares traded -- Stuart.

VARNEY: Peter, you didn't detect a real mood switch today?

VILES: No, we bounced off the low in what they call this trading range. But we're still within a trading range and people expect that to continue.

VARNEY: Well, you have a nice day anyway. Peter Viles, thank you.

The fuel for today's run up in stocks and bonds: that market- friendly report on producer prices. The news really couldn't have come at a better time for Wall Street, on edge over the Federal Reserve's next move on interest rates.

From Chicago, Ceci Rodgers has more.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

CECI RODGERS, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): Prices paid to makers of computers, automobiles and food all fell in July, offsetting a surge in energy costs. The producer price index rose 2/10 of a percent overall, and registered no change, when you take out the volatile food and energy components.

Bond traders cheered the news, sending prices up more than a full point for the 30-year benchmark Treasury.

WILLIAM DUDLEY, CHIEF ECONOMIST, GOLDMAN SACHS: Now if there is inflation, the Fed is going to be aggressive, and if there is inflation, people are also going to worry that the Fed is just late and their going to lose confidence. So inflation is really the key to the market's psychology right now, and that's why the market reacted so violently today to that good PPI report.

RODGERS: Good news on wholesale inflation helped ease concerns about a series of rate hikes from the Federal Reserve. But most still expect a quarter point rate hike at the Fed's August 24 meeting as an insurance policy against future inflation.

CHARLES REINHARD, ABN AMRO: We've passed the sweetest spot of the inflation cycle, in that we're started to creep up a little bit, and that that trend will continue on into next year. So we see a little bit less growth, a little bit more inflation going forward.

RODGERS (on camera): Where that inflation could show up is in services, a big component of the consumer price index. Traders will be braced for July's read on the CPI, due out next week, and most expect it, too, to be tame.

Ceci Rodgers CNN Financial News, Chicago.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

VARNEY: A closer look now at today's markets. Long-term interest rates fell, for a change, in the bond market. The yield on the Treasury's 30-year issue is down to 6.09 percent. The price jumped more than a full point.

Now on the Big Board, winning issues beat out losers by almost a two-to-one margin. But new lows are still far out-pacing new highs; 43 stocks climbed to 52-week highs, 138 fell to new lows.

This week's Big Board movers come from the financial and tech sectors. JP Morgan, up eight percent. Merrill Lynch soared 15 percent. Intel, eBay and Broadcom rose sharply on the week as well.

One of this week's big winners was Reynolds Metals, now the target of the latest corporate bidding war.

Greg Clarkin is here with the details for us -- Greg.

GREG CLARKIN, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): Well, Stuart, today, a little-known company really making a very big splash in offering a bid for Reynolds Metals. Now the bid was from Michigan Avenue Partners, and it comes just days after a $5.6 billion bid for Reynolds from Alcoa. Michigan Avenue's chairman Michael Lynch wouldn't give a specific value on the bid, but he did say it was an all-cash offer. And Lynch has moved aggressively into aluminum in the last year and half. He told MONEYLINE he believes the industry is, quote, "undervalued and mismanaged." And he also went on to say that he's not looking for a quick turnaround here, but he plans on being a major player in this business for the years ahead.

Now Michigan Avenue's aluminum assets, including a unit it bought from Reynolds just over a year ago, are valued at roughly $1 billion. Reynolds shares today, they soared on the news of a competing bid. The company wouldn't comment beyond saying that their board will be meeting on Sunday to discuss Alcoa's bid. And that stock, if you consider it began the week trading about 56 and change, had a nice run as the subject of a takeover battle.

All in all, really it was a wild week in the aluminum business. Earlier this week, Canada's Alcan linked up in a three-way merger to create the world's largest aluminum company.

Stuart, this is a commodity that really has been under a lot of pressure lately. So we're seeing a lot of combinations, potential combinations, really.

VARNEY: Look, Michigan Avenue Partners has to come up with something like $6 billion dollars, I mean, roughly that kind of money. Where do they get it from?

CLARKIN: Exactly. Lynch wouldn't get specific as to where the money is coming from. He went on to say a number of times, he was confident they could arrange the necessary financing. We should point out, he has Bear Stearns, a couple of big bankers there advising him and helping on this. Calls to those folks late this afternoon weren't returned.

VARNEY: That's a lot of money.

Greg Clarkin, thanks.

Still to come on MONEYLINE: Iridium -- out of orbit, into bankruptcy. But up next: Is it the rebirth of the summer rally? Find out next from BankBoston's Ned Riley.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

VARNEY: Topping tonight's "MONEYLINE Movers," one of the Nasdaq's newest additions: Quest Software, and that is up 33. The networking software maker went public at $14 a share, raising $61 million.

Sabratek -- that fell four, after the medical device maker said its quarterly results will be delayed, pending completion of an audit. Earlier this month, the company warned it would miss analysts' estimates.

Now Stewart Enterprises fell nearly four. Merrill Lynch downgraded that stock after the funeral company warned that its quarterly profits will come in lower than a year ago.

Minimed, up 5 1/2, after Standard & Poor's said it was adding the maker of insulin pumps to the S&P 400 mid-cap index.

Now the dynamic rebound on Wall Street is the subject of our "MONEYLINE Focus." The Dow and Nasdaq are both down from last month's all-time highs, true, still, their year-to-year gains are impressive. The Dow is up more than 19 percent, more than it gained for all of last year. The Nasdaq is up 20 percent. Today's gains brought that index out of the correction territory.

Joining me now from Seattle to wrap up a wild week on Wall Street, is Ned Riley of BankBoston.

Ned, it's good to have you with us.

NED RILEY, CIO, BANKBOSTON: It's good to be here, Stuart.

VARNEY: OK, it's Friday, it's high summer, big rally in stocks across the board -- are you a happy man this evening, Ned?

RILEY: It's Friday the 13th, Stuart, and look at the luck it brought us today, so I am a happy man today.

Actually I'm a little surprised though, because even though the PPI report -- that you mentioned before -- was quite benign, it seemed to be in line but not necessarily unusually stimulative to the market. I was surprised, a little surprised, at the reaction, but I was happy. We're looking for lower rates and it was nice to see the rally in the bond market today.

VARNEY: OK, you're looking for low rates. That's interesting. Do you think that 6.25 percent on the 30-year Treasury, is that the high for this current cycle? And if it is, what's the low?

RILEY: Well, I'd like to think it's the high. We may challenge 650, but I'd think at 6.25, if you look at it from the perspective of the real return to investors at a 6.50, that would give investors about a 400 to 450 basis points real return. I think that's extremely handsome for most investors.

You asked me the low, I think we can really get below five percent again. Remember, it was only last fall that this long bond yielded a 4.72 percent during that financial crisis. I think we can get back there again, but it probably is going to take a little bit longer and it should not occur around a financial crisis but a slower growth period in the United States.

VARNEY: Let me get this straight, you are forecasting that within this cycle, this interest rate cycle, we could get down below five percent. You didn't misspeak, below five percent is coming?

RILEY: Below five percent. And I can give you the rationale. First of all, if we look at the bond investors today, the majority of them are bearish. I mean, 90 percent of those surveyed still feel that this economy's incredibly strong, and, therefore, interest rates should be rising. I love that kind of the mood and atmosphere, because if you look back to last year's fall, when the rate structure was at 4.72 percent, 90 percent of those measured by Market Vain were actually bullish about lower rates and bearish about the economy.

So the psychology is just where it should be for a rally.

VARNEY: If you're talking about below five percent yield on the long bond, you've got to be talking a significant rally for stocks, surely.

RILEY: It will provide that support for stocks. The only fly in the ointment here right now, Stuart, would be that as this economy starts to slow down, and particularly around year end and Y2K issues, I think what we'll see is selective industries falling by the wayside and I think coming to the fore are going to be industries like technology, health care, the financials will do well because these industries and companies prosper in a lower interest rate environment.

VARNEY: Can you give me two names of stocks, first of all in technology?

RILEY: In technology, I love Microsoft. It's a little rich -- I should say that. I'm out here in Seattle right now. I do think that the Intels, I think the IBMs, I even like EMC. EMC looks good right now, even though, obviously, they're trying to expand their businesses into the middle of the market as opposed to the high end.

But those companies, I think, should be owned in every portfolio for a long period of time.

VARNEY: Can you give me two stocks in the health care business you like?

RILEY: I could probably give you four or five that I like, and I would always recommend to investors to have at least that many. I love Merck right now. The company's selling at about 24 price/earnings ratio, it's growing at 12 to 14 percent a year. It's clearly being pummeled by this pending, you know, tax legislation. This bill attached, it would make -- depress drug stock prices. I like Baxter Labs, I like Ilon (ph), which is an Irish drug company that has been back and forth, a very volatile stock this year…

VARNEY: Let me jump in for a second, Ned, I'm sorry to do that to you, but we've got…

RILEY: No problem.

VARNEY: … five seconds left. Give me five seconds on Internet stocks.

RILEY: The Internut? Oh, excuse me, the Internet. Is that what you asked me, Stu?

VARNEY: I did.

RILEY: I think they're still very rich, very highly priced, and unfortunately I don't think people understand that these companies should be companies that are business assets, growing profits and growing dividends. VARNEY: Your time is up but it was a good time. Thank you very much. Ned Riley, BankBoston, thank you, sir.

RILEY: My pleasure, Stu.

VARNEY: Next on MONEYLINE, why the sky is falling at Iridium.

And as we go to break, check out this: This chart tells you how each Dow stock did in terms of price, all 30 of them. But also, just try scanning it for color and you get a sense of the overall market. Red down, green up. Now, cast your eyes over it, and that, ladies and gentlemen, is what we call a rally.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

VARNEY: Oh, a dark day, indeed, for Iridium. The stock plunged another 30 percent today after Iridium filed for bankruptcy.

Steve Young has more on the company that is struggling to provide a leading-edge technology in satellite communications.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

YOUNG (voice-over): The sky fell today for Iridium. The first of four multi-satellite systems to offer service failed to attract customers and it slid into bankruptcy. The international consortium led by Motorola has only 15,000 customers, far short of what it had aimed for.

Iridium said in a statement it's banks, bond holders and partners backed the decision to restructure under chapter 11 protection in a Delaware court. It said it will conduct business as usual and expects to survivor.

ARMAND MUSEY, BANK OF AMERICA SECURITIES: All sides believe there's a viable business model in there somewhere. I think the odds are that yes, they will come out on the other side. It's a question of how long is it going to take, and the longer it takes the less the whole thing's worth.

YOUNG: Motorola says it's confident the restructuring can be completed within a month. A competitor, Globalstar, whose biggest investor is Loral Aerospace, is scheduled to be operating no later than November. Another company, Ico, has had trouble getting funded and could fold within a month. That could leave Globalstar as the last standing viable company.

ROBERT KAIMOWITZ, ING BARINGS: We've always thought that Globalstar had the best cost structure, the best management, the best strategic plan and partners and the best marketing plan, and they had the best chance to succeed.

YOUNG: Five billion dollars been sunk into Iridium, the most ambitious satellite venture ever attempted. It had manufacturing problems and wasn't able to distribute phones to meet the early demand. Then additional demand was choked off by the high cost of the phones, as much as $3,000, and the high service charge, as much as $6 per minute.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

YOUNG: Iridium's CEO said in a conference call the challenge of dealing with his creditors reminds him of a water hole. "First the zebras come down to drink," he said, "think they spot a crocodile and scatter. Then the wildebeests arrive, drink and scatter, too." It isn't easy appeasing all those with a stake in Iridium -- Stuart.

VARNEY: That's a great quote. You had one of these phones, didn't you, Steve?

YOUNG: Well, they lent me one. I had it for about a week. It worked pretty good, not inside rooms, but as they said on tops of buildings and in some streets.

VARNEY: Fair enough. Steve Young, thanks.

Still to come on MONEYLINE, the incredible shrinking world of Disney.

That's next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

VARNEY: In our "Corporate Briefs" tonight, a high-tech acquisition for Lucent Technologies. The leading telecommunications equipment maker will get Xedia Corporation for nearly $250 million. Xedia makes equipment that lets employees connect to private corporate networks from the Internet.

Dutch financial group ING is offering $2.2 billion for outstanding shares in Germany's BHF bank. ING already owns 42 percent of BHF.

And the Walt Disney Company had no comment on reports that it's selling Fairchild Publications. It boasts the fashion bible, W, Women's Wear Daily and Jane magazine. Word is Conde Nast and Hearst have been bidding.

Up next, "Ahead of the Curve," some of what you need to know tonight tonight before Monday's markets open.

Plus, "The Bottom Line" at American Home Products: fen-phen and beyond.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

VARNEY: Here's what -- some of what could move the markets next week. The last of the Dow companies, Hewlett-Packard, reports its earnings on Monday, as does a Nasdaq bellwether, Dell Computer, also, retailers including JC Penney, Dayton Hudson, Home Depot and the Limited.

Expect part two of the inflation reading within the Consumer Price Index on Tuesday. The latest reports on the business at the nation's factories and the trade deficit for June, all out next week.

VARNEY: Finally this evening, "The Bottom Line," our regular Friday feature inside one company at a crossroads. Tonight, American Home Products: Profit trouble and the legal uproar over the diet drug fen-phen has battered the company's stock.

Fred Katayama looks at whether the market's punishment is justified.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

KATAYAMA (voice-over): Investors of American Home Products can probably use some Advil. In June, the company warned quarterly profits will fall about 17 percent shy of analysts' expectations on shrinking revenues.

Last Friday, a Texas jury awarded more than $23 million to a woman who claimed its diet drug, pondimin damaged her heart valve. Pondimin is the "fen" half of the diet drug combination fen-phen.

And on Wednesday in New Jersey the company faced opening arguments in the first class-action lawsuit over that drug.

The stock could use an antidepressant. It has skidded from roughly 40 percent since peaking in April.

JEFF CHAFFKIN, PAINEWEBBER: People have really forgotten about the liability risk. It happened a year-and-a-half ago, it's been very quiet, and now it just came back to the forefront. And so, you know, I think, people may reassess it.

KATAYAMA: It's a humbling time for a proud, 73-year-old giant with a knack for acquiring companies and turning little-known products into household brands, like the estrogen tablets, premarin, the most widely-prescribed drug in the U.S., and the cough syrup Robitussin.

Pharmaceuticals make up two-thirds of sales, a fifth comes from farm products. Consumer health care makes up the rest.

But growth has slowed for drugs like premarin and oral contraceptives. American Home's key pharmaceutical brands grew just one percent in June, lowest among the major drugmakers. Worse, sales of agricultural products shrank 29 percent in the second quarter. Low grain prices are forcing farmers to trim their use of pesticides and herbicides. Wall Street is sharply divided over American Home's prospects.

Jeffrey Chaffkin of Painewebber says litigation will pressure the stock. Four thousand cases are pending.

CHAFFKIN: People have seen what's happened in other cases, whether the breast implant case or the tobacco situation, and it's very hard to quantify. And it's the uncertainty right now that I think's really the biggest problem.

KATAYAMA: But analyst David Saks rates AHP a bargain. He says investors will eventually realize that even with the litigation, the core business is healthy.

DAVID SAKS, GRUNTAL & CO.: Bristol Myers' breast implant was around a long time. The stock -- I only use it as an example, when they produce good earnings and a good story on new products. Today, as we know, Bristol's near its high. And they still haven't yet completed the Bristol Myers' breast implant issue. There's only a certain amount of worry that you can have and you go to the basic sound business.

KATAYAMA: Unlike tobacco companies, American Home has yanked its products off the shelves, limiting the number of possible claims. The company told MONEYLINE in a statement, "The ultimate liability of the company will not have a material adverse effect on the company's financial position but could be material to the results of operations in any one accounting period."

The law aside, American Home boasts the fattest drug pipeline in its history. Among those expected to be approved soon, the sedative Sonata; a drug to prevent rejection of transplanted kidneys, Rapamune; and a pneumococcal vaccine to prevent bacterial infections in kids.

Wall Street is counting on those drugs to help boost earnings roughly 14 percent next year.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

KATAYAMA: Both bulls and bears agree on one point: To boost its stock price, American Home must dump its agricultural business, by spinning it off, selling it or creating a joint venture with another company. American Home would only say it's exploring "strategic alternatives" -- Stuart.

VARNEY: Fred, do you think that means it's preparing itself for sale?

KATAYAMA: That's what analysts on Wall Street say, that if it gets rid of its agricultural business, it will become a much more attractive merger candidate. The company did try to merge with two other companies last year, Monsanto and Smithkline Beecham. Those talks were called off.

VARNEY: All right, what's its current stock price look like compared to the rest of that group?

KATAYAMA: Well, Stuart, right now it's trading at a discount. The drug industry on average is trading 27 times year 2000 earnings, whereas this company, AHP, is only trading at 21 times. That's about more than a 20 percent discount.

VARNEY: Now that is a discount. Fred Katayama, thank you.

That is MONEYLINE for this Friday. I'm Stuart Varney, Willow Bay will be back on Monday. Enjoy that weekend please.

"CROSSFIRE"'s next.

urn:contentItem:5Y6D-YF31-JC8S-D34V-00000-00Stocks extend gains as investors focus on latest earnings2020-02-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:23ZLexisNexisAPg. A005Stocks extend gains as investors focus on latest earningsAlex Veiga

1) Meric Greenbaum, center, works with traders at his post on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange. PHOTO: Richard Drew/Associated Press

Major U.S. stock indexes closed mostly higher Tuesday, led by health care companies, retailers and banks. The modest gains nudged the S&P 500 and Nasdaq to all-time highs for the second straight day. The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished essentially flat. Investors weighed another batch of mostly solid company earnings reports.

Sprint soared after a federal judge cleared a major obstacle to the company being acquired by T-Mobile. Microsoft and Facebook slumped after federal regulators announced they've ramped up an antitrust probe into the two companies as well as Amazon, Apple and Google parent Alphabet. Cruise operators, hotels and other companies that focus on travel made solid gains, the latest sign that traders are feeling less worried about the economic impact from the virus outbreak that began in China. "Stocks are collectively saying, 'hey, maybe we can work past some of the noise with the virus; maybe the fallout won't be as big as we thought," said Willie Delwiche, investment strategist at Baird. "And the U.S. economy, so far at least, looks like it's weathering it pretty well." The S&P 500 index rose 5.66 points, or 0.2%, to 3,357.75. The Dow Jones Industrial Average slipped 0.48 points, or less than 0.1%, to 29,276.34. It had been up 0.5%. The Nasdaq composite gained 10.55 points, or 0.1%, to 9,638.94. The Russell 2000 index of smaller company stocks picked up 9.85 points, or 0.6%, to 1,677.51. Markets in Europe and Asia rose. Bond prices fell, sending bond yields higher. The 10-year Treasury yield rose to 1.60% from 1.54% late Monday. After a downbeat January, U.S. stocks have been mostly notching gains this month as traders brush off fears about the virus outbreak and its impact on businesses and the global economy. Beijing has promised to take measures to soften the blow to China's economy and investors are hopeful that other governments will do the same if necessary. China remained mostly closed for business Tuesday as the daily death toll from a new virus topped 100 for the first time, pushing the total deaths above 1,000. The outbreak has infected more than 43,000 people globally, though most of the cases and deaths are in China. Travel-related stocks, which have been hammered by traders in recent weeks, notched gains Tuesday. Hilton Worldwide rose 1.4%, Carnival climbed 2.8% and American Airlines gained 3.6%. Wall Street got some encouragement Tuesday from Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell. In his semiannual monetary report to Congress, Powell said it was too early to assess the threat the virus poses to the U.S. economy, but he noted that the economy "is in a very good place" with strong job creation and moderate growth. Traders welcomed a federal judge's decision to reject claims by a group of states arguing T-Mobile's proposed $26.5 billion buyout of rival Sprint would mean less competition and higher phone bills. Shares in Sprint surged 77.5%, while T-Mobile jumped 11.8%. Meanwhile, the Federal Trade Commission said Tuesday it has ordered Facebook, Amazon, Apple, Microsoft and Google's parent Alphabet to turn over detailed information on their acquisitions going back to 2010 as part of an investigation into the five giant tech companies' market dominance. The FTC, the Justice Department and a House committee have been investigating the conduct of big tech companies and whether they aggressively bought potential rivals to suppress competition. Some critics have pointed to Facebook's acquisition of Instagram and WhatsApp, for example, as deals that should be questioned. Microsoft slid 2.3%, Facebook fell 2.8% and Apple dropped 0.6%. Amazon rose 0.8%, while Alphabet inched up 0.1%. Investors also assessed the latest batch of company earnings reports Tuesday. AutoNation climbed 6.3% after the car dealership's latest quarterly results topped Wall Street's forecasts, aided by higher demand for used cars. Cloud-based phone system provider RingCentral also posted surprisingly good earnings and issued a solid forecast. The stock rose 6.8%. Strong fourth-quarter results also gave shares in Brighthouse Financial a boost. Shares in the annuity and life insurance company, which announced a $500 million share buyback program, jumped 10.7%. Results from other companies failed to impress traders. Goodyear Tire & Rubber slumped 12.4% after the tire maker's fourth-quarter earnings and revenue fell short of Wall Street forecasts. Under Armour plunged 18.9% after the athletic gear company said it may need to restructure this year, which may involve scuttling the opening of its New York City flagship store. The company also gave investors a weak profit forecast for the year and said the virus outbreak in China will drag first-quarter sales down by $50 million to $60 million. Benchmark crude oil rose 37 cents to settle at $49.94 a barrel. Brent crude oil, the international standard, gained 74 cents to close at $54.01 a barrel. Wholesale gasoline fell 1 cent to $1.51 per gallon. Heating oil climbed 2 cents to $1.63 per gallon. Natural gas rose 2 cents to $1.79 per 1,000 cubic feet.

urn:contentItem:5FJ2-RB61-F00X-J01R-00000-00Stocks Fall as Wall Street Braces For Federal Reserve's Meeting2015-03-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:23ZLexisNexisStocks Fall as Wall Street Braces For Federal Reserve's MeetingKeris Alison Lahiff

The Federal Reserve's press conference is still a day away but the potential outcome created tremors on Wall Street on Tuesday.

NEW YORK ( TheStreet ) -- The conclusion of the Federal Reserve's March meeting is still a day away but the potential outcome caused tremors on Wall Street during Tuesday's session. Investors have been fretting this past week over whether Fed Chair Janet Yellen will signal a rate hike sooner rather than later. 

The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 recovered from the worst of the day, pulling back from losses of around 1% earlier but still closed in the red. The Dow slid 0.72% and the S&P 500 fell 0.34%. 

Prepare for some bumpiness on Wednesday too, says one analyst. 

"On Fed statement day, you typically get a whipsaw reaction as people try to digest the news," said Eric Mintz, portfolio manager at Eagle Asset Management, in a call. "I wouldn't be surprised if there was an initial knee-jerk move down."

In particular, economists will be keen to see whether the keyword "patient" might be removed from the statement, a move that would set into action a possible rate hike as soon as June.

"Even though the removal of 'patient' will be interpreted as a hawkish signal that a June rate hike remains on the table, Fed Chair Yellen could conceivably use the subsequent press conference to take some of the sting out of the market's reaction by reinforcing the data-dependency of the Fed's decision with regard to the timing and pace of liftoff," said TD Securities' head of U.S. rates and economic research Eric Green.

Crude oil recovered above $43 a barrel by the afternoon session. West Texas Intermediate crude was down 1.7% to $43.12 a barrel, though it bounced back from losses of more than 1% earlier.

The commodity had been under pressure after Iran's oil minister said on Monday that the country would increase production by 1 million barrels a day if international sanctions are lifted. U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry and Iranian Foreign Minister Mohammed Javad Zarif are reportedly close to sealing a nuclear deal that could involve lifting sanctions.

Major oilers including PetroChina
, Royal Dutch Shell
, BP
and Total
were higher, though the Energy Select Sector SPDR ETF remained 0.36% lower.

The Nasdaq added 0.13%, pulled higher by Apple
and Facebook
. Apple was up 1.8% on reports the tech giant could announce a Web TV offering as early as June, according to The Wall Street Journal. Facebook added nearly 2% after Brean Capital initiated coverage with a 'buy' rating and $96 price target. The firm said the company can harness growth opportunities in emerging markets.


Alibaba
was 0.54% higher after Stifel Nicolaus upgraded shares to "buy" from "hold" noting regulatory risk surrounding counterfeit items had subsided.

Retail fund Macerich
rejected a $16 billion bid from shopping-mall real estate company Simon Property
and adopted a poison pull to go into effect should anyone acquire more than a 10% stake. Macerich dropped 3.5% and Simon Property was down 0.5%.

Chipmaker Himax
plummeted nearly 10% after Bank of America analysts downgraded the stock to "underperform" from "buy" and slashed price targets to $7. The firm said there has been little news of new products requiring microdisplays from big tech companies that would prove beneficial to Himax.


DSW
surged 4% after reporting a 7% increase in comparable-store sales over its fourth quarter. The footwear retailer reported earnings of 35 cents a share, 7 cents better than forecast, while sales spiked nearly 12%. Burlington Stores
popped 2.1% after beating analysts' estimates on its top- and bottom-line and after posting a nearly 7% increase in comparable-store sales during the fourth quarter.


Plug Power
shares tumbled 4.9% after the fuel cell maker reported a wider-than-expected loss in the fourth quarter. The alternative energy company reported a net loss of 8 cents a share, double forecasts.


Oracle
and Adobe
 will report earnings after the closing bell on Tuesday. Oracle is expected to report quarterly earnings of 68 cents a share, while Adobe should post 39 cents a share.
