Oct 08, 2012 (The Business Insider:http://www.businessinsider.com/ Delivered by Newstex)
Banks were closed for Columbus Day. And there were no economic reports. But there were a couple of headlines worth noting.


First the scoreboard:
Dow: 13,583, -26.5, -0.1 percent SP 500: 1,455, -5.0, -0.3 percent NASDAQ: 3,112, -23.2, -0.7 percent
And now the top stories:
Last night, a CBS 60 Minutes story on two of China's largest tech companies brought attention to a new report filed by the House Intelligence Committee. "China has the means, opportunity, and motive to use telecommunications companies for malicious purposes," the report says. The report specifically urges U.S. regulators to block any dealings with China's Huawei Technologies and ZTE Corp.Huawei fired back saying that the report was based on rumors. SEE ALSO: 15 States That Would Get Slammed In A Trade War With China > California's gas price crisis continues to get worse with prices establishing new all-time highs. The pain at the pump is pinching California's poorest the most. But with the price increases decelerating, analysts think that the worst may be over. Here's California's Gas Price Nightmare In Two Maps > Two big tech names moved today. Netflixsurged 11 percent after Morgan Stanley's Scott Devitt upgraded the stock. "Our upgrade is based on our view that Amazon.com is not a direct threat to Netflix's US business," wrote Devitt who has an $85 price target on the stock. Apple was a notable loser today falling 2 percent and taking the Nasdaq and SP 500 down with it. The stock sold off on no obvious bad news. However, chart-watchers like Bespoke Investment Group noted that the stock fell below its 50-day moving average, which could mean the stock has further to fall. Things should get much more interesting tomorrow afternoon as aluminum giant Alcoa kicks off Q3 earnings season. Analysts expect it to be the ugliest earnings season since the crisis with profit growth turning negative. SEE ALSO: Brian Belski Wants All Of His Clients To See These 13 Charts > Don't Miss: 10 Countries Sitting On Gigantic Piles Of Gold >

Please follow Money Game on Twitter and Facebook.

May 21, 2011 (TradersHuddle.com delivered by Newstex) --
Weston, May 21st (Tradershuddle.com) Stocks ended lower for the week on global uncertainty and weak economic data in the U.S., amid excitement from the LinkedIn IPO. The euro moved lower amid doubts regarding the debt restructuring in Greece and on signs the German economy was slowing, along with uncertainty after the IMF Chief resigned following sexual assault charges.



For the week, the blue chip index fell 0.66%, the S&P 500 Index lost 0.34% and the NASDAQ dropped 0.89%.

At the start of the week, stocks ended lower, as technology shares were dumped, with investors worrying about continuing woes over the European debt crisis. The Dollar finished lower, but trimmed its losses, with the U.S. Government reaching its legal debt ceiling.

Asian markets finished lower after Japan provided mixed economic data, with machine orders much higher than expected, but consumer confidence much lower. Meanwhile China and Hong Kong also moved to the downside on inflation fears.

European markets finished lower on news the IMF Chief was detained in New York on sexual assault charges. The CAC underperformed the other major bourses, as Mr. Strauss-Kahn, who was also rumored to be a leading French Presidential Candidate. The news spurred jitters on the sovereign debt situation, as it came very near talks on how to handle the euro zone crisis, as finance ministers are already discussing the next round of help for Greece and Portugals bailout.

An upturn in the greenback and weakness in technology, the biggest sector by weight, dragged the market lower. The tech heavy NASDAQ was the notable underperformer with the index falling to a 1-month low and just above its 50day moving average. PowerShares QQQ Trust (NASDAQ:QQQ), the ETF that seeks to provide investment results that correspond to the price and yield performance of the NASDAQ-100 Index, fell 1.73% to $57.40, closing just above its 50day moving average at the $57.26 area.

Among the S&P 500 sectors, healthcare was the only sector finishing in positive territory with a fractional gain, while technology, consumer discretionary, and energy led the declines.

Technology as a group tumbled 1.5% during the session, with big cap tech among the weakest areas in the sector, with investors moving away from riskier assets. Apple (   NASDAQ:AAPL), the maker of iPads and iPhones, dropped 2.11% to $333.30, closing lower than its pre-earnings close on April 19th and giving back more than its gap up after the spectacular quarterly earnings. The stock broke below its 50day moving average last week, spurring downward momentum on the stock, with next level of support at $320.16.

In the Dow Jones Industrial Average, technology also dragged the index lower, with the top three decliners coming from big tech companies. Microsoft (NASDAQ:MSFT) (   NASDAQ:MSFT), the worlds largest software publisher, lost 1.84% to $24.57, closing 3.22% from its calculated support at $25.36. Cisco (   NASDAQ:CSCO), the worlds largest networking equipment maker, fell 1.66% to $16.60, closing below calculated support at $16.64, while Hewlett-Packard (   NYSE:HPQ), the worlds largest PC maker, slid 1.51% to $39.80, closing 1.61% above calculated support at $39.16.

Consumer discretionary stocks also came under sharp pressure. The sector's 1.4% decline came as Lowe's (NYSE:LOW) Companies (   NYSE:LOW), the second largest home improvement retailer, tumbled 3.57% to $24.84, a three-month low, following a disappointing quarterly report, which featured an earnings miss and disappointing forecast, as the retailer trimmed its full year earnings forecast.

JC Penney (   NYSE:JCP), the department stores operator based in Plano, TX, tumbled 3.20% to $37.21, after gapping up to a 2-year high at $41 following an upside earnings surprise, but the stock quickly rolled over.

Meanwhile, financials, which had lagged last week, traded with relative strength for much of the session, finishing with a fractional loss. The sector received a boost from card metrics that showed improvements for credit card issuers from March to April.

American Express (   NYSE:AXP) gained 1.17% to $50.07, as the company said that its April U.S. Managed Net write-off and delinquency rates improved in April. American Express (NYSE:AXP) actually gapped up earlier in the session, with the stock posting a new 52-week high at $50.61Capital One (   NYSE:COF) also was a notable outperformer in the sector and in the broad market index, as it gained 2.18% to $53.48 after significant improvements in its April Card Metrics.

Also on the financial sector, the NYSE Euronext (NYSE:NYX) (   NYSE:NYX) plunged 12.62% to $35.73 on news that the NASDAQ OMX (   NASDAQ:NDAQ) and the IntercontinentalExchange (NYSE:ICE) (   NYSE:ICE) withdraw their proposal to acquire NYSE Euronext, following discussions with the Antitrust Division of the U.S. Department of Justice, which made it clear that the deal will not be successful in securing regulatory approval. Shares of NASDAQ OMX also suffered, falling 2.53% to $26.23, meanwhile InterncontinentalExchange jumped 3.30% to $122.22.

A drop in crude oil prices and gasoline futures pressured the energy sector. Crude oil settled lower by 2.3% to $97.37 per barrel. A selloff in gasoline futures, to the tune of 4.5%, weighed on crude oil throughout the afternoon session. A weaker Dollar had little bearing on crude's movement after it was unable to trade above the flat line.

Valero (   NYSE:VLO), the independent refiner, fell 1.50% to $26.23, closing just above its calculated support at $26.18. Gasoline prices pressured the stock, as traders sold the futures on reports the opening of the Morganza Spillway, was reducing the risk of flooding in the refineries along the Mississippi River in Louisiana.

Weakness in the greenback initially helped precious metals move higher, but both metals pulled back, after trading to their respective highs, despite continued weakness in the greenback. June gold shed 0.2% to close at $1490.60 per ounce, while July silver fell 2.5% to end at $34.11 per ounce. The iShares (NASDAQ:FEFN) (NASDAQ:EUFN) (NASDAQ:EMMT) (NASDAQ:EMFN) (NASDAQ:AXFN) (NYSE:CFT) (NASDAQ:ACWX) (NASDAQ:ACWI) (NYSE:EMB) (NYSE:TOK) (NYSE:SCZ) (NYSE:IGF) (NASDAQ:IFSM) (NASDAQ:IFNA) (NASDAQ:IFGL) (NASDAQ:IFEU) (NASDAQ:IFAS) (NYSE:TLT) (NYSE:SHY) (NYSE:WPS) (NYSE:RXI) (NYSE:MXI) (NYSE:KXI) (NYSE:JXI) (NYSE:EXI) (NYSE:EFA) (NYSE:EFV) (NYSE:EFG) (NYSE:TIP) (NYSE:NYC) (NYSE:DVY) (NYSE:EEM) (NYSE:KLD) (NYSE:IWC) (NYSE:TLH) (NYSE:SHV) (NYSE:IEI) (NYSE:GVI) (NYSE:GBF) (NYSE:CSJ) (NYSE:CIU) (NYSE:ITB) (NYSE:ITA) (NYSE:IHI) (NYSE:IHF) (NYSE:IHE) (NYSE:IEZ) (NYSE:IEO) (NYSE:IAT) (NYSE:IAK) (NYSE:IAI) (NYSE:TUR) (NYSE:THD) (NYSE:EIS) (NYSE:SCJ) (NYSE:ECH) (NYSE:BKF) (NYSE:AIA) (NYSE:IVV) (NYSE:EWZ) (NYSE:EWJ) (NYSE:EWH) Silver Trust ETF (   NYSE:SLV), the fund that corresponds to the price of silver owned by the Trust less expenses and liabilities, tumbled 4.48% to $32.85, with the trust trimming its year to date gains to 8.85%, while extending its losses for May to 29.9%.

On Tuesday, the market started in negative territory after giving up an early bid following disappointing guidance from Hewlett-Packard and weaker than expected housing starts and building permits.

In addition to the housing starts, bears received ammunition with a report that showed Industrial output in the U.S. was unchanged in April, as factory production fell 0.4%, the first drop in 10 months and adding to the evidence that the economic recovery is struggling and will likely slowdown.

European markets fell, with shares hitting a 4-week closing low, as technology shares moved lower pressured by the weak outlook from tech giant Hewlett-Packard.

But the market was able to move off its lows of the day, thanks to a downturn by the Dollar and relative strength amid the financial sector. Stocks were snared at the neutral line, though. Selling pressure took stocks down markedly at midday.

Tech stocks were hit early on with some of the hardest selling interest. The sector tumbled to a loss of more than 1%, as shares of Hewlett-Packard (   NYSE:HPQ), the tech giant, plunged to a new 52-week low at $36.91 following downside guidance for the current quarter and for the full year, which overshadowed the better than expected results. HP fell 7.26% to $36.91, closing below calculated support at $39.16 and posting the biggest decline in the Dow Jones Industrial Average.

However the tech sector cut its loss significantly, finishing the session with only a 0.2% loss, making industrials and materials the biggest drags in the broad market, Apple (   NASDAQ:AAPL) was a stock that helped the tech sector cut into its losses, as shares moved to positive territory after falling to a low of $330.73 earlier in the session, following reports that FBR Capital had trimmed its second quarter iPhone production estimates downward primarily due to lower than expected CDMA iPhones sales through Verizon (NYSE:VZ) , and due to some spotty iPhone component supply in early May. Apple finished higher by 0.85% to $336.14, receiving a late bid late in the session.

Economic sensitive stocks, like materials and industrials were shun by investors after the latest data from industrial production was disappointing, with the industrial components in the blue chip index posting some of the biggest percentage losses. Caterpillar (   NYSE:CAT), the worlds largest earthmoving equipment maker, tumbled 3.78% to $102.08, posting the second biggest percentage decline in the index. Boeing (NYSE:BA) (   NYSE:BA), the worlds second largest commercial aircraft maker and biggest defense company, also suffered, falling 1.4% to $76.68, closing below its 20day moving average, as investors moved away from the sector.

Also weighing in the blue chip index was Wal-Mart (NYSE:WMT) (   NYSE:WMT). The worlds biggest retailer fell 0.93% to $55.54 following better than expected quarterly results, as investors worried about traffic slowdown at its domestic stores, likely impacted by higher gas prices. Wal-Mart said it earned $0.98 per share, $0.03 better than consensus, on revenues that climbed 4.4% year over year to $104.19 billion.

But Home Depot (NYSE:HD) (   NYSE:HD), the largest home improvement retailer, provided support to the index, and was one of its biggest percentage gainer, climbing 1.14% to $37.40, as the company beat earnings expectations on falling revenue, faring better than its rival Lowes but still affected by a challenging housing market.

Financials received the strongest bids in the session, possibly benefiting from some sector rotation, as participants move assets towards defensive sectors and some of the sectors that had lagged the market in the last weeks.

JPMorgan (   NYSE:JPM), the second largest U.S. lender, was among the outperformers in the sector, posting the biggest percentage gain in the blue chip index, as shares jumped 2.17% to $43.81. JPMorgan (NYSE:JPM) received a strong bid as it held its annual shareholder meeting and its CEO Jamie Dimon commented the economy was at the beginning of a self-sustaining recovery.

American Express (   NYSE:AXP) also moved in the financial bandwagon, with shares posting the second biggest percentage gain in the Dow and posting a new 52-week high at $50.80. AMEX shares gained 1.38% to $50.76.

The consumer discretionary sector edged 0.1% higher, despite retailers having a mixed day, in addition to Home Depot and Wal-Mart, Saks, Dicks Sporting Goods (NYSE:DKS) , TJX Companies (NYSE:TJX) , and Urban Outfitters (NASDAQ:URBN) also reported their quarterly results.

Dicks (   NYSE:DKS), the sporting goods retailer, fell 3.12% to $39.42, closing 0.38% above calculated support at $39.27, after beating earnings expectations on revenues that were below consensus and issuing earnings guidance for the current quarter an its full fiscal year below consensus. The stock traded as low as $38.53 however it traded off its lows after Needham upgraded Dicks to a Buy from Hold, setting its target price at $45, as the firm sees store openings accelerating, margins continuing to expand, and operating leverage continue to grow.

Saks (   NYSE:SKS), the owner and operator of Saks Fifth Avenue (NYSE:SKS) stores, fell 0.62% to $11.20, following and earnings beat on revenues that were in line with consensus and as the company said that it expects comparable store sales growth in the high-single digit range for Q2 and in the mid-to-high single digit range in the second half of the fiscal year. Saks traded initially to the upside, posting an intraday high of $11.79, however it lost steam and moved into negative territory by mid morning trade.

TJX Companies (   NYSE:TJX), the owner and operator of T.J. Maxx and Marshalls chains, tumbled 4.14% to $52.06, as its quarterly profit was below expectations on revenues that were in-line with consensus. TJX said results were negatively impacted by the closing of its A.J. Wright Chain, and a decline in same-store sales in Europe. TJX was actually priced to perfection, with the stock trading near its all-time high of $54.94.

The sector received support from the luxury casino operator, Wynn Resorts (NASDAQ:WYNN) (   NASDAQ:WYNN), as it gained 1.64% to $142.85, following yesterdays announcement from its CEO Steve Wynn that the company will double its revenue coming from Macau as a new resort, its Cotal Development, opens in 2015, with the company joining Las Vegas Sands (OOTC:LVSXP) (OOTC:LVSXU) (NYSE:LVS) (   NYSE:LVS) as U.S. casino operators that generate most of their revenues from what has become as the gaming capital of the world. Las Vegas Sands gained 0.66% to $41.33.

Mid week, stocks gained, snapping a 3-day losing streak, as investors appetite for risk returned, which coupled with a weak Dollar, sparked a rebound in commodity prices. Sentiment received a boost from Dells earnings and from indications from the Fed that it does not plan to hike rates anytime soon.

The unwillingness for stocks to move lower, along with persistence strength in the materials, energy, and technology (OTCBB:ENGT) sectors provided leadership for the broad market to gradually add to gains as the session progressed, with the Dollar trading in negative territory for most of the session.

The market was able to build to the gains after the Fed released its latest FOMC meeting minutes. The Fed stressed that their talk of any exit strategy doesn't mean they are ready to tighten monetary policy soon. Actually, according to the minutes most Fed officials prefer to tighten policy through interest rate hikes rather than asset sales. However since they see inflation as transitory, they are looking to maintain low interest rates for the foreseeable future. The central bank indicated they would eventually cut the Fed's portfolio, and that selling mortgage-related debt would be a priority.

Most of the S&P 500 sectors finished with gains, materials, energy, consumer discretionary, and industrials were the best performers, while utilities fell and consumer staples gained the least amid the sectors.

Investors risk appetite returned during the session, which along with a weak greenback made for a string session in the commodities. Crude oil surged 3.3% to close at $100.12 per barrel as it was impacted as well by the inventory report and news of wild fires in Canada near the oil sands that have caused the shut-in of some production as a precautionary measure.

Big Oil was an outperformer, with Chevron (   NYSE:CVX) and Exxon Mobil (NYSE:XOM) (   NYSE:XOM) posting some of the biggest gains in the Dow Jones Industrial Average. Chevron jumped 2.44% to $102.86, closing below its high for the session at $103.46; meanwhile Exxon gained 1.65% to $81.74, also closing below its intraday high of $82.27.

Suncor Energy (   NYSE:SU), the integrated energy company focused on developing petroleum resource basins, such as the Athabasca oil sands (TSX:ATH) (OOTC:ATHOF) in Canada, jumped 2.62% to $40.72, with the stock continuing to trade below its pre-earnings price, despite beating expectations, as it had been under pressure in the last sessions as the whole energy sector.

Precious metals move higher in early morning, with both metals extending their respective rallies heading into the afternoon session, where gold put in highs at $1499.70 an ounce and silver at $35.55 an ounce. Both pulled back modestly from those highs before closing.

Pan American Silver (   NASDAQ:PAAS), the second largest primary silver producer in the world with operations in Argentina, Bolivia, Mexico, and Peru, climbed 1.55% to $32.77 on higher silver prices. The company slid 0.24% in after hours on news that Treasury Metals (TSX:TML) (OOTC:TSRMF) has agreed to purchase 100% of the Pico Machay Gold Project from Pan American Silver. (TSX:PAA) (NASDAQ:PAAS)

Not all gold miners benefited from the higher prices on the bullion. Eldorado Gold (TSX:ELD) (OOTC:ELDXF) (AMEX:EGO) (   NYSE:EGO), the Canadian gold miner with operations in Turkey, China, Greece and Brazil, was shun by investors, with its shares falling 2.14% to $15.12 after rolling over at its intraday high of $15.70.

The strength in natural resource plays and other economic and dollar sensitive stocks, like the industrials, pushed Caterpillar (   NYSE:CAT) to the top of the blue chip index. Shares of Caterpillar traded as high as $105.50 and closing with a 3.11% gain at $105.25. Caterpillar has calculated support at $101.47 and resistance of $116.25, its all-time high.

Technology gained 0.8%, as Dell (NASDAQ:DELL) provided a boost to the sector. However Hewlett-Packard (   NYSE:HPQ) posted the biggest percentage decline in the Dow Jones Industrial Average once again, as shares were fell 1.14%, extending yesterdays sell-off after receiving a downgrade from JPMorgan to a Neutral from Overweight. The firms also cut its target price to $42 a share from $55, citing the major disappointment in its outlook. HP was able to trade off its lows of $35.99, which was a new 52-week low.

Dell (   NASDAQ:DELL), the worlds third largest PC maker, surged 5.35% to $16.73 to the top of the NASDAQ-100 but the stock was not able to close above its calculated resistance at $16.80. Dell posted a new 52-week high early on at $16.96 after the company posted an upside earnings surprise. Dell said profit for the quarter was $0.55 per share, $0.11 better than consensus; revenues climbed 1.0% year over year to $15.02 billion versus consensus of $15.41 billion. Participants cheered that non-GAAP operating margin of 9.2% was well above consensus of 7.5% consensus, reflecting Dell's improved profitability in end-user-computing.

Also providing a lift in the tech sector, Research In Motion (TSX:RIM) (NASDAQ:RIMM) (   NASDAQ:RIMM), the maker of the Blackberry smartphone, jumped 3.77% to $45.43 after it was upgraded to Market Perform from Underperform at Bernstein.

Apple (   NASDAQ:AAPL) also benefited from Dells boost to the tech sector; the stock climbed 1.11% to $339.87, extending its rebound from yesterdays low at $330.73. Apple faces resistance to the upside from its declining 50day moving average at the $343 area.

And Renren (   NYSE:RENN), the leading real name social networking Internet platform in China, surged 7.62% to $13.70, still trading below its original IPO price of $14 on anticipation of the   LinkedIn IPO, which priced after the close at $45 per share.

Consumer discretionary stocks posted important gains, climbing 1.2% in the session, despite Staples (   NASDAQ:SPLS), the office product retailer, plunging more than 15% to $16.63 and posting the biggest percentage decline in the S&P 500 Index. Staples suffered after the company reported disappointing same store sales and weaker than expected results.

Target (   NYSE:TGT), the Minnesota based general merchandise discount store chain, was another retailer than struggled during the session and limited gains in the sector. Target fell 1.61% to $49.96 after its earnings topped expectations but its sales fell short of estimates. The retailer said that it earned $0.99 per share, $0.05 better than consensus, on revenues that climbed 5.1% year over year to $15.94 billion.

However better than expected results from BJs Wholesales and Abercrombie & Fitch (NYSE:ANF) helped lift the sector. BJs (   NYSE:BJ), the third largest wholesale club retail chain, climbed 1.75% to $52.19 and posting a new 52-week high at $52.46 on the back of an upside earnings surprise as more consumers turned to BJs for groceries and gasoline.

And Abercrombie & Fitch (   NYSE:ANF), the specialty retailer, rallied 3.44% to $75.69, after posting a new 52-week high of $76.76, on an upside earnings surprise and as Needham raised its target price on the stock to $92 from $85, citing a renewed earnings power.

On Thursday, stocks managed to close higher despite weak economic data amid the LinkedIn IPO frenzy and weakening crude oil prices.

The Labor Department said that initial claims for unemployment fell by 29,000 to 409,000 in week ended May 14 from an upwardly revised 438,000 claims the week before. Economists had expected claims to fall to 420,000 from the previously reported 434,000. Continuing claims fell to 3.71 million in the week ended May 7 from 3.79 million.

However the early move lost steam, following unexpectedly lower than expected economic data, which pushed the major indices into negative territory. The Philadelphia Fed's business activity index tumbled to 3.9 in May from 18.5 in April, a surprising drop, as economists had expected the index to rise to 20.

The Conference Board's index of leading indicators fell 0.3% in April from a 0.7% gain in March. It was the first decline for the index since June 2010. Also, existing home sales fell 0.8% in April, surprising economists that had expected home sales to rise.

But after midday the bulls regrouped in a renewed push to send major benchmark indices to positive territory, amid falling crude oil prices and the frenzy that followed the LinkedIn IPO, the biggest Internet IPO since Google. (NASDAQ:GOOG)

Among the key S&P 500 sectors, industrials, telecom, and consumer staples posted the best performances. Industrials managed to put together a 0.7%, however its lack of weight in the overall market limited their ability to lead. Meanwhile, Healthcare was the only declining sector.

The industrial sector was able to gather some strength despite the weak economic data, as the dollar weakened, lifting the earnings potential of the big blue chips. Boeing (   NYSE:BA) was one of the best components in the blue chip index, with shares climbing 1.14% to $78.02. General Electric (   NYSE:GE), the maker of power turbines and medical devices, also benefited, with shares gaining 1.01% to $19.96. GE likely received a bid on speculation of possible share buybacks; following a Financial Times article saying the company might repurchase $12 billion of its common stock.

The biggest headline of the day was the debut of LinkedIn (NYSE:LNDK), LinkedIn (   NYSE:LNKD), the social networking site for professionals. LinkedIn soared more than 140% to a high of 122.7, as participants bid the stock amid frenzy to get a stake in the social network play. LinkedIn finally closed with a gain of 109.44% to $94.25, raising eyebrows with some remembering the 90s tech bubble and comparing the crazy multiples. Other pundits and analysts were commenting on the pricing of the IPO at $45, which originally valued the company at $4.25 billion, with the market bumping that valuation at the end of the session to $8.9 billion.

The LinkedIn price action coupled with its sky-high valuation impacted trading in Renren (   NYSE:RENN). The stock traded as high as $14.80, once again trading above its $14 IPO price, however the move lost steam towards the close, with Renren closing with a modest gain of $0.36% to $13.75. Renrens IPO deflated quickly with participants selling off positions after hitting a high of $24 on growth and valuation concerns.

The tech sector ended with a fractional gain, as it was pressured by weakness in the semiconductors space, as Goldman Sachs turned cautious on the sector, citing declining pc demand and increasing inventories.

Intel (   NASDAQ:INTC) lost 1.42% to $23.54, posting the biggest percentage decline in the Dow Jones Industrial Average, after it was downgraded to a Sell from Neutral at Goldman Sachs.

KLA-Tencor (   NASDAQ:KLAC), the maker of yield management and process monitoring systems for the semiconductor industry, also suffered, tumbling 3.78% to $41.21, posting one of the biggest percentage declines in the broad market index, after it was also downgraded to a Sell from Neutral at Goldman Sachs.

The tech sector ended near the flat line, following Apple (   NASDAQ:AAPL), which traded as high as $342.41 before retreating as it faced strong resistance at its declining 50day moving average in the $343 area. The stock ended the session edging up by 0.19% to $340.53. The tech giant and owner of iTunes signed a cloud-music licensing deal with EMI Group Ltd. and is close to completing agreements with Universal Music Group and Sony Music Entertainment.

The energy sector ended with a fractional gain amid weakness in the energy complex. Natural gas shed 2.3$ to $4.10 per MMBtu on bearish inventory data, while crude oil closed with a 1.7% loss at $ 98.93 per barrel, as gasoline futures sold-off early on, remaining the rest of the session range bound. Crude weakened as The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration forecast an above average hurricane season, but it dialed back its Atlantic hurricane season forecast a little from last year.

Consumer stocks saw interest, specifically food related stocks, like McDonalds (   NYSE:MCD), the worlds largest restaurant chain. McDonalds jumped 1.24% to $82.51 and posting a new all-time high of $82.63 after the company announced its Board of Directors declared a quarterly cash dividend of $0.61 per share of common stock. Investors bid the stock, as sluggish economic data seems to suggest that consumers will likely trade down amid an economic slowdown, benefiting companies like McDonalds.

Retailers on the other hand struggled following a series of weak earnings results and outlooks. Sears Holdings (   NASDAQ:SHLD), the holding company that owns and operates the Sears and Kmart retail chains, fell 2.62% to $73.86, trading below calculated support at $75.25, after reporting a wider-than-expected loss on declining sales. The retailer said that for its fiscal first quarter it loss $1.39 per share, $0.17 worse than consensus, on revenues that fell 3.4% year over year.

GameStop (   NYSE:GME), the video game retailer, rebounded from a loss of more than 5% to finished with a gain of 2.40% to $27.32, following comments from its CEO in the post earnings conference call and after a follow up interview in CNBC, stressing the fact that the retailer is transforming into a hybrid model, which incorporates new technology for streaming and downloading games. The CEO also commented on their highly successful trade-in program. GameStop was under pressure after delivering a disappointing second quarter earnings outlook, despite stronger-than-expected results for the first quarter.

But Dollar Tree (   NASDAQ:DLTR), the operator of a discount variety single-price-point retail chain, jumped 2.90% to $63.11, trading above calculated resistance at $61.80, after a beat of profit expectations as the company continued to benefit from shoppers looking for value and low price items.

Big Lots (   NYSE:BIG), the closeout retailer, impacted the retail space, as it plunged more than 10%, posting the biggest decline in the S&P 500 Index, on reports that the company will not put itself for sale.

The financial sector saw mixed performances, with American Express (   NYSE:AXP) once again posting the biggest percentage gain in the Dow, as shares jumped 1.49% to $51.82.

But Bank of America (   NYSE:BAC), the largest U.S. lender, saw weakness, with shares falling 0.85% to $11.69, posting a new 2011 low at $11.68. In after hours, there were reports that a California appellate court has allowed a class action lawsuit against Bank of Americas unit Countrywide, to proceed. The suit alleges that Countywide made and publish false statements and prospectus regarding its mortgage back securities.

And BlackRock (   NYSE:BLK) jumped 2.51% to $198.10 after the company said that it had agreed to to repurchase Bank of America's remaining ownership interest in BlackRock totaling 13,562,878 of its Series B Convertible Preferred Shares for approximately $2.545 billion, or $187.65 per share.

At the end of the week, stocks ended sharply lower amid options expiration, Dollar strength, and global economic uncertainty. Concerns over European sovereign debt restructuring along a weak outlook for U.S. retail weighed heavily on sentiment.

European markets started with gains on the back of natural resources plays, with London outperforming thanks to BP (NYSE:BP) (   NYSE:BP), which rally after it disclosed that its 10% partner in the Macondo Well, MOEX Offshore, agreed to pay $1.1 billion to settle all the claims regarding the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico last year. However markets reacted negatively to the weak euro on renewed sovereign debt concerns.

In M&A news, Barnes & Noble (   NYSE:BKS), the bookseller chain, surged 29.91% to $18.33 on news that its Board of Directors received a $17 all-cash offer from Liberty Media (   NASDAQ:LINTA) to buy the company. The proposal is contingent on the participation of founding chairman Leonard Riggio, both in terms of his continuing equity ownership and his continuing role in management. Shares of Liberty Media fell 1.47% to $17.70 on the news.

The euro moved lower ahead of elections in Spain on news of a slowing German economy and on uncertainty over how Greece's debt problems could be contained. Fitch downgraded Greece's credit rating and warned of further downgrades if a credible plan to resolve the country's debt crisis was not found.

Most of the key S&P 500 sectors fell, with only the utilities sector finishing unchanged. Financials, materials, and consumer discretionary posted the biggest declines.

Crude oil had a volatile session that saw the energy component surrender an early gain to drop to about $96.40 per barrel before it rallied back to finish pit trade with a 1.2% gain at $100.12 per barrel, as it moved along with the Dollar and on initial concern over economic growth given the uncertainty over the debt situation in Europe.

As for precious metals, gold prices gained 1.2% to end the week at $1510.20 per ounce while silver prices added a relatively modest 0.4% to close the week out at $35.09 per ounce

Regardless of the volatility in oil, BP (   NYSE:BP) jumped 2.53% to $45 benefiting from the news of the payment of $1.1 billion from one of its minority partners settling the claims from the Deep Horizon rig accident. BP closed at its 50day moving average.

JPMorgan Chase (   NYSE:JPM) fell 1.98% to $43.13, posting the biggest percentage decline in the blue chip index, as the financial sector was under pressure amid global financial uncertainty and the cloudy outlook from retailers, which will translate to higher prices for consumers and likely lower sales. JPMorgan was initiated with a Hold at Stifel Nicolaus. The firm noted that the first quarter being the seasonal peak in trading revenues, it is hard to identify a near-term catalyst for approximately 75% of the company's revenue base.

Bank of America (   NYSE:BAC) also saw weakness, with shares falling 0.94% to $11.58, posting a new 2011 low at $11.53. Bank of America was one of the worst Dow components of the session.

In the Dow Jones Industrial average, General Electric (   NYSE:GE) lost 1.70% to $19.62, closing just 0.10% above calculated support and posting the second biggest decline in the blue chip index.

Yingli Green Energy (   NYSE:YGE), the China based photovoltaic modules maker, was tumbled 9.14% to $9.04 after its quarterly results missed expectations. Price action in Yinlgi had left the stock open for additional weakness, as it had closed below its calculated support at $10.15 last session. The company said it earned $0.38 per share, $0.01 worse than consensus. Collins Stewart lowered its estimates and target price on the stock noting that the he solar market is currently in a state of flux, with prices falling rapidly as the industry deals with the overhang of weak first half demand and high inventory. Collins Stewart cut its target price to $13 from $17.

In the tech sector, the frenzy around the LinkedIn IPO eased. LinkedIn (   NYSE:LNKD) fell 1.23% to $93.09 after trading as high as $107, which is still way off from its high reached yesterday at the height of the frenzy of $122.70. Investor demand for the social network play pushed the company towards incredible valuations, as investors shrug off an already hefty valuation at the original IPO price of $45; however today slightly cooler heads prevailed.

Dangdang (   NYSE:DANG), the ecommerce site that its known as the Chinese Amazon.com, gained 3.95% to $21.76, after the company posted results that beat expectations, while providing current quarter revenue guidance that was in-line with consensus. Dandnag traded as high as $22.45 but give back close to half its gains. The company reported earnings of $0.01 per share, $0.01 better than consensus.

Meanwhile, Youko.com (   NYSE:YOKU), the Chinese version of you tube and which IPO was the same day than Dangdang fell 3.71% to $47.75, after the company priced a 12.31 million ADS offering at $48.18 per ADS.

Apple (   NASDAQ:AAPL) was 1.56% to $335.22, with the stock trading as high as $340.95. Apple faces resistance at its declining 50day moving average in the $342 area. The stock closed below its options max pain of $340. Apple move to the downside on iPad 2 production concerns after Bloomberg News reported an explosion at a Foxconn factory in China, which is making the device. The stock had little reaction to Sterne Agee raising its target price to $460 from $445.

But it was consumer discretionary stocks and specifically retail that was garnering attention amid weakness on concern over margin compression, sparked after the Gap (   NYSE:GPS) earnings outlook misstep.

Gap Inc. (   NYSE:GPS), the owner and operator of specialty retailers like Banana Republic and Old Navy, plunged 17.48% to $19.35, closing below its 200day moving average at $20.54 and posting the biggest percentage decline in the S&P 500 Index, after disappointing investors with a weak outlook, overshadowing better than expected results for the previous quarter. The company slashed its earnings outlook due to cost increases in the back half of the year, which will outweigh price increases.

Aeropostale (   NYSE:ARO), the specialty retailer, tumbled 14.25% to $18.30 after its own earnings misstep, however in Aeropostales case, analysts were pointing to problems with merchandising as the main culprit for the miss. Stiffel Nicolaus downgraded the retailer to a Hold from Buy and cited lack of a balance and compelling womens clothing assortment.

The weakness in retail touched also the luxury side, however the stocks were faring better on the sense that they should be able to pass price increases without affecting sales volumes significantly. Tiffany (   NYSE:TIF), the fine jewelry maker and luxury retailer, fell 1.45% to $69.24, closing 3.99% above calculated support of $66.48. Tiffany traded as high as $70.26, its calculated resistance.

urn:contentItem:5WFJ-TGY1-JB4M-V1R6-00000-00Stocks finish best June in decades, capping strong first half of 20192019-06-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:23ZLexisNexisStocks finish best June in decades, capping strong first half of 2019Thomas Heath

Stocks on Friday finished their best June in decades, capping a strong first half of 2019 and a big rebound from May's market downer. But the good news is tempered by the fact that investors relied on five giant companies for a third of the gains over the past quarter, reflecting the digital economy's remarkable growth and its potential for fragility.

Three of the Standard & Poor's 500 index leaders - Facebook, Apple and Amazon - have come under scrutiny from regulators and politicians in the past several months for their consumer dominance. Microsoft and Walt Disney round out the big five performers.

(Amazon founder and chief executive Jeff Bezos owns The Washington Post.)

The five companies together are worth more than $3.4 trillion as measured by the price of their stock. That is 14 percent of the combined value of all the companies in the S&P 500, according to Howard Silverblatt of S&P Dow Jones Indices.

"I would prefer broader market leadership and not such a narrow focus," said Charlie Toole, portfolio manager at Adviser Investments. "When you have one or two or four names leading the market, you worry that if they trip up, it's going to trip up the entire market."

All three indexes are up on the year, with the S&P 500 climbing 17 percent in the first six months, the Dow Jones industrial average registering a 14 percent gain and the technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index leading everybody with 20 percent. All three are close to their all-time highs on a June bounce following remarks from Federal Reserve Chair Jerome H. Powell that "we will act as appropriate to sustain the expansion."

The Dow closed at 26,599, up 73 points on Friday to finish June with a gain of 7.1 percent. It was its best first half since 1999 and best June since 1938, when it surged 24 percent. The S&P 500 closed at 2,941, up 16 points on the day and up 6.89 percent for June. The broad market posted its best first half since 1997. It was the S&P's best June since 1955, when it climbed 8.2 percent. The Nasdaq composite finished up 38 points at 8,006, pushing its June rally to 7.4 percent. That's the Nasdaq's best June since 2000, when it gained 16.6 percent.

Stocks got a boost on several fronts toward the end of the week. The Federal Reserve signed off on stock buybacks and dividends for 18 big banks, spurring a rally in financial stocks. U.S. consumer spending in May increased moderately, feeding hopes for a Federal Reserve interest rate cut. Consumer sentiment rose slightly above forecasts, although the measure has slipped since early May, when it posted a 15-year high.

High-tech dominance has been the story of the past several years of the bull market, with Google, Facebook, Amazon and Apple nudging out legacy names like General Electric, Walmart and Exxon.

Money managers say investors need to own the big technology stocks or lose out.

"Technology is where you have the revenue and profitability growth, and that's where stocks would be going up," said Krishna Memani, vice chair of investments at Invesco. "The number of stocks that have been able to do that has been narrow, so investors are willing to pay a high premium for those stocks rather than for a paper company."

The technology and communications service sectors, which cover four of the five leaders, together make up 30 percent of the S&P, according to Silverblatt. Technology is up 26 percent this year.

"I don't want to talk down the stock rally because there's only two or three stocks behind it," said Chris Rupkey, chief financial economist at MUFG Union Bank. "A lot of times, the companies that are increasing at a greater rate naturally slow down and other companies come along and pick up the slack."

Technology companies have been under increased attention from Republican and Democratic leaders and from government regulators in the United States and abroad who say Big Tech has become too powerful.

Facebook co-founder and former spokesman Chris Hughes has called for the breakup of the social media giant. The U.S. Justice Department and Federal Trade Commission have put Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google parent Alphabet under heightened antitrust scrutiny.

Apple chief executive Tim Cook earlier this month disagreed with politicians such as Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.), a presidential candidate who has called for the company's breakup. Cook said in an interview on "CBS This Morning" that Apple is not a monopoly, but he said, "Scrutiny is fair."

Investor Michael Farr, president of wealth-management firm Farr, Miller & Washington, said today's market leaders will sooner or later run out of steam, prompting investors to look for new faces or even to latch on to some old names that have been ignored and are cheap.

"Everybody wants to bet on yesterday's fastest horse," Farr said. "They don't care if they are healthy. But you have horses dropping dead, and you've got to find a fresh one to ride."

Aerospace giant Boeing was among the Dow's best performers in 2018, but its stock has dropped around 20 percent in the past four months over its 737 Max problems. Disney shares, on the other hand, have risen more than 25 percent in the past two months, boosting its market cap by around $50 billion.

Memani, Rupkey and others see big upside in stocks through the rest of 2019, even as anxiousness prevailed Friday ahead of a critical meeting between President Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping on the sidelines of the Group of 20 meeting in Japan.

Trump's obsession with rising stock prices has been one of the hallmarks of his presidency. He even tweeted about the bull market, now in its 10th year, from the G-20:

"The Stock Market went up massively from the day after I won the Election, all the way up to the day that I took office, because of the enthusiasm for the fact that I was going to be President. That big Stock Market increase must be credited to me. If Hillary won - a Big Crash!"

Rupkey said Trump "will do whatever it takes to get stocks on track coming out of the weekend. The lesson of recent months is whatever the negative headline, somehow the trade talks get resurrected. So try not to hit the sell button."

Between Trump's stock market fixation and the Federal Reserve's willingness to use the money supply to bolster returns, some investors say there is a safety net under the stock market.

"We have to recognize the power of the Fed," said Kristina Hooper, global market strategist at Invesco. "The Fed has placed a 'put' under the stock market over the past decade and could do so once again."

Hooper said investors might be concerned that the market is fragile because of its narrow leadership. "But that has occurred in the past, and it doesn't have to end calamitously. The baton can get passed to other names."

urn:contentItem:5WCW-Y7Y1-F19Y-C242-00000-00Stocks gain amid fresh trade deal hopes; dollar slips before Fed decision2019-06-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:23ZLexisNexisExclusiveStocks gain amid fresh trade deal hopes; dollar slips before Fed decisionAyesha Hassan

In the bond market, Treasurys slipped as 10-year yields gained 3 basis points.

Asian stocks climb amid renewed trade deal hopes.

Fed likely to leave rates unchanged at 2 p.m. ET.

OPEC finalizes meeting dates.

Asian stocks gained while European shares and U.S. equity futures reflected cautious trading as markets evaluated fresh hopes of a trade deal between the U.S. and China. The dollar dipped ahead of the U.S. Federal Open Market Committee's announcement.

U.S. President Donald Trump said he will have an "extended meeting" with Chinese counterpart Xi Jinping at the G-20 summit in Japan next week. Both the parties will resume trade negotiations before that, Trump added.

The Shanghai SE Composite gained 1%, Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index climbed 2.6% and Japan's Nikkei 225 index closed 1.7% higher.

European shares were little changed as of 6:30 a.m. ET, with the exception of the FTSE 100, which lost 0.3%. Meanwhile, the German automotive sector gained, with Continental AG's shares rising 3.2% and Daimler AG and Bayerische Motoren Werke AG gaining 1% each.

International Consolidated Airlines Group SA's shares shed 4.4% as it intends to buy 200 of Boeing Co.'s 737 aircraft, which are currently grounded globally.

Wall Street is due to open higher, though by a small margin.

The dollar spot index, which measures the currency against a basket of peers, dipped almost 0.1% to $97.567.

The central bank is expected to hold rates today, "but investors expect the Fed to lose 'patience' in its accompanying statement and remain ready to 'act as appropriate'," Ipek Ozkardeskaya of the London Capital Group wrote.

Trump has repeatedly criticized the Fed for its rate hikes, and reports emerged yesterday that the White House in February weighed the legality of demoting Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell to a governor post. When asked about Powell's potential demotion, Trump said June 18: "Let's see what he does."

Sterling appreciated 0.1% against the dollar. The U.K.'s Conservatives have narrowed down the leadership race to five candidates, with former foreign secretary and hard Brexiter Boris Johnson still the clear front-runner.

The euro rose 0.1% against the dollar, while the Japanese yen was little changed.

In the bond market, Treasurys slipped as 10-year yields gained 3 basis points to 2.089%.

Ten-year German Bund yields also added 3 basis points to negative 0.289%, having fallen yesterday on European Central Bank President Mario Draghi's speech signaling the possibility of rate cuts and asset purchases. Draghi's tone suggests the ECB could take action based on only a small drop in growth and core inflation, or a significant decline in survey-based inflation expectations, Berenberg Economics said in a note.

However, BofA Merrill Lynch Global Research notes that data does not justify the "aggressive" monetary policy easing being priced in by markets for the G-10 economies, unless a trade war persists.

In commodities, Brent crude oil fell 0.43% to $61.87 per barrel on the ICE Futures Exchange. The OPEC will meet in Vienna, Austria, July 1 and then have a meeting with its allies July 2.

Gold slipped 0.3% per ounce.

More from S&P Global Market Intelligence:

Inflation expectations weaken before FOMC as focus shifts to Powell messaging

Market punishes Prosperity for paying 'very full price' in LegacyTexas deal

As big tech moves into financials, banks argue for a level regulatory field

Economists: US retail sales will grow at a moderate pace in Q3

Deutsche Bank's future in US uncertain as i-bank shakeup looms

The day ahead:

8:30 a.m. ET Canada CPI (Econoday consensus: 2.2% yearly, 0.2% monthly)

10:30 a.m. ET U.S. Energy Information Administration petroleum status report

2 p.m. ET U.S. FOMC announcement and forecasts

2:30 p.m. ET U.S. Fed Chair Powell's press conference
