Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:420K-BY90-009B-G436-00000-00Stocks Gain Ground in Midweek Bounce Back; Network Associates Succumbs to Intense Selling Pressure; A Look at Law and Order in 20002000-12-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:23ZLexisNexisCNN MONEYLINE NEWS HOUR 18:30Ralph AcamporaBusinessSHOW00122700V19Stocks Gain Ground in Midweek Bounce Back; Network Associates Succumbs to Intense Selling Pressure; A Look at Law and Order in 2000Stuart Varney, Allan Chernoff, Fred Katayama, Bruce Francis, Catherine Callaway, Ceci Rodgers, Peter Viles, Casey Wian, Steve Young, Myron Kandel

Wall Street gained ground today, as investors emerged to snap up bargains and pushes the Dow to its fourth straight gain. Plus, a look back at this year's legal highlights, from the Microsoft ruling to the Emulex stock scam: how events at the courthouse made headlines around the globe. Also, it rode to prominence fighting computer viruses, but today Network Associates succumbed to intense selling pressure. Can it ever recover?

THIS IS A RUSH TRANSCRIPT. THIS COPY MAY NOT BE IN ITS FINAL FORM AND MAY BE UPDATED.

STUART VARNEY, CNN ANCHOR: Tonight, a blue chip winning streak. The Dow gains ground for the fourth straight session, and the Nasdaq moves higher as well, in a midweek bounce back.

It rode to prominence fighting computer viruses. But today, Network Associates succumbed to intense selling pressure: Can it ever recover?

Brutal winter weather wreaking havoc on the roads; we'll look at how it's threatening the economy at a crucial time.

And the Emulex hoax, the Love Bug virus, and the titanic battle between the government and Microsoft, all part of our look back at law and order in 2000.

ANNOUNCER: This is MONEYLINE. Reporting tonight from New York, Stuart Varney.

VARNEY: Good evening everyone and welcome to MONEYLINE. Willow is off tonight.

Our top story: a blue chip winning streak on Wall Street. The Dow today rose for the fourth straight session, up 4.5 percent over one week. But the damage in 2000 is hard to erase in just a few good sessions. Unless the Dow breaks back above 11,000 over the next two days and stays there, this will go down as the worst year for the blue chips since 1981. But today investors seemed cautiously positive, sending the Dow up almost 111 points, to 10,803.

And the Big Board volume stronger than yesterday with over a billion shares traded. The Nasdaq fared even better than the Dow today, in percentage terms. That is, it was up 46 points. That is nearly 2 percent. It ended at 2539.

The S&P 500 rose nearly 14 points, that's about 1 percent. It closed just under 1393.

Allan Chernoff has been following the action all day; he joins us now from the New York Stock Exchange -- Allan.

ALLAN CHERNOFF, CNN CORRESPONDENT: Stuart, welcome to the battleground. The battle in these final days of the year is between bargain hunters on the one hand, and tax-loss sellers, those investors trying to get some benefit out of an absolutely miserable year, by taking losses to offset capital gains. The tax-loss sellers seemed to be dominating in the morning, but, as trading progressed, it was the bargain hunters who won the day.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

(voice-over): Bargain hunters turned to retailers to do their stock shopping today. A shopping mall survey showed sales rose a surprising 2.2 percent during the holiday season. While the survey said little about profit, investors snapped up apparel retailers anyway. Abercrombie and Fitch, a stock as volatile as fashion trends, was up more than 4, a 25 percent gain. Pacific Sunwear, American Eagle outfitters, and TJX benefited from positive comments at UBS Warburg.

STUART SHIKLAR, PRESIDENT, SHIKLAR ASSET MANAGEMENT: With it being bargain hunting for sales after Christmas in the department stores, I think we've had the same phenomena occurring now in the stock market. We've had many stocks decline this year -- 20, 30, 40, 50 percent from where they were just a year ago. And that seems to be the same percentage discounts we're getting in retail stores.

CHERNOFF: There was also shopping for some fallen tech titans: like Fiber Optic component maker JDS Uniphase, up for the second day in a row, but still off 70 percent from its high in March. Networking chipmaker PMC Sierra, another fallen star, attracting investors today, but still off 67 percent from its high. It was another strong day for banks and insurance shares. Investors stocking up on financials, anticipating an easing in the Federal Reserve's monetary policy.

And pharmaceutical stocks continued their run, now up 26 percent on the year. Dow component Johnson & Johnson has helped rally the industrials higher for four straight sessions. But, like every rally this year, the question remains: can it last?

SETH TOBIAS, CIRCLE T PARTNERS: There are some worried investors out there waiting for the next shoe to drop, whether it's a major technology stock that's going to have disappointing earnings, or there'll be some sort of economic data that will come out and disappoint investors. I'm not so sure we're completely out of the woods here.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

CHERNOFF: So, in the face of more earnings warnings to come, can we expect a rally at the beginning of the year? As tax loss selling dissipates, many money managers are betting the market will rise early in January. We'll tell you why that is so important to the coming year later in the broadcast -- Stuart.

VARNEY: That's Allan Chernoff at the Big Board battleground. Thanks so much, Allan.

Let's go right to Fred Katayama now at the Nasdaq market site with a look at the big tech movers and one bombshell profit warning. Another one, Fred. What is it?

FRED KATAYAMA, CNN CORRESPONDENT: Well, that bombshell is big, indeed. Investors shook off some tech earnings warnings and went bargain hunting for big cap stocks. In a reversal of yesterday, investors sold off at the open following an earnings warning from Internet security firm Network Associates. But the Nasdaq quickly reversed course, as investors piled into chip stocks, some of it on short covering, as well as business-to-business software stocks.

SG Cowen's positive earnings outlook on b2b companies fueled buying in that sector. Commerce One rocketed more than 13 percent higher. Ariba gained more than 3 3/8 percent. And purchasepro.com added a little more than 2.

Yesterday's losers were today's winners, as the Philadelphia Semiconductor index added 24 points for a gain of more than 4 percent. PMC Sierra and Applied Micro Circuits, as well as Triquint Semiconductor all gained more than 12 percent. And Novellus rose 2 15/16. Intel, however, finishing on the down side, losing five- sixteenths. It has lost 56 percent of its value since September 1, as you see in the chart, right over there.

Institutional investors sought comfort in established big name stocks, such as telecom equipment stocks. JDS Uniphase rose 5 1/2 after the investment house Ryan, Beck predicted, JDS will expand its earnings next year and raise its price target to $200.

Another winner: Qualcomm. It gained 7.2 percent. Dell was another winner. It added 50 cents. But Oracle fell, as did Microsoft. Microsoft losing nearly 1 percent on the day. There were several positive aspects about today's session: the Nasdaq closed at the day's high. Volume was a firm 1.9 billion shares. And investors did not sell into the rally. But some market watchers say it's too early to say the tide has turned. Larry Wachtel at Prudential says he wants to see the Nasdaq rally at least three days in a row before he gets excited. The last time the Nasdaq did that was in August -- Stuart.

VARNEY: Fred, are there many Nasdaq investors who are really saying, yes, this is a sustainable rally?

KATAYAMA: Well, not yet Stuart. Many stock strategists we talked to, say what we saw today was a bounce back. Investors were simply nosing around for what they termed bargains.

VARNEY: Fair enough. Fred Katayama at the Nasdaq market site. Thanks so much, Fred.

Well, the tech stock in the glare today, as Fred mentioned, Network Associates. The company, best known for its virus-fighting computer products, issued a massive profit warning last night and a corner office shakeup. The reaction was swift and severe today on Wall Street. Bad news for a company that's already had a rough year.

Bruce Francis reports. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

BRUCE FRANCIS, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): Shares of Network Associates lost more than half of their value, as investors shuddered at tech's latest warning. After the bell Tuesday, Network Associates warned that revenues would fall far short of expectations, about a quarter of what Wall Street was expecting. Part of the reason: weak spending on the company's key "sniffer" product for corporate network management. The company is also changing accounting methods, booking sales only on "sell-through", when the end-user has purchased the product, not when Network Associates sells it to the distributor.

MARK FERNANDES, MERRILL LYNCH: Most of the leading companies are recognizing revenue on sell-through, which is really what you need to be doing, I think, because you have no idea what the end-user demand is otherwise, and this is why, you know, Network Associates has had this trouble.

FRANCIS: Network Associates made the change so it would be in compliance with a new accounting rule, known as SAB 101. Just six weeks ago, the company said in a SEC filing, that it is currently evaluating the impact of SAB 101, but does not expect that such impact, if any, will be material. Instead, the changes, along with the lower revenues, will wipe out profits, and force the company to take a major loss. The company is also making a clean sweep of the executive suite: CEO Bill Larson, Chief Financial officer Prabhat Goyal and President Peter Watkins have all resigned.

The problems are familiar to investors, who endured a 92 percent drop in the company's stock since its peak nearly two years ago. With the stock now in the single digits, some analysts say the company might make an appealing takeover.

BOB LAM, BEAR STEARNS: I think what's going on in a company with a change in management, I think a number of large companies might be quite interested in them.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

FRANCIS: The key question for investors: is this another sign that tech spending is weakening across the board, or just a one- company story. Right now analysts are saying that it's a little bit of both and that's kind of troubling, Stuart

VARNEY: It's hedging, isn't it, basically?

FRANCIS: Absolutely.

VARNEY: Thanks, Bruce.

The news from Network Associates hits the rival stocks as well. Let's take a look at the damage: Network Associates, itself, plunged 7 1/4 points, that is about 62 percent; it closed at 4 1/2. Symantec fell just over a dollar, down to 30 15/16. Entrust Technologies gave back nearly 2 points, and Checkpoint Software lost more than 5 1/2, but that stock is still a rare high-tech hotshot this year. It's still up more than 170 percent.

News out after the bell tonight: job cuts in America's biggest railroad. Union Pacific said it will cut 2000 jobs next year, that's about 4 percent of the work force. The company also said that quarterly profits will fall short of expectation, with the chief executive blaming the sudden weakening of the economy in the last few weeks. The warning may be a downer for Union Pacific investors, who watched the stock surge this year. Today, it closed up nearly 1 1/2 at 52 5/8, and that is a new 52-week high.

Still ahead on MONEYLINE, as severe winter storms hammer the plains, is the economy starting to feel a chill? Find out whether icy roads can throw economic growth into a tailspin.

Plus, with Japan tilting toward recession, what's the potential impact for a worldwide economic slowdown?

And later, a look back at a year in which some of the biggest tech battles were fought not in the marketplace but in the courtroom. It's the latest in our series on the year's top business stories.

ANNOUNCER: From CNN's New York headquarters, this is THE MONEYLINE NEWS HOUR.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

VARNEY: A discovery today at the home of the suspect in those Massachusetts office shootings. More on that from Catherine Callaway in the "MONEYLINE News Digest" -- Catherine.

CATHERINE CALLAWAY, CNN ANCHOR: Thank you, Stuart.

Investigators say they have confiscated bomb-making materials, blasting caps and literature on explosives at the home of Michael McDermott. He pleaded not guilty today to shooting seven colleagues at Edgewater Technology. Prosecutors told the court that McDermott attacked with, in their words, "extreme atrocity and cruelty." He allegedly began by shooting five co-workers in the company's reception area and corridors.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TOM O'REILLY, ASST D.A., MIDDLESEX COUNTY: He then went down into the accounting area, where several individuals had barricaded themselves in an office. Mr. McDermott blew the door off and the door handle with a shotgun. He then went inside and he shot one individual three times in the chest in an apparent attempt -- as he was, like, crawling on his back trying to flee him.

Another woman was shot twice in the legs and then shot in the head with a shotgun.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CALLAWAY: McDermott is being held without bail tonight. Prosecutors are still trying to determine whether a tax dispute with the IRS touched off yesterday's shooting rampage.

And also arraigned today on a very different charge: actor Robert Downey Jr. He pleaded not guilty to drug possession. Downey was arrested over Thanksgiving weekend, just four months after his release from prison on another drug charge. If convicted, he could face up to four years behind bars.

And there are doubts tonight about whether a planned meeting between Israeli and Palestinian leaders in Egypt tomorrow will take place. They're scheduled to discuss peace proposals from President Clinton. At least one Palestinian official reportedly says a letter from his side today is a virtual rejection of the proposals.

And finally, the South is still battling snow and ice from its latest winter storm, the second in two weeks. Nearly 600,000 homes across the region were without power today. More snow could arrive tomorrow night.

Those are the stories at the top of the hour.

Back to you now, Stuart.

VARNEY: All right, thanks very much, Katherine.

The harsh winter weather is clearly a travel threat. Is it an economic threat as well. With fears of a slowdown mounting, the holiday storms appear to have to put the chill on retail sales in key areas of the country.

Ceci Rodgers has the story from Chicago.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

CECI RODGERS, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): You could call it a case of bad timing. Just as the economy began to slow down, the worst winter weather in more than a decade blasted through the United States. And rather than slide over icy roads to the shopping malls, many consumers opted to stay home.

DANA TELSEY, BEAR STEARNS: Cold weather definitely impacts, especially in some of the Midwest and Northeast areas.

RODGERS: Even with a last-minute surge the week before Christmas, the final tally shows retail holiday sales rose at the slowest pace in four years. The weak results can't all be blamed on weather. Consumers are feeling less confident for a variety of reasons, including the crash in Nasdaq stocks and higher energy costs. But harsh weather is making things seem even worse, especially because it comes on the heels of the warmest winter in more than a century.

JON DAVIS, SALOMONSMITH BARNEY: The reason why this winter is so noteworthy is that it's such a major change from what we've been through in the winters of the late '90s, which were unseasonably warm across the entire country. It's a shock when we're going to get our heating bills coming up over the next couple of months. It's a shock when you're walking to work or walking to school. RODGERS: Analysts say heating costs will go up even more than the doubling that was already expected this winter due to rising oil prices. That's because temperatures are more than 10 degrees below normal.

FADEL GHEIT, FAHENSTOCK & CO.: If the cold weather continues, expect to pay higher prices.

RODGERS: And the weather is expected to continue to be colder than usual.

DAVIS: There's absolutely no indication of any kind of a big warm-up. It looks like we just continue the intrusion of Arctic air masses into the United States.

RODGERS (on camera): Economists don't know the exact cost of transportation delays, business closings, and the squeeze on consumers as they spend more to heat their homes. What they do know is the economic impact of a harsh winter is more likely negative than positive.

Ceci Rodgers, CNN Financial News, Chicago.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

VARNEY: And here's another negative for the economy: one report forecasting weakness for months to come. The index of leading indicators, which points to economic conditions six months maybe nine months down the line, declined 0.2 percent in November. The Conference Board, which puts out the survey, said it was looking for significantly slower growth next year.

Quoting the study, quote now, "The economy continues to cool off, run up against limits to growth and suffer from financial market distortions. More recently, there has been an added measure of caution on the part of both businesses and consumers," end quote.

Now here's another industry growing more cautious day by day, and that is the dot.coms. A report released this morning found the number of layoffs at Internet companies continued to rise in December. More than 10,000 dot.com employees lost their jobs this month. Over the last six months, more than 36,000 pink slips have been handed out. That is a 600 percent increase compared to the first six months of the year.

And one dot.com company is taking more drastic measures than just their job cuts, it is liquidating. Quepasa.com, the Spanish-language Internet site, announced today it is closing its doors. Quepasa shares never opened for trading today. The stock, which started the year at just under $13 a share last traded at 13 cents.

Coming up, with Wall Street worried about the health of the U.S. economy, we'll check out the risks from abroad, as a major trading partner, Japan, faces the threat of its own hard landing.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK) VARNEY: As the U.S. economic engine shifts out of high gear, one of this country's biggest trading partners is slowing down even more rapidly.

Peter Viles now on the threat to the U.S. economy from a recession thousands of miles away.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

PETER VILES, CNN ANCHOR: Among economic problems the Bush administration will inherit is the one that frustrated even the firm of Greenspan Rubin and Summers: what to do about Japan.

Economists fear the world's second largest economy is heading into its fourth recession since the early '90s.

C. FRED BERGSTEN, INSTITUTE FOR INTERNATIONAL ECONOMICS: It looks like Japan has already lapsed back into recession. It clearly has slowed down. It's used up most of its policy tools.

VILES: One Japanese prime minister after another has tried to jump start Japan's economy, and all they have to show for it is huge government debt. As one economist put it, Japanese consumers are unwilling to spend, and Japanese banks unwilling to lend.

Part of the problem is Japan's stock market, locked in a 10-year bear market, a lost decade for investors. A worst-case scenario: sinking stock prices and bad debt will ruin some Japanese banks.

BERGSTEN: If it really imploded, if a number of Japanese banks literally went bankrupt, they'd have to call in their loans, their capital from all over the world, a lot of which is in the United States. That would weaken our financial markets, push our interest rates up and cause trouble here just when we need it least.

VILES: A more widespread worry is the growing likelihood of a worldwide economic slowdown led by the two biggest economies.

CLYDE PRESTOWITZ, ECONOMIC STRATEGY INSTITUTE: The impact on the United States of a downturn in Japan will actually probably not be very great. But the impact of a downturn in Japan combined with a slowing U.S. economy could be very serious for the rest of the world, particularly for the countries in the Asia-Pacific region.

VILES: The last time Asian economies took a collective hit was the currency crisis of 1998, an event many believe depressed global prices and actually helped contain inflation in the United States.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

VILES: This time around, though, a slowdown in Asia would clearly be unwelcome news for corporate America. American multinationals have already been hurt by weak demand from Europe and from the United States. A slowdown in Asia would only compound those problems -- Stuart.

VARNEY: Peter, is there anything the incoming Bush administration could do to help Japan at this time?

VILES: Boy, nothing obvious, because if there was the Clinton administration probably would have done it. The biggest economic problems in Japan are home grown. They need structural reform in the financial systems there, very painful reforms that will probably result in the failure of some big institutions. And this is something the Japanese need to take on themselves -- Stuart.

VARNEY: But structural reform cannot come quickly, can it, Peter?

VILES: No, it takes time. And 10 years has essentially been lost here while the Japanese economy has tried fiscal stimulus, government spending and some corporate spending that really hasn't taken hold with the consumers of Japan, who are just sitting on their wallets.

VARNEY: Peter Viles reporting. Thank you, Peter.

Here's another consequence of the Japanese slowdown, it's being felt in the currency markets, the dollar rose to its highest point against the Japanese yen in more than a year, as traders bet that the U.S. economy still offers better prospects than the Japanese.

A different story for the dollar against the single European currency, the euro, which a few months ago had slumped to record lows. It has now rebounded against the greenback.

Up next on MONEYLINE, absolutely, positively have to have it there overnight? Well, get ready to pay more. Why a shipping giant is upping prices.

We'll be back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

VARNEY: In tonight's "Profile," an executive who's seen better days, the outgoing CEO of Network Associates, William Larson.

In 1993, the Sun Microsystems VP took over the little-known computer-virus protection company. Under his leadership, sales grew from $20 million to $900 million. And the hard-charging executive oversaw more than 45 acquisitions.

Larson once became so determined to take over his competition, he said, quote, "I don't care if I make a goddamn dime," end quote.

That may have been one of his problems. The firm, which had a market cap of $19 billion two years ago, now has a market cap of only $627 million. Another CEO will now be in charge in trying to regain that value.

MONEYLINE will be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK) VARNEY: FedEx is feeling the impact of higher fuel prices and the slowing economy, and its customers soon will be paying the price. Starting February 1st, the price for overnight delivery in the U.S. will jump 4.9 percent, and about 3 percent for overseas shipments.

Last week, FedEx warned that 2001 profits would miss expectations, and its stock has promptly fallen 20 percent -- that's this month, by the way. Today, it gained a fraction.

Coming up in our next half hour, bargain hunters storm the Street, fueling a triple-digit blue chip rally and putting the teeth back in the Nasdaq.

Plus, as California takes drastic action to solve its energy crisis, we'll tell you who's plugged in to win and who is losing.

And we'll look back at a year that saw some of high-tech's biggest battles waged in the courtroom. It's the latest in our series on the top business stories of 2000.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

ANNOUNCER: MONEYLINE continues. Here again, Stuart Varney.

VARNEY: And topping today's headlines, Wall Street gains ground as investors emerge to snap up bargains, pushing the Dow to its forth straight gain.

Natural gas prices head into the stratosphere, hitting record highs as much of the country shivers through winter weather.

Plus, we'll look back at this year's legal highlights, from the Microsoft ruling to the Emulex stock scam, we'll check out how events at the courthouse made headlines around the globe.

First, though, more on tonight's top story: Blue chip stocks play host to their fourth straight winning session, whittling away at this year's losses as bargain hunters come out of the woodwork, buying both old economy stalwarts and some tech high-flyers.

The Dow shook off a tough start to rise steadily through the day, gaining nearly 111 points and closing at 10803. The volume just under 1.1 billion shares. And beaten down tech prices drew bidders to the Nasdaq which rose almost 46 points -- that's about 2 percent. It closed at 2539. A strong volume, nearly two billion shares moved on the Nasdaq today. Check the broader markets, the S&P 500 gained nearly 14 points. It closed just under 1329.

Today's gains may have been a pleasant surprise, but the real question is how Wall Street will welcome the new year? Allan Chernoff joins us now from the New York Stock Exchange to answer that one -- Allan.

ALLAN CHERNOFF, CNN CORRESPONDENT: Thank you, Stuart.

Well, we've certainly had some rallies in the past few months, but they've turned out to be duds. Now, money managers are talking up the possibility of an early January rally, and if it does happen, it could be very significant because history would be on the side of the stock market.

The fact is, January serves as barometer for the stock market, specifically the S&P 500. If the S&P 500 is up in January; the market tends to be up and vice versa. It's worked for the past 41 of 50 years -- that's quite a track record over there, and there have been only four significant errors during that period because the other years the S&P 500 ended up or down less than 2 percentage points. And this system has always worked in odd years, and keep in mind we are entering an odd year, 2001.

How well did the system work this year? Well, let's have a look. In January, the S&P 500 is off a little more than 5 percent and you can see year-to-date we're down a bit more than 9 1/2 percent. But you say want an idea of what's going to be happening at the beginning of January?

OK, there's an early warning system the first five trading days of the year and this system has worked 36 of 50 years. And this year, as you can see, the beginning of January we were off about 1 percent and as we said, year-to-date down 9.6 percent. So, Stuart, the bears on Wall Street, they're hoping for bargain hunting come the beginning of January.

Back to you.

VARNEY: I'll bet they are. Allan Chernoff at the big board. Thanks very much, Allan.

Now, check some of the day's big movers: Home Depot led a rebound among retailers. It was up more than 2 points. And 3M gained more than 4. As for Procter & Gamble, it picked up over $2 today. But CNN's parent, Time Warner, sank $4.75, and its merger partner America Online slipped $2.75. Now look at Qualcomm, it jumped more than 6, and JDS Uniphase surged 5 1/2. PMC-Sierra soared nearly 9 1/2 points. Applied Microcircuits added over 8. But Network Associates sank 7 1/4, losing nearly two thirds of its value after warning of a fourth quarter loss.

One item moving skyward today, that's natural gas prices, soaring to their highest levels ever. The cost of January natural gas futures jumped past $10 per million BTU's, boosted by forecasts for a cold weather headed for the Northeast and also for the Midwest.

But most of the headlines over higher energy costs have sprung from another part of the country, and that's California. For months, the Golden State has been plagued by a power crunch, and today California's two largest investor-owned utilities pushed for rate increases to stave off bankruptcy.

Casey Wian reports.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE) CASEY WIAN, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): California regulators began two days of emergency meetings to consider how much help the state's troubled utilities need. They heard a wide variety of proposals, from having the state buy power plants to keeping electricity rates frozen.

Meanwhile, California's governor was in Washington discussing the crisis with President Clinton, following his talks yesterday with the heads of the Federal Reserve and Treasury.

GOV. GRAY DAVIS (D), CALIFORNIA: Deregulation works when you have genuine price competition. That only works when you have some rough balance between supply and demand, which we do not have, and will not have for at least two years.

WIAN: The crisis has already produced its share of winners and losers: politicians in California and nationally are increasingly taking heat for allowing the crisis to escalate. California's decision to stop building power plants more than a decade ago and its failed electricity deregulation efforts are big factors in the energy squeeze.

Some say the Clinton administration and especially federal energy regulators share the blame because of a flawed national energy policy. Also among the losers in the crisis are shareholders of PG&E and Edison International. They've paid a combined $8 billion more for power than they've been able to collect from consumers this year. Both have threatened bankruptcy.

And the state's consumers. Already San Diego electric rates nearly tripled this summer. For much of the rest of the state, rates hikes of up to 20 percent are likely next week.

ANDREW LEVI, CREDIT SUISSE FIRST BOSTON: This has become a nightmare for the politicians; but ultimately, rates have to go up and we have to keep these utilities viable. Bankruptcy is not the option that I think anybody wants to see right now, because bankruptcy is just going to cause a disruption in electricity supply.

WIAN: Environmentalists may soon become losers because of efforts to lift antipollution restrictions and allow new power plant construction. Winners include energy wholesalers supplying California with electricity: shares of Calpine, Duke Energy, Southern Company, Enron, and Dynegy have soared this year.

And alternative energy producers, such as turbine and wind power generators are also cashing in.

(on camera): Perhaps the biggest winner is the City of Los Angeles. Its Department of Water and Power steered clear of electricity deregulation, and now enjoys a power surplus. Its 3.8 million customers have not had an electricity rate increase in almost nine years.

Casey Wian, CNN Financial News, Los Angeles.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

VARNEY: We had other late news on the story. The Energy Department extended an emergency order that forces electricity generators to sell power to California. As for those California utilities, they've had a dismal year while the Dow Jones Utility Index has hit record highs. Edison International is down 48 percent from its high while PG&E closed today at 19 7/8 and that is down 38 percent from its high of the year.

And coming up, we'll hear from one of the many Wall Street analysts who called for a solid showing for the markets this year. Prudential's Ralph Acampora on what went wrong when we come back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

VARNEY: In tonight's MONEYLINE focus: One of Wall Street's best known forecasters, Ralph Acampora. Now back in 1998, he said Dow 10000 was coming. Less than a year later, he was right. The Dow hit the historic 10000 mark in March 1999. This year, its been an altogether different story and a completely different market than Acampora called for. The Dow is nowhere near his year end target of 12500. Now he's eyeing chemicals, drugs and utilities. So, has this market turned one of Wall Street's biggest bulls into a bargain hunter?

Prudential's chief technical strategist Ralph Acampora joins us now.

Welcome back, Ralph.

RALPH ACAMPORA, PRUDENTIAL SECURITIES: Hi, Stuart.

VARNEY: I bet there must have been time this year when you wished you'd never been in the forcasting buisness.

ACAMPORA: Well, I was chewing on my finger nails there for a while. And I think what happened to us is that we hit a bubble. And the bubble was technology. And a lot of that bubble in the technology, when it popped it took the Dow and the S&P down with it.

VARNEY: OK, is it over? Have we seen "the" bottom of the Nasdaq or "a" bottom?

ACAMPORA: Well, I've been saying a bottom. And I still -- I think the jury's still out whether we made the bottom. But the more important thing is what's happening under the surface. And I think you were pointing out before some of the real winners in the past few days, these chemical stocks and the Procter & Gambles. It's the old economy, Stuart, that's coming back. And I think that's what's going to lead and I think for the first time in a a long, long time, you're going to see the Dow do better than the Nasdaq.

VARNEY: But you're known as a bull. And when I say you're a bull, that means pretty much across the board, you expect stock prices to go up. Well, do you take that bullish position that across the board we're in for a rally? ACAMPORA: No, you can't do that.

VARNEY: You're not doing that anymore.

ACAMPORA: In fact -- in fact, if we were to stopped the market right now, tonight, you know the Dow's down about 6.5 percent for the year, and the S&P midcap is actually up 15 percent for the year.

VARNEY: Up?

ACAMPORA: Up. And the Nasdaq is down 34 percent. So you have different parts of the market. And I hope our viewers understand that.

And what's happening now is that we've goten a rotation away from those overvalued stocks that were leading last year. And now you're getting to the undervalued or the old economy. And these are names that everybody knows, like Union Pacific, Procter & Gamble, Allied Products. I mean, there are some real nice names.

VARNEY: All right, would you go after some of the other big-name stocks that are truly beaten town, an AT&T at 17, a WorldCom at 14, a Yahoo! way below 30 -- or it was.

ACAMPORA: I wish I could say that.

VARNEY: No?

ACAMPORA: No, I can't. I really can't. I -- I don't see…

VARNEY: So you don't see a bounce in some of those that are most severely beaten down, just go in a different area?

ACAMPORA: Oh, we'll get a bounce perhaps, but I'm talking about investable participation. No, I don't see that. I'd rather buy a pollution stock like Waste Management, believe it or not, or Philip Morris, believe it or not. They look very, very good.

VARNEY: You've not been saying anything like this for the past three or four years.

ACAMPORA: Exactly right. You're exactly right. In fact, those stocks actually peaked, I think on balance, peaked in July in 1998. They've been out of favor.

Do you remember Warren Buffett? For two years everybody laughed at Buffett. His stocks don't work. Guess what, he's back in vogue. That's it.

VARNEY: Are you still in the forecasting business?

ACAMPORA: The last time I looked, I was.

VARNEY: So give me a number on the Nasdaq for the end of this comming year.

ACAMPORA: I don't have a very big number. I'll say as high as 4000. That's as high as I can get it.

VARNEY: The Dow?

ACAMPORA: I'm still going to try for that 12500.

VARNEY: Brave man. Ralph Acampora, Prudential Securities, thanks very much for coming back to us.

ACAMPAORA: Thanks.

VARNEY: Thank you, Ralph.

Next on MONEYLINE, looking back at the dockets in a jam-packed year for legal drama. The cases that rocked the business world in 2000 as our special year-end series continues.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

VARNEY: It's being described by federal officials as among the first criminal prosecutions in the online auction business. Authorities in Los Angeles have arrested one man and are searching for another suspected of ripping off buyers on eBay. They allegedly offered to sell on the site dozens of computers and other products, took the winning bidders' money and sent them nothing, defrauding nearly 250 buyers out of more than $100,000.

That is just the latest legal case in what's been a very busy year for courtroom controversies. And tonight, we continue our special year-end wrap of the top business stories of 2000 with a look at high-tech law and order.

Steve Young joins us now, with a look at the dramas that kept lawyers on the toes this year -- Steve.

STEVE YOUNG, CNN CORRESPONDENT: Stuart, in the annals of law and order, a judge's decision to split a mammoth company blows away everything else in year 2000 technology.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

(voice-over): The law butted heads this year big-time with the world's richest man, ordering a breakup of his company.

BILL GATES, CHAIRMAN MICROSOFT: This plan would undermine our high-tech economy, hurt consumers, make computers harder to use, and impact thousands of other companies and their employees throughout the high-tech industry.

YOUNG: District Court Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson ruled Microsoft violated antitrust law, abused its Windows monopoly; and in the judge's words, "placed its oppressive thumb on the scale of competitive fortune."

Microsoft will face a new Justice Department in February for two days of arguments in the D.C. Circuit Court of Appeals. Judge Jackson could be reversed in whole or in part, sending the case back to his court. Although if that happens, he might want another judge to step in.

THOMAS PENFIELD JACKSON, U.S. DISTRICT COURT JUDGE: If I am found to be egregiously in error, then even if they didn't remove me from the case, I might very -- think very seriously about removing myself.

YOUNG: Nineteen states say they'll continue to press their Microsoft suit if the Bush administration has less enthusiasm for the case.

Microsoft's foe in Washington, lawyer David Boies, was Napster's friend in California. The music industry considered the Web site's Internet file-swapping technology a monster threat. The recording industry won a temporary injunction, but then an appellate court granted a reprieve.

DAVID BOIES, NAPSTER ATTORNEY: This is a decision that says we're going to hold everything in place. We're going to preserve the status quo. We're going to let Napster continue to service its listeners and users until we have a chance -- that is, we, the Court of Appeals, have a chance to consider the case its merits.

YOUNG: Later, with the case still hanging, Napster won a $50 million deal, giving Bertelsmann, parent of BMG Records, a majority stake.

Half a world away, Onel De Guzman, a Philippines student, was apprehended after allegedly unleashing the most destructive computer virus in history. Nicknamed the "love bug," the virus wiped out PC hard drives, crippled corporate e-mail systems, and cost business at least $1 billion.

STEPHEN BARR, VICE PRESIDENT, PREDICTIVE SYSTEMS: The Philippines don't have any cybercrime law, so current charges are under credit card crime laws, and they or may not be fully applicable.

YOUNG: It turned out De Guzman could not be prosecuted, but a new Philippine law on cybercrime has been enacted since then.

A little known company, Emulex, grabbed headlines when its stock fell victim to a stunning Internet scam. Authorities say 23-year-old Mark Jacob, a California student, sent a bogus press release to his former employer, Internet Newswire, falsely claiming Emulex was restating earnings.

PAUL FOLINO, CEO, EMULEX: It actually had the name of one of our investor-relations employees and her telephone number on it, just like you would see from a normal press release.

YOUNG: In a wild sell-off, Emulex lost two-thirds of its value before rebounding to close down just 8 percent. Authorities say Jacob made a quarter million dollars by selling Emulex stock short.

As the year wound down, the age of Internet stock-fraud suspects plunged precipitously. KEVIN MERINO, LAWYER: He is in many ways the normal 15-year-old: likes sports, a big New York Met fan, likes music and contemporary literature and what have you, likes hanging out with his friends.

YOUNG: Jonathan Lebed of Cedar Grove, New Jersey, was not quite your typical kid. The Securities and Exchange Commission said Lebed liked pumping and dumping microcap stocks, using the Internet, protecting himself by using sell orders.

RONALD LONG, SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION: That would allow him to then go to school, be in class while the -- knowing that his 200 to 300 false postings would have moved the price and that he would sell and make a profit while he was sitting in class.

YOUNG: In settling with the SEC, Lebed gave back $285,000. But he was allowed to keep even more money from other trades.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

YOUNG: In all these cases, electronic sleuthing, whether through surveillance software or just plain old e-mail, enabled the good guys to track down their suspects. That underscores a truth of the information age: Technology makes life easier -- on both sides of the law -- Stuart.

VARNEY: Nicely put. Steve Young, thanks very much.

Well, of course, the courtroom controversies haven't been confined to high-tech.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

VARNEY (voice-over): Perhaps the biggest this year, the uproar over Firestone tires on Ford Explorers. Reports of tread separation unleashed federal investigations, a flood of lawsuits and a PR nightmare for both companies.

There was a huge development in the long-running battle over tobacco. During the summer, a Florida jury ordered cigarette companies to pay nearly $145 billion to sick smokers in history's biggest punitive damage award.

A very different case rocked the art world when former Sotheby's chief executive Diana Brooks pleaded guilty this fall to price fixing charges, settling with federal authorities in a sweeping antitrust case against the auction house.

From the New York art scene to the Hollywood hills, another fallen hotshot. Dana Giachetto, the investment adviser to stars like Leonardo DiCaprio, pleaded guilty to a scheme that cost his clients as much $10 million.

But perhaps the most sordid fall from grace, former investment banker James McDermott, convicted last spring of passing insider tips to Kathryn Gannon, better known in the adult film world, as Marilyn Star. (END VIDEOTAPE)

VARNEY: All right. just ahead, the markets may have turned around today, but our financial editor Myron Kandel is watching some other dark clouds on the horizon. More on potential trouble spots, when we come back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

VARNEY: Our financial editor likes to look on the bright side of life, and that stood him in very good stead in this difficult year. But tonight, there's a couple of dark clouds on his horizon. Here is Myron Kandel. What are they, Mike?

MYRON KANDEL, CNN FINANCIAL EDITOR: Well, Stuart, first, I like what the stock market did today.

VARNEY: Oh, yes, 12000 by the end of January. You just love it today, don't you?

KANDEL: But I'm worried about a couple of things: one at home and one at abroad. First, and we've discussed these, the Japanese economy is verging on maybe even depression. Retail sales down four months in a row. Consumer spending falling. Unemployment at an eight-month high. It could have an impact on the global economy as well as in Japan, particularly Southeast Asia. That's a period -- that's a place we should worry about.

VARNEY: I'm going to interrupt because you know, we always think of Alan Greenspan as the central banker to the world these days, not just the United States. Could he step in and try to do something about Japan's situation? Is that possible?

KANDEL: Well, I -- look, the governor of California went to speak to him about that. I'm going to talk about that in a minute, but, you know, I think that might even lead the Fed to drop interest rates faster than it normally expected. I think we could see drop in interest rates before the next Fed meeting. You know, that's a possibility maybe within -- in the middle of January rather than the end.

But let me turn to my other point of worry -- the California energy crisis. Don't forget, California accounts for 12 percent of the total U.S. GDP. I mean, that's a major amount and California is already affected by the technology slowdown. So that's -- those are two places I'm worried about. Not panicking yet, but I'm worried about them and I think we have to keep an eye on them.

VARNEY: So, the California energy crisis could rebound to a slowing of the California economy? It could have that effect, you think?

KANDEL: Yes, and on the national economy as well. I think Alan Greenspan is aware of that. The governor just told him about it yesterday.

VARNEY: But here's two negatives, and you're looking for 12000 on the Dow in January. OK, we've got to go. Thanks, Mike.
